author: Aswathi, G. and Dhivya, R.
title: Assessment of the ant diversity in Chethallur Village in Palakkad District, Kerala, India
note: Part of FORMIS 23; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: *[This study was conducted in the Chethallur village, an agricultural village, in Palakkad District, Kerala, India.  The study was carried out from October 2020 to January 2021, on the river banks, adjoining fields, cultivated lands, & residence areas of study site.  Intensive all out search method (manual collection of ant species by using a brush & forceps) during daytime from 9 am to 6 pm at regular intervals every day was employed in the study.  Generally, morning time & evening time gave good results.  Results from this preliminary study, revealed 21 species of ants belonging to 14 genera & 4 subfamilies.]          *[ NOTE: These identifications needs to be confirmed.  Camponotus atriceps is a neotropical species.  Camponotus herculeanus is a Holarctic species.  Camponotus japonicus, Formica rufa, & Lasius niger are temperate palearctic species.  Camponotus modoc, Camponotus pennsylvanicus, Liometopum occidentale, Novomessor cockerelli, & Tapinoma sessile are North American species.  Dinoponera gigantea is a South American species.  Linepithema humile is an invasive species, that has not been reported from India.  Myrmecia pilosula is an Australian species; it is in the subfamily Myrmeciinae, not Myrmicinae.  Oecophylla longinoda is an African species.  Pheidole pallidula is a west-Mediterranean species.]          *[ NOTE: This identification needs to be confirmed.  India would be a significant range extension for the invasive species Solenopsis invicta.  All previous reports of S. invicta from India are marked as dubious; https://www.antwiki.org/wiki/Solenopsis_invicta  checked 11Oct22.]

author: Aswathi, P. and Gayathri, P. and Sabu, K.T.
title: Nesting trees of weaver ants in a rural agroecosystem in South Malabar
abstract: *[Introduction & maintenance of weaver ants for insect pest management in agribelts requires data on the host plant trees which can support weaver ant colonies.  This study was carried out to identify the preferred native host plants species in the rural agriculture belts of North Malabar region.  Twenty-two plants were identified with 6 plants (Strychnos nux-vomica (Poison nut tree), Cinnamum verum (Cinnamon tree), Persea macrantha (Machilus), Mimusops elengi (Bulletwood tree), Magnifera indica (Mango), & Artocarpus heterophyllus (Jackfruit tree)) as most preferred & 7 plants (Zanthoxylum rhetsa (Indian prickly ash), Syzygium malaccense (Wax apple), Olea dioica (Indian olive tree), Cassia fistula (Cassia), Alianthus excelsa (Tree of heaven), Anacardium occidentale (Cashew tree), & Litsea wightiana (Litsea)) as moderately preferred host plants.  High preference towards major plants is linked to their evergreen nature, large sized leaves, honey production, & nectar production & to reduced human interference in the canopy due to their status as non-utility trees in agrihabitats.  Lesser preference towards the moderate host plants is linkedto the presence of crazy yellow ants & their deciduous habits during dry season.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Anoplolepis gracilipes; Oecophylla smaragdina; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; distribution; nests; nest sites; nest tree preference, biocontrol; weaver ants; yellow crazy ants;

author: Aswathi, P. and Jobi, M.C. and Thomas, S.K.
title: Biocontrol of home invading rubber litter beetle, Luprops tristis with weaver ants (Oecophylla smaragdina)
abstract: *[Predatory efficiency of weaver ants, Oecophylla smaragdina, Fabricius, on Luprops tristis (Fabricius) (Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae) were tested in both lab & field conditions.  Active predation of the weaver ants on the beetles during both nocturnal & diurnal conditions & the non-deterrence by the gland secretions indicates that weaver ants is an efficient natural predator of L. tristis, & has the potential to be used as an effective biocontrol agent to regulate the population build up of L. tristis.  However, the lack of host plants of weaver ants in the monoculture rubber plantations & the negative attitude of stakeholders in view of their aggressiveness may hinder the introduction of weaver ants as an effective predator of L. tristis in rubber plantations.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Oecophylla smaragdina; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; prey; litter; impact; agricultural; rubber plantation; urban; houses;

author: Aswathi, P. and Ravi, A. and Sabu, K.T.
title: Insect groups, host plants and flowering pattern of mistletoes in a semiurban agricultural landscape
abstract: *[Details of the host plants, phenology of flowering, & composition of insects associated with the common mistletoe in a semiurban agriculture landscape is provided.  High abundance of weaver ants indicates that mistletoes are an alternate food resource & nesting plant for weaver ants in the mango tree dominated agrilands.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Oecophylla smaragdina; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; distribution; nests; nest sites; impact; agricultural; mangos; biocontrol; weaver ants; black ants;

author: Aswathi, P. and Thomas, S.K.
title: Weaver ant (Oecophylla smaragdina), huntsman spider (Heteropoda venatoria) and house gecko (Hemidactylus frenatus) as potential biocontrol agents of the nuisance pest, Luprops tristis
abstract: *[The influence of defensive glands of rubber litter beetle, Luprops tristis, in determining the feeding preference of the huntsman spider (Heteropoda venatoria), weaver ant (Oecophylla smaragdina), & house gecko (Hemidactylus frenatus) on Luprops & the feeding preference of the predators are tested.  House geckos & spiders are deterred by the presence of defensive gland, while weaver ants are not deterred by the gland.  Higher consumption of Luprops by weaver ants establishes that among the 3 predators tested, weaver ants are the most efficient predator of the Luprops & has potential in the biocontrol of Luprops in rubber plantations.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Oecophylla smaragdina; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; prey; biocontrol; natural enemies; Rubber litter beetle;

author: Aswathi, P. and Thomas, S.K.
title: Weaver ants and biocontrol of the nuisance pest Luprops tristis (Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae)
booktitle: Basic and Applied Aspects of Biopesticides
editor: Sahayaraj, K.
abstract: *[The utility of weaver ants (Oecophylla smaragdina Fabricius, 1775), & their potential in the control of agricultural pests, is highlighted.  Comprehensive data on its habits, habitat requirements, foraging behavior, social organization; polyethism; polydomy; nesting behavior, aggressiveness, & biocontrol agent of the main insect pests in cashew, citrus, & mango are listed.  Identification of weaver ants as the sole arthropod predator that prey upon the nuisance pest Luprops tristis Fabricius, 1801, in rubber plantations & its possibility as an effective biocontrol agent to regulate the beetles are detailed.  Lack of nesting trees in monoculture rubber plantations & the negative attitude of people towards weaver ants will hinder the establishment of weaver ants as an effective predator & biocontrol agent of L. tristis in rubber plantations.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Oecophylla smaragdina; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; weaver ants; impact; agricultural; rubber; nuisance pest; biocontrol potential; natural enemies;

author: Aupanun, S. and Jaitrong, W. and Suttiprapan, P. and Peeters, C. and Ito, F.
title: Nest architecture, worker reproduction, and polygyny in the ponerine ant Harpegnathos venator
note: Part of FORMIS 23; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: The Indian jumping ant Harpegnathos saltator is one of the most well-studied ant species; however, little is known about the biology and behavior of sister species in the genus. To understand the universality of the phenomena revealed in H. saltator, biological studies of closely related species are important. We investigated the nest architecture and colony reproductive structure of Harpegnathos venator at two sites in northern Thailand. Nests had chimney-like entrances with a funnel diameter of about 3 cm and consisted of two or three chambers, the floors of which were flat and smooth. The floors and walls inside the chambers were decorated with several small fragments of cocoons, which has been referred to as wall-papering. Most colonies included one or more mated dealate queens that laid eggs, whereas only a few mated workers reproduced in the queenright colonies. In our sampling, virgin dealate queens were found in several colonies, but there were very few queenless colonies that reproduced by mated workers. Additional colonies collected from three other sites in Thailand also had dealate queens. The H. venator colonies reproduced mainly by mated queens, although many mated workers were present. The nest architecture of H. venator was similar to that of H. saltator, but the colony reproductive structure was different: queen colonies of H. saltator are always monogynous, and queenless colonies that reproduce by gamergates are frequently found. Furthermore, virgin dealate queens are never found in H. saltator. Factors affecting these differences between the two congeneric species are discussed.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Harpegnathos venator; Ponerinae; Asia; Thailand; scientific; workers; alates; dealate queens; gamergate; colonies; worker reproduction; monogyny; polygyny; nests; nest architecture; nest structure; behavior; wall-papering;

author: Ayyanar, M. and Silambarasan, R. and Sureshkumar, J. and Gurav, S.S.
title: Reproductive biology of East Indian satinwood (Chloroxylon swietenia DC., Rutaceae: Sapindales), a threatened timber-yielding tree
note: Part of FORMIS 22; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Chloroxylon swietenia DC. (Rutaceae) is widely used in folk medicine and provides a commercial timber. In the present study, phenological events such as flowering and fruiting phenology, pollinator visitation, anthesis, pollen viability, and pollen tube germination tests were analyzed in 11 populations, in Tamil Nadu, India. The number of flowers was recorded as 82.6 ± 1.4 to 162.2 ± 4.2 during flower bud formation and reduced to 25.4 ± 0.5 to 61.8 ± 1.0 at maturity. The number of fruits per twig was 21.0 ± 0.8 to 47.2 ± 0.7 in initial stages and slightly reduced to 16.2 ± 1.8 to 34.6 ± 1.4 at maturation. Sixty-two species of insects were visiting the flowers with bees/ants as effective pollinators. The 2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide assay revealed more viable pollen grains in five populations, and fluorescence dye assay revealed maximum viable pollen grains in six populations. In the pollen tube germination test, the 60% sucrose concentration provides significant results, with a high number of germinated pollen grains. Principal component analysis of flowering and fruiting phenology, floral visitors, and pollen viability showed 79.5%, 79.3%, 56.7%, and 41.7% for the first factor, respectively. Our results indicated that C. swietenia depends heavily on pollinators for its reproduction. Hence, there is a need to expand this study to related species which are having agronomic, pharmacological, and economic potential.          *[Text (p.216) says 8 species of ants were recognized as pollinators; only 4 listed in supplementary data.]          *[This identification needs to be checked.  Monomorium minimum is a North American species and not previously reported from India.  AntWiki 21May22.]

author: Azc·rate, F.M. and Manzano, P.
title: A fable on voracious and gourmet ants: Ant-seed interactions from predation to dispersal
booktitle: Predation in the Hymenoptera: An evolutionary perspective
editor: Polidori, C.
note: Part of FORMIS 12; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW, verified-PW.
abstract: *[Ants & seeds show a variety of interactions, from generalist seed harvesters to more selective elaiosome-eating ants.  Seed harvesting by ants is an interaction typical of non-forested systems from mid & low latitudes.  Most aspects of the foraging strategy of harvester ants can be interpreted as a time-saving policy.  Ants take advantage of the limited periods of time in which activity outside the nest is feasible to collect as many seeds as possible, using in many cases a trunk trail system to access to the foraging patches.  This voracious strategy inflicts severe seed losses to certain plant species.  However, harvester ants also behave as accidental seed dispersers (dyszoochory) by dropping or mislaying seeds in foraging areas, foraging trails, chaff piles; & granary chambers.  The alteration of local microsite conditions caused by harvester ants can be beneficial for the dispersed seeds.  In contrast to the less-discerning seed harvesters, some seed-feeding ants behave as true gourmets.  Myrmecochory is an interaction that requires selective ants to collect elaiosome-bearing seeds & disperse them after consuming the elaiosome.  Ants obtain nutritional benefits from myrmecochory, valuable in quality rather than in quantity.  Plants can benefit from an increase in dispersal distance, predator avoidance, reduction of kinship among seeds & arrival to favorable microsites.  The interaction can be vital for plants, & is highly dependent on the ant species that collects the diaspore.  A third type of interaction involving seeds & ants is diplochory.  In this case, seeds experience 2 phases of dispersal, usually a combination of a coarse & a fine event.  Ants can participate in diplochory by collecting coarsely dispersed seeds & transporting them to favorable microsites.  Many diplochorous plants offer a reward for frugivores in the form of fruit pulp, as well as a reward for ants in the form of an elaiosome.  In other cases, the seeds can be secondarily dispersed by dyszoochory rather than by myrmecochory.]          [NOTE: S. saevissima is S. invicta or S. richteri in North America.]

author: Azhagu Raj, R. and Sathish, R. and Prakasam, A. and Krishnamoorthy, D. and Balachandar, M.
title: Diversity and distribution of ant species (Hymenoptera: Formicidae), in Pachaiyappa's College, Kanchipuram, Tamil Nadu, India
note: Part of FORMIS 17; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[We studied the ant species diversity & distribution at Pachaiyappa's college for Men campus, Kanchipuram, Tamil Nadu, India.  Ant species were collected from the 3 zones of the college campus, with the help of baits, All out Search Method, & Hand Collection Method during post monsoon seasons.  In the studied area, a total of 10 species belonging to 9 genera in 4 subfamilies of ants were recorded.  Formicinae was the most dominant subfamily in terms of species richness (5 species), followed by Myrmicinae (3 species), Pseudomyrmicinae (1 species), & Dolichoderinae (1 species).  One-way ANOVA proved that significant differences was found between ant species composition in various months.  Similarity indices showed that zone-I & zone-II were similar in ant species composition, diversity, & species richness in the college campus.]          **Solenopsis geminata misspelled Solenopsis geminate in Table 2 & text; incorrectly listed as Formicinae in Tables 1 & 2, it is in the subfamily Myrmicinae.  Trichomyrmex glaber (AndrÈ, 1883) is a Myrmicinae, not Dolichoderinae, Table 2; there are no Dolichoderinae listed in this publication.

author: Azuma, N. and Ogata, K. and Kikuchi, T. and Higashi, S.
title: Phylogeography of Asian weaver ants, Oecophylla smaragdina
note: Part of FORMIS 10; from NAL'S AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: The phylogeography of Oecophylla smaragdina was studied using the mitochondrial cytochrome b gene (Cytb), cytochrome oxidase subunit I (COI), and nuclear long-wavelength opsin gene (LW Rh). Weaver ants were collected from 35 localities and from one to nine colonies per locality. Neighbor-joining trees inferred from 647 bp of Cytb and 1,026 bp of COI using Oecophylla longinoda as an outgroup indicated that the haplotypes of O. smaragdina were clearly separated into seven groups: group 1 of India excluding West Bengal; group 2 of Bengal, Indochinese Peninsula, Malay Peninsula and Greater Sunda Islands, including Lombok and Sumbawa; group 3 of the Philippines; group 4 of Flores; group 5 of Sulawesi; group 6 of Halmahera; and group 7 of New Guinea and Australia. This grouping was also supported by a strict consensus tree derived from maximum parsimony and maximum likelihood trees. In addition, two haplotypes of LW Rh were found in O. smaragdina: one in group 2 and another in all the other groups. Comparison to haplotypes in other hymenopteran species suggests that group 2 is younger than other groups of O. smaragdina. The clustering of the seven groups was coincident with geological evidence of the distribution of continents, islands, and seas during glacial periods.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Oecophylla longinoda; Oecophylla smaragdina; Formicinae; Africa; Cameroon; Asia; Bangladesh; India; Indonesia; Biak; Bali; Flores; Greater Sunda Islands; Halmahera; Java; Krakatau; Lombok; Sulawesi; Sumatra; Sumbawa; Kalimantan; Malaysia; Philippines; Thailand; New Guinea; Vietnam; Australia; scientific; genetics; mitochondrial DNA; mitochondrial cytochrome b gene; Cytb; cytochrome oxidase subunit I; COI; nuclear long-wavelength opsin gene; LW Rh; distribution; phylogeny; phylogeography;

author: Babu, M.J.
title: Antennal sensilla of the weaver ant Oecophylla smaragdina (F.)- males and females sense differently?
abstract: *[This study explores the sexual dimorphism in Oecophylla smaragdina with respect to antennal morphology, morphometry, & sensilla profile, which are often considered key components of the peripheral sensory system.  Scanning electron microscopic (SEM) studies revealed that the sensilla profile on the antenna probably reflects the sensitivity.  Antennal morphology & sensilla profile differ in males & females.  Sensilla profile of the females (major worker) is different in the number & types of chemosensilla.  Sensilla basiconica type1 & type 2, sensilla trichoidea curvata, sensilla ampullacea, & sensilla coeloconica were the abundant ones observed on the female antenna.  Males have sparse sensilla, & their putative sensilla basiconicais are strikingly different.]

author: Babu, M.J. and Ankolekar, S.M. and Rajashekhar, K.P.
title: Castes of the weaver ant Oecophylla smaragdina (Fabricius) differ in the organization of sensilla on their antennae and mouthparts
abstract: *[This study addresses whether individual castes (queen, major, or minor) of the weaver ant, Oecophylla smaragdina (Fabricius) differ in the organization of the chemosensory structures on the antenna, maxillary, & labial palps. The sensory structures were studied by light & scanning electron microscopy.  It was observed that the sensilla numbers differ among the 3 castes, whereas all the 3 castes possess similar types of chemosensilla.]

author: Babu, M.J. and Patil, R.K.
title: Antennal lobe organisation in ant, Oecophylla smaragdina: A Golgi study
note: Part of FORMIS 24; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Antennal lobes (AL) are the primary olfactory centres of the insect brain, the organisation of which reflects the chemosensory repertoire of the insect. The sensory neurons from the antenna, local neurons (LNs), and projection neurons (PNs) constitute the neuropilar organisation of the AL, which often varies according to the ecology and behaviour of the insects. We explored the organisation of the AL in the ant Oecophylla smaragdina through Golgi analysis and other standard histological procedures. Six topographically distinct glomerular clusters were noticed in the AL. AL volume, total number of glomeruli and its spatial organisation were different in the castes of Oecophylla smaragdina. We could count 220 glomeruli in the AL of the major worker, whereas only 140 glomeruli were located in AL of minor workers. LNs with their cell body located on the dorsal, dorso-lateral, ventral, ventro-lateral, and medial position of the AL were characterised. Most of the LNs are oligoglomerular. Uniglomerular and multiglomerular PNs were also identified. The results underline a caste specific organisation of the AL in Oecophylla smaragdina. The characterised LNs and PNs further reveals the complex neural circuitry involved in the processing of important chemical cues related to the lifestyle of the ant.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Oecophylla smaragdina; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; morphology; antennal lobe; Golgi analysis; local neurons; projection neurons; neural circuitry; glomeruli; glomerular clusters; caste specific organisation; histology; behavior;

author: Badwaik, V.J.
title: An initial checklist of the ants (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) and their specific distribution from District Wardha, Maharashtra, India
note: Part of FORMIS 23; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[In this study, the comprehensive list of ant species & their distribution in Wardha District from 2019 to 2021 was studied.  The habitats selected to study the diversity of ants is agricultural field, domestic habitats, tree plantations, & surrounding water bodies.  This is the first checklist of ant recorded in 8 tehsil places (Seloo, Wardha, Deoli, Arvi, Ashti, Karanja, Hinganghat, Samudrapur) of Wardha District.  The ant species recorded belong to 6 subfamilies: Dolichoderinae, Dorylinae, Formicinae, Myrmicinae, Ponerinae, & Pseudomyrmecinae.  A total of 57 species belonging to the 30 genera are recorded in the district.  The species diversity index is higher in agricultural fields followed by domestic habitats.  The generic richness is highest for Camponotus (8 spp.) & Crematogaster (6 spp.).]          *[Camponotus inconsistently misspelled Componotus; Pseudomyrmecinae misspelled in abstract.]

author: Baidya, P. and Bagchi, S.
title: A new species of Protanilla Taylor 1990 (Hymenoptera: Formicidae: Leptanillinae) from India
abstract: *[Protanilla flamma sp.n. from Goa, India is described, which is the thirteenth species in the genus Protanilla & the second record of this genus from India.  Morphologically, the new species appears close to P. lini Terayama, 2009 in terms of mandibular teeth count & the structure of petiolar & post-petiolar nodes.  However, it can be very easily differentiated based on the short antennal scape, which does not exceed the posterior margin of the head.]

author: Baidya, P. and Bagchi, S.
title: Influence of human land use and invasive species on beta diversity of tropical ant assemblages
note: Part of FORMIS 22; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: Understanding how biodiversity is distributed is increasingly becoming important under ongoing and projected human land use. Measures of beta diversity, and its partitions, can offer insights for conservation and restoration of biodiversity. We ask how different species, functional groups, and land use contribute to beta diversity, and whether invasive species have a negative influence on beta diversity. We address these questions using ant assemblages (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) at 277 sites distributed across five geomorphic land use types in Goa, India. We recorded 68 species (35 genera, 7 subfamilies) of which 5 were invasive. We classified them into eight functional groups. Oecophylla smaragdinaa common tropical arboreal species, and Anoplolepis gracilepisa globally significant invasive, contributed the most to beta diversity. Largebodied omnivores which may influence soil functions contributed more to beta diversity than smallbodied predators. Lateritic plateaus contributed most to beta diversity, whereas humaninfluenced plantations contributed the least. Beta diversity across sites was related to species turnover, whereas nestedness was more prominent for functional groups. This indicates how species replace one another with change in land use, but functional roles are lost despite such turnover. Sites with human land use had higher incidence of invasive species, and invaded sites contributed less to beta diversity than noninvaded sites. Human land use strongly influences diversity and distribution of ant assemblages. Land use may spare local species richness, but not functional groups. A small number of invasive species exert negative influence even in very speciose communities.

author: Bain, A. and Harrison, R.D. and Schatz, B.
title: How to be an ant on figs
note: Part of FORMIS 14; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Mutualistic interactions are open to exploitation by one or other of the partners and a diversity of other organisms, and hence are best understood as being embedded in a complex network of biotic interactions. Figs participate in an obligate mutualism in that figs are dependent on agaonid fig wasps for pollination and the wasps are dependent on fig ovules for brood sites. Ants are common insect predators and abundant in tropical forests. Ants have been recorded on approximately 11% of fig species, including all six subgenera, and often affect the fig-fig pollinator interaction through their predation of either pollinating and parasitic wasps. On monoecious figs, ants are often associated with hemipterans, whereas in dioecious figs ants predominantly prey on fig wasps. A few fig species are true myrmecophytes, with domatia or food rewards for ants, and in at least one species this is linked to predation of parasitic fig wasps. Ants also play a role in dispersal of fig seeds and may be particularly important for hemi-epiphytic species, which require high quality establishment microsites in the canopy. The intersection between the fig-fig pollinator and ant-plant systems promises to provide fertile ground for understanding mutualistic interactions within the context of complex interaction networks.

author: Baiswar, P. and Firake, D.M.
title: First record of Pandora formicae on ant, Camponotus angusticollis and Batkoa amrascae on white leaf hopper, Cofana spectra in rice agroecosystem of India
note: Part of FORMIS 24; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Two entomophthoralean fungi, Pandora formicae and Batkoa amrascae were reported for the first time from India as a dominant biocontrol agents of Camponotus angusticollis and Cofana spectra, respectively in rice agroecosystem. The biocontrol potential of B. amrascae studied under field conditions during 2012-2016 showed its ability in drastically reducing the population of C. spectra in rice fields and the nursery and could be used as a potential biocontrol agent against white leaf hopper.

author: Bakalial, B.
title: Ant (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) diversity of Bahona College Campus, Jorhat, Assam with some new records for the state
note: Part of FORMIS 23; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[This study was carried out explore the ant species present in the Bahona College campus of Jorhat, Assam.  A total of 39 species of ants were recorded during the study representing 6 subfamilies.  The subfamily Formicinae included 19 species, followed by Myrmicinae (10 species), Ponerinae (5 species), Dolichoderinae (3 species), Dorlyinae (one species), & Pseudomyrmecinae (one species).  Camponotus had 10 species, Polyrhachis 6 spp., Diacamma 4 spp., & Monomorium 3 spp., & the other genera contained one or 2 spp. each.  Five species of ants: Camponotus irritans (Smith, 1857), Camponotus radiatus Forel, 1892, Camponotus sericeus (Fabricius, 1798), Polyrhachis bicolor Smith, 1858, & Polyrhachis abdominalis Smith, 1858 are recorded for the first time from Assam.]          *[Camponotus radiatus misspelled Camponotus radiates; Carebara misspelled Cerabera; Diacamma assamense misspelled Diacamma assamensis; Solenopsis cf. geminata misspelled Solenopsis cf. germinate.]

author: Baker, A.J. and Heraty, J.M. and Mottern, J. and Zhang, J. and Hines, H.M. and Lemmon, A.R. and Lemmon, E.M.
title: Inverse dispersal patterns in a group of ant parasitoids (Hymenoptera: Eucharitidae: Oraseminae) and their ant hosts
note: Part of FORMIS 21; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: When postulating evolutionary hypotheses for diverse groups of taxa using molecular data, there is a tradeoff between sampling large numbers of taxa with a few Sangersequenced genes or sampling fewer taxa with hundreds to thousands of nextgenerationsequenced genes. High taxon sampling enables the testing of evolutionary hypotheses that are sensitive to sampling bias (i.e. dating, biogeography and diversification analyses), whereas high character sampling improves resolution of critical nodes. In a group of ant parasitoids (Hymenoptera: Eucharitidae: Oraseminae), we analyse both of these types of datasets independently (203 taxa with five Sanger loci, 92 taxa with 348 anchored hybrid enrichment loci) and in combination (229 taxa, 353 loci) to explore divergence dating, biogeography, host relationships and differential rates of diversification. Oraseminae specialize as parasitoids of the immature stages of ants in the subfamily Myrmicinae (Hymenoptera: Formicidae), with ants in the genus Pheidole being their most common and presumed ancestral host. A general assumption is that the distribution of the parasite must be limited by any range contraction or expansion of its host. Recent studies support a single New World to Old World dispersal pattern for Pheidole at c. 11-27	Ma. Using multiple phylogenetic inference methods (parsimony, maximum likelihood, dated Bayesian and coalescent analyses), we provide a robust phylogeny showing that Oraseminae dispersed in the opposite direction, from Old World to New World, c. 24-33	Ma, which implies that they existed in the Old World before their presumed ancestral hosts. Their dispersal into the New World appears to have promoted an increased diversification rate. Both the host and parasitoid show single unidirectional dispersals in accordance with the presence of the Beringian Land Bridge during the Oligocene, a time when the changing northern climate probably limited the dispersal ability of such tropically adapted groups.          *[Ant species listed from Table S1: Oraseminae ant and plant host records.]

author: Bala, M. and Kaur, P.
title: Insect faunal succession on buried piece of pork in the State of Punjab (India): A preliminary study
abstract: *[Successional studies were carried out on 5-kg of pork piece used as research model which was clothed with the cotton cloth & buried at a depth of 30cm in the forest area of Ghawaddi village of Ludhiana (Punjab) (India).  The pork was exhumed 2 times a day (morning & evening).  The entire process of decomposition took 16 days & was divided into 4 decompositional stages (fresh, bloated, active decay, decay stage).  A total 10 beetle species belonging to 6 families (Euspilotus assimilis, Saprinus pensylvanicus, Saprinus sp. (Histeridae), Gonocephalum patruele, Typhaea stercorea, Tenebrio molitor (Tenebrionidae), Dermestes maculatus (Dermestidae), Hybosorus sp. (Scarabidae), Pterostichus melanarius (Carabidae), & Necrobia sp. (Cleridae)) were observed.  Two ant species, Camponotus compressus & Pheidole indica, were observed during different stages of decomposition.  Ants were found in abundance on the pork piece, comprising 34% of insect fauna associated with pork decomposition.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Camponotus compressus; Pheidole indica; Formicinae; Myrmicinae; Asia; India; scientific; forensic entomology; decomposition; succession;

author: Bala, M. and Kaur, P.
title: Entomofauna on decomposed piece of pork: Study on delayed burial
note: Part of FORMIS 18; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Studies on insect succession pattern in buried piece of pork revealed the presence of 41 insect specimens belonging to 3 orders, 9 families and 13 species. 10 specimens belonging to 4 families and 5 species from order Diptera were observed. These are Chrysomya megacephala (Calliphoridae) Sarcophaga sp. (Sarcophagidae), Musca domestica, Musca autumnalis (Muscidae) and Anthomyia sp. (Anthomyiidae). 14 specimens belonging to 4 families and 6 species from order Coleoptera were observed and these are Euspilotus assimilis & Saprinus sp. (Histeridae), Dermestes maculatus (Dermestidae), Gonocephalum patruele, Typhaea stercorea (Tenebrionidae), Pterostichus melanarius (Carabidae) and 17 specimens belonging to 2 species i.e. Pheidole indica and Camponotus compressus of family formicidae from order hymenoptera were also observed in this experiment.

author: Balaji, R.K. and Kumar, K.
title: Arthropod diversity in mango at Karaikal
abstract: *[The diversity of arthropod fauna of the mango ecosystem & their population dynamics was studied in Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru College of Agriculture & Research Institute, Union Territory of Puducherry, from August 2016 to February 2017.  The fauna was collected at weekly intervals with net sweeping method, pitfall traps, & in situ counts.  The biodiversity analysis with Shannon-Wiener index & Margalef richness index revealed that the diversity was more for Coleoptera (3.0220 and 5.0520); Simpson's index was maximum for Orthoptera (0.1846), & equitability index maximum with Neuroptera (1.00).  Among the 127 arthropods observed, the incidence of Polyrhachis spp. revealed a positive correlation with maximum temperature, evening relative humidity, rainfall, & a negative correlation with minimum temperature & morning relative humidity.]          *[Polyrhachis rastellata misspelled Polyrhachis rastella; Tetraponera rufonigra misspelled Tetraponera rufouigra.]

author: Balakrishna, S. and Batabyal, A. and Thaker, M.
title: Dining in the city: Dietary shifts in Indian rock Agamas across an urban-rural landscape
note: Part of FORMIS 17; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Rapid urbanization is a growing threat to biodiversity, causing wide-scale extirpation of species from their natural habitats. Some species such as rock agamas, Psammophilus dorsalis, seem to be sufficiently tolerant and continue to persist in urban environments. Given that urbanization alters species composition at multiple trophic levels, we expect a shift in the diet composition and hunting modes of populations across rural and urban areas. Based on identified contents from stomach flushes, we found that P. dorsalis are generally myrmecophagous, and their diet is mainly composed of ants (Hymenoptera: Formicidae). Diet of males and females in each area overlapped highly (80-91%), even though males were significantly larger than females. Dietary overlap between urban and rural populations also was high (80.3%). Surprisingly, rural lizards had lower body mass indices than did urban lizards, despite the greater diversity of prey types and the larger volume of food consumed. This species uses a sit-and-wait hunting strategy, but we found that the rate of movement of males was higher in rural areas compared to urban areas, which likely results in higher energy expenditure. Individuals of P. dorsalis do not seem to be negatively affected by urbanization but instead manage to hunt in and around the small patches of vegetation that remain, enabling them to maintain a higher body condition than that of lizards in undisturbed rural habitats.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Asia; India; scientific; diversity; myrmecophagy; lizards; rock agamas; Psammophilus dorsalis; diet; energy expenditure; habitats; landscapes; rural areas; stomach contents; trophic levels; urban areas; urbanization; vegetation;

author: Balakrishnan, M.M. and Vinodkumar, P.K. and Prakasan, C.B.
title: A note of green scale-ant association on coffee
abstract: *[The Green Cafe cochineal (Coccus viridis) is a major sucking insect coffee.  In nature, populations of this pest are usually regulated by biotic & abiotic factors.  The green mealybug excretes honeydew, which attracts ants, establishing a mutualistic association with insects helping to develop and settle quickly.  In order to understand the role of ants in the establishment of the scale insect, for 3 years (1987-1989) we investigated the association of ants (Crematogaster spp., Oecophylla smaragdina (Fabricius), Paratrechina longicornis Latreille, Prenolepis indica Forel, Tapinoma melanocephalum (Fabricius), & Technomyrmex sp. with cochineal green coffee in the Coffee Research Station.  The observations revealed that among the various ants studied Oecophylla smaragdina & Crematogaster spp. provided sufficient protection for green mealybug natural enemies & climatic conditions (other species did not influence natural mortality factors), therefore the exclusion of those ants produce cochineal greatly reduced because natural enemies are active in the area.  However, considering that the ants are beneficial to other crops, it is advised promote them in habitats where they are useful.]

author: Balakrishnan, S. and Srinivasan, M. and Mohanraj, J.
title: Diversity of some insect fauna in different coastal habitats of Tamil Nadu, southeast coast of India
note: Part of FORMIS 18; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: We investigated the biodiversity of some insect fauna in different coastal habitat of Tamil Nadu, Southeast coast of India and also tried to clarify the relationship between surrounding coastal environmental ecosystem of three coastal habitats (station-I estuarine complex, station-II mangrove area and station-III sandy beach), in order to, eventually, contribute to biodiversity conservation as well as to management of coastal habitat in India. Insect were collected from the three sites, from January 2008 to December 2008. Studies regarding diversity of insects available on coastal environments are very few. A total of 929 insects belong to 23 families and 6 orders were recorded from the 3 sites. Among them, 487 species are from station-II 259 species from station-I and 183 species are from station-III were recorded. Statistical tools PRIMER (Ver. 6.1.11) were employed to find the species diversity, richness and evenness were calculated.          *[Solenopsis sp. collected at station-I & station-II.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Solenopsis; Myrmicinae; Asia; India; scientific; diversity; richness; evenness; habitat; biodiversity conservation; coasts; ecosystems; estuaries; aerial nets; sweep nets; beating shrubs;

author: Banik, S. and Biswas, S. and Karmakar, R. and Brahmachary, R.
title: Necrophoresis in two Indian ant species, Camponotus compressus (Fabricius) and Diacamma vagans (Smith) (Insecta: Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
abstract: *[Necrophoresis (removal of nest-mate corpses) was studied in 2 Indian ant species, Camponotus compressus & Diacamma vagans, collected from suburbs of Calcutta (now Kolkata), India.  Small groups of worker ants were maintained in artificial nests in order to study 'hard-wired' behavior patterns in the absence of any stimulus from gynecoids, eggs, larvae etc.  C. camponotus regularly showed a site specific disposal area (=cemetery) for nest-mate corpses but they chose a preliminary & a second, a more permanent site which was shifted later while the primary site remained unaltered.  In contrast, these ants formed no midden (a pile of refuse), but removed remnants of food only to slight distances in a random fashion & those refuse materials were never carried to the cemetery site.  To our knowledge, the double cemetery site is a new record.  D. vagans, on the other hand, established neither a cemetery nor a midden.  They removed nest-mate corpses again & again to different directions & distances.  As many as 12 removals of a single corpse were recorded in 48 hrs time period.  Food remnants were removed to slight distances in different directions.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Camponotus compressus; Diacamma vagans; Formicinae; Ponerinae; Asia; India; scientific; behavior; necrophoresis; nest-mate corpses; cemetary; midden; refuse piles;

author: Banik, S. and Biswas, S. and Karmakar, R. and Brahmachary, R.
title: A comparative account of behaviour pattern in two Indian ant species in captivity
abstract: *[Activity-rest time budget & aggression were studied in small isolated groups of Camponotus compressus & Diacamma vagans.  Those ants were not subjected to the influence of important stimuli like the presence of eggs, larvae, reproductive forms etc. & so the more innate or 'hard-wired' activity patterns were evident.  Under such circumstances, C. compressus was generally inactive, remaining for days together inside the nest.  But on introduction of another small group from the same natural colony, intense activities occurred for a few days.  Because of natural polymorphism in C. compressus, even without marking, it could be established that the major worker (soldier) was at sentry duty for 11 h continuously, while other workers were less active.  After a few days the ants reverted to the inactive state.  D. vagans was more active & (marking with paint) the activity ethograms of 2 individual ants were determined.  Aggression of D. vagans was relatively mild & they never killed conspecifics, members of different colonies were accepted after some time.  In the case of C. compressus, killing of conspecifics was noted.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Camponotus compressus; Diacamma vagans; Formicinae; Ponerinae; Asia; India; scientific; worker; media worker; major worker; soldier; behavior; activity-rest time budget; aggression;

author: Baratte, S. and Cobb, M. and Deutsch, J. and Peeters, C.
title: Morphological variations in the pre-imaginal development of the ponerine ant Diacamma ceylonense
abstract: *[In the present paper, the larval development of the queenless ponerine ant Diacamma ceylonense is studied.  Four instars were identified on the basis of cuticular processes, tubercles & spinules, which show discontinuous variation during growth, providing precise & reliable external morphological criteria for instar discrimination.  In the first 3 instars, the larva possesses a striking proboscis, which disappears between the third & fourth instars.  Larval weight increased around 50-fold in the 21 days of larval life between eclosion & pupation (mean weight for first instar = 0.37 mg; for fourth instar = 20 mg).  In addition, the morphology of the gemmae, structures resembling vestigial wings in workers, is described in pupae.]

abstract: *[In D. ceylonense & D. australe, we studied the behavior of new callows confronted with dominant individuals of different fertility or age.  Faced with a young unmutilated worker (= the future gamergate with poorly developed ovaries), callows were aggressive, whereas they did not resist gamergates.]

author: Bargali, H.S. and Akhtar, N. and Chauhan, N.P.S.
title: Feeding ecology of sloth bears in a disturbed area in central India
abstract: *[In Central India, the North Bilaspur Forest Division harbors a large number of sloth bears, Melursus ursinus.  The managed forests of the division are mostly patchy, fragmented, degraded, & interspersed with crop fields & villages with high human & cattle population.  The feeding ecology of sloth bears was studied by analyzing 568 scats; 21 species of plants, termites, ants, & bees, as well as unidentified animal matter were found in bear scats.  Year-round frequencies of occurrence of animal & plant matter were similar.  Animal matter constituted 87% of scats during monsoon & 82% during winter seasons, but dropped to 65% during summer.  Frequency of occurrence of insects was high during monsoon (87%) & winter (82%), whereas Ficus species were more common (68%) during summer season.  Termites & ants were by far the most frequently encountered food item in monsoon & winter.  We also noted extensive digging for termites & ants in crop fields close to the den sites during monsoon season.]

author: Baroni Urbani, C.
title: Primi reperti del genere Calyptomyrmex Emery nel subcontinente Indiano
note: Part of FORMIS 94; from The Ants, verified-CBU; from ANTBIB; Date from Bolton, verified-PSW;
abstract: The ant genus Calyptomyrmex is recorded for the first time from the Indian subcontinent with the following 4 new species: C. wittmeri n. sp. (Southern Bhutan), C. tamil n. sp. /Ceylon), C. singalensis n. sp. (Ceylon), C. vedda n. sp. (Ceylon). Moreover, C. beccarii var. glabrata Viehmeyer 1916 is considered as a good species (n. status) and a key is given to the workers of the 6 presently known species of the Oriental region.

author: Baroni Urbani, C.
title: Materiali per una revisione della sottofamiglia Leptanillinae Emery (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
note: Part of FORMIS 94; from The Ants; verified-CBU; from ANTBIB; Date from Bolton, verified-PSW; from-DPW,
abstract: 33 species are recognized in the ant subfamily Leptanillinae. 17 of them are based on workers and 16 on unassociated males. The workers are grouped into the single genus Leptanilla Emery (= Leptomesites Kutter, syn. nov.) which includes the following species: L. revelierei Emery (= L. doderoi Emery, syn. nov.) from S. France, Corsica, Sardinia and N. Africa. The three intraspecific forms attributed to this species can be separated from the typical form and one from each other on consistent morphological grounds but they have been not formally synonymized because of the high number of male-based and morphologically divergent species coming from the same area and which should at least in aprt correspond to the worker-based forms.  L. theryi Forel from Algerie and Tunisia. L. kubotai n. sp. from Japan. L. morimotoi Yasumatsu from Japan. L. buddhista n. sp. from Nepal. L. besucheti n. sp. from Sri Lanka. L. oceanica n. sp. from Ogasawara Is. L. havilandi Forel from Singapore. L. tahi n. sp. from Thailand. L. butteli Forel from Malaysia. L. swani Wheeler from Australia. L. tanakai n. sp. from Japan. L. escheri (Kutter) from S. India. L. vaucheri Emery from Morocco. L. boltoni n. sp. from Ghana. L. nana Santschi from Tunisia.  The males are only partly reviewed because it has not been possible to examine all the known species. It is underlined, moreover, that some of these males could be extraneous to the Leptanillinae and even to the Formicidae, although their placement within the Leptanillinae seems to represent the most reasonable solution for the moment. 11 species in 4 genera result from literature and 5 additional species are recognized in the present paper. Only 3 of them, of particular zoogeographical interest, are described, that is: L. africana n. sp. from Nigeria, L. australis n. sp. from S. Africa and L. islamica n. sp. from Aden. Two others from Spain and Tunisia respectively, are briefly described but not named because of the intriguing status of the previously known Mediterranean species.  A particular emphasis is given to the discovery of L. oceanica on the Ogasawara Islands. To explain this record we are forced to admit the capacity of long distance dispersal for Leptanilla, an assumption which reproposes the problem af the previously supposed antiquity of these ants and of their consequently low evolutionary rate.

author: Baroni Urbani, C.
title: Contributo alla conoscenza del genere Amblyopone Erichson (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
note: Part of FORMIS 94; from NAL's AGRICOLA; verified-CBU; from ANTBIB; Date from Bolton, verified-PSW; verified-DPW.
abstract: Six species of Amblyopone (two of which new to science) are recognized in the Mediterranean region and a key based on the workers is given for their identification. The material considered on the present study originated from the following countries: A. denticulata (Roger) from Italy, Greece, Bulgaria, Turkey and Lebanon; A. impressifrons (Emery) from Italy; A. ophthalmica n. sp. from Israel; A. normandi (Santschi) from Tunisia and Israel (first record for this country); A. emeryi (Saunders) and A. gaetulica n. sp. both from Morocco.  Moreover, two new exotic species of particular interest are described: A. pertinax n. sp., taken at 2200 m altitude in the Darjeeling district (India), which represents the northern record for the genus in central Asia and the highest altitudinal record for the genus as a whole.  This species shows no morphological relationships with other Indian species, but is comparable with A. minuta (Forel) from Sumatra.  A. besucheti n. sp. is described from the island La Digue in the Seychelles.  This is the smallest known species in the genus and it shows no considerable affinities with other species.  It is regarded as a palaeoendemic, also in view of the fact that no Amblyopone species are known to occur in central and South Africa and Madagascar, a situation contrasting with the high species concentration in the Indoaustralian area.

author: Baroni Urbani, C.
title: The ant genus Gnamptogenys in Dominican Amber. (Amber Collection Stuttgart: Hymenoptera, Formicidae. IV: Ectatommini)
journal: Stuttg. Beitr. Naturkd. Ser. B (Geol. Palaontol.)
note: Part of FORMIS 94; from Biblio Fourmis Database; verified-CBU; from ANTBIB; verified-PSW; from-DPW,
abstract: Two new Gnamptogenys species in Dominican amber (Early Miocene) are described from a single specimen each. One of them (G. pristina) shows clear relationships with those Recent Central American species which occur also on the Greater Antilles. The second one - (G. levinates)- also matches some Recent relatives in several characters, but it strikingly differs by all of them by the lack of gastral costulation. It is argued that this character might not have an important evolutionary value. These first Neotropical fossils of Gnamptogenys throw a new light on the palaeogeography of the genus and especially on the past distribution of Recent Caribbean Gnamptogenys species.

author: Baroni Urbani, C.
title: The number of castes in ants, where major is smaller than minor and queens wear the shield of the soldiers
note: Part of FORMIS 00; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: The traditional hypothesis that ant soldiers originate from large size workers is rejected in favour of their direct origin from gynes. This conclusion is supported by the first report of soldiers smaller than workers, by an intercaste morphometric comparative analysis by means of D'Arcy Thompson's transformation grids and by phylogenetic studies on Cephalotes showing that the cephalic shield appeared ancestrally among soldiers and only later among gynes. The same conclusion flows from facts already known but hitherto misunderstood and stressed in this paper such as: 1) there are species of Cephalotes with soldiers with incomplete cephalic shield and no gyne shield and other species with complete soldier shield but only incomplete gyne shield; 2) the phragmotic behaviour is exercised by workers and soldiers and not by gynes but its morphological correlate, i.e., the shield-shaped head, occurs among soldiers and gynes and not in workers. These observations prove that the selection pressure for the shield morphology acts on workers and soldiers and not on gynes but its morphological correlate actually appears first in soldiers, later in gynes and never in workers. These data sharply contrast with a worker origin of soldiers and are perfectly consistent with the hypothesis of a separate origin of soldiers directly from gynes.

author: Baroni Urbani, C. and Bolton, B. and Ward, P.S.
title: The internal phylogeny of ants (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
note: Part of FORMIS 94; from NAL'S AGRICOLA; verified-CBU; Part of the Leaf-Cutting Ant Bibliography; From ANTBIB; verified-PSW;
abstract: The higher phylogeny of the Formicidae was analyzed using 68 characters and 19 taxa: the 14 currently recognized ant subfamilies plus 5 potentially critical infrasubfamilial taxa.  The results justified the recognition of 3 additional subfamilies: Aenictogitoninae Ashmead (new status), Apomyrminae Dlussky & Fedoseeva (new status), and Leptanilloidinae Bolton (new subfamily).  A second analysis of these better delimited 17 subfamilies resulted in 24 equally most parsimonious trees.  All trees showed a basal division of extant Formicidae into two groups, the first containing (Myrmicinae, Pseudomyrmecinae, Nothomyrmeciinae, Myrmeciinae, Formicinae, Dolichoderinae, Aneuretinae) and the second the remaining subfamilies.  Clades appearing within these groups included the Cerapachyinae plus 'army ants', the Nothomyrmeciinae plus Myrmeciinae, the 'formicoid' subfamilies (Aneuretinae + Dolichoderinae + Formicinae), and the Old World army ants (Aenictinae + Aenictogitoninae + Dorylinae), but relationships within the last two groups were not resolved, and the relative positions of the Apomyrminae, Leptanillinae and Ponerinae remained ambiguous.  Moreover, a bootstrap  analysis produced a consensus tree in which all branches were represented in proportions much lower than 95%.  A reconstruction of the ground plan of the Formicidae indicated that the most specialized of all recent ants are the members of the subfamily Dorylinae and the least specialized ones are the monotypic Apomyrminae.

author: Baroni Urbani, C. and Boyan, G.S. and Blarer, A. and Billen, J. and Musthak Ali, T.M.
title: A novel mechanism for jumping in the Indian ant Harpegnathos saltator (Jerdon) (Formicidae, Ponerinae)
note: Part of FORMIS 95; from NAL'S AGRICOLA; verified-DPW.
abstract: *[The Indian ant Harpegnathos saltator may be unique among insects in using its jumping capacity not only as an escape mechanism, but also as a normal means of locomotion, & for catching its prey in flight.  High-speed cinematography used to analyse the various phases of the jump suggests that Harpegnathos employs a novel jumping mechanism to mediate these behaviors: namely the synchronous activation of its middle & hindlegs.  Electrophysiological recordings from muscles or nerves in pairs of middle & hindlegs show remarkably synchronous activity during fictive jumping, supporting the synchronous activation hypothesis.  Harpegnathos is not the only ant to jump, & a cladistic analysis suggests that jumping behaviour evolved independently 3 times during ant evolutionary history.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Harpegnathos saltator; Ponerinae; Asia; India; scientific; behavior; jumping ability; locomotion; electrophysiology; escape mechanism; prey capture; evolution;

author: Baroni Urbani, C. and Kutter, N.
title: PremiËre analyse biomÈtrique du polymorphisme de la caste ouvriËre chez les fourmis du genre Pheidologeton (Hymenoptera: Aculeata)
note: Part of FORMIS 94; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from Biblio Fourmis Database; verified-CBU; from ANTBIB; verified-PSW; from-DPW,
abstract: Measurements of head width of 2,068 workers from a single colony of Pheidologeton diversus (Jerdon) collected in south India, allowed a clear grouping of the population into three major subcastes. The size limit of head width for each subcaste and its relative frequency are as follows: minor workers (0.56 - 1.00 mm; 90.48%); medium workers (1.00 - 3.12 mm; 7.54%); major workers (3.12 - 5.20 mm; 1.98%). The boundary between the contiguous subcastes is well marked by strong reductions of frequency or total absence of intermediate individuals belonging to the critical size groups. Polynomial regressions have been used to analyze the allometry between different body parts between a representative subset of 88 workers fitting the whole variability range of the population. The following measurements have been taken: head length, head width, scapus length and length of the posterior tibia. The results show triphasic allometry between scapus and tibia length; tetraphasic allometry between head length and head width, between scapus and head length, and between scapus length and head width; pentaphasic allometry between tibia length and head width and between tibia and head length.  These results represent the first records of pentaphasic allometry in ants and some of the few records of allometry of a degree higher than triphasic among animals, although this is probably partly due to the use of less ensitive analytical methods in most of the previous literature. Our results entirely confirm a former suggestion by van Boven (1970) that the length of the tibia, when compared with some cephalic measurements, shows the hignest degree of allometry in ants.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Pheidologeton diversus; Myrmicinae; Asia; India; scientific; minor workers; medium workers; major workers; caste polymorphism; colony; morphology; biometrics; linear; scapus length; scapus length;

author: Barsagade, D. and Masram, P.
title: Post embryonic changes in different caste of weaver ant, Oecophylla smaragdina (Fabricius) in central India
abstract: *[The Asian weaver ant, Oecophylla smaragdina a dominant species, is found in tropical region of central India.  The post embryonic metamorphic characters confirm 4 moultings, with 5 larval instars & the pupal stages developing into 4 types of polymorphic adults.  The larval instars are typical oecophylloid type & are characterized by an apodous, curved body with apically placed mouth & postero-apical anus.  The pupal stages are divided into pre, early, mid, & late, & show few morphological changes in the structure.  The adults are clearly divided into fertile & non-fertile castes, where the non-fertile caste consists of minor & major worker & the fertile castes consists of drone (male) & queen (female).  During brooding season, there are always a couple of alate adult queens socializing with each other before mating.  The complete development of weaver ant from egg to adult occurs within a period of 32 days in the tropical zone of central India.]

author: Barsagade, D.D. and Gharade, S.
title: Ultrastructural study on male external genitalia of the weaver ant Oecophylla smaragdina (Fabricius), (Hymenoptera: Formicedae <sic>)
abstract: *[The male genitalia of Oecophylla smaragdina appear to be phallic structures.  The phallus is usually a large, highly complex arising from the wall of the genital chamber above the ninth sternum.  The male external genitalia consist 3 parts, basimere, telomere, & adeagus.  Scanning electron microscopic studies reveal 5 types of sensilla: sensilla trichoidea ST-I, ST-II, & ST-III, sensilla trichoidea curvata, & sensilla basiconica are present on the genitalia.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Oecophylla smaragdina; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; male; external genitalia; phallus; sensilla; sensilla trichoidea; sensilla trichoidea curvata; sensilla basiconica;

author: Barsagade, D.D. and Masram, P.P. and Nagarkar, D.
title: Surface ultra-structural studies on antennae in polymorphs of weaver ant Oecophylla smaragdina; Fabricius (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) with reference to sensilla
abstract: *[Oecophylla smaragdina is an established biological pest control agent in south-east Asian continent for cash crops like cashew and mango.  The morphological & ultra-structural investigation of such worker antenna was done with scanning electron microscopy to reveal presence of various chemosensory, thermo-sensory, & tactile sensory sensillae on the antennal segments with their specific role in the polymorphs.  The role of workers in foraging activity is supported with the presence of large number of sensilla compared to other castes.]

author: Barsagade, D.D. and Nagarkar, D.A. and Kirsan, J.R.
title: Surface ultrastructure of antenna and distribution of sensilla in the Leptogenys chinensis (Mayr) (Fabricus) (Formicidae: Hymenoptera)
abstract: *[The surface micro-morphology of the antennal sensilla of Leptogenys chinensis workers show the presence of various types of sensilla (sensilla trichodea, sensilla trichodea curvata, sensilla basiconica, sensilla coeloconica, sensilla chaetica, sensilla coelocapitular).  Sensilla trichodea are distributed on all parts of the antenna.  Sensilla trichodea curvata type III are typically present on flagellar segments only.  Sensilla basiconica with arrowhead, that are present on scape ball, are slightly different than the sensilla basiconica with rounded head that are present on the flagellar tip.  Sensilla coelocapitular are observed only on the flagellar tip.  On the joint of scape ball & pedicilar shaft, 3 types of sensilla trichodea are present on the ball ridge, while sensilla basiconica are distributed on the dorso-lateral margin of the ball.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Leptogenys chinensis; Ponerinae; Asia; India; scientific; morphology; antenna; flagellum; flagellar segments; scape; scape ball; sensilla; sensilla trichodea; sensilla trichodea curvata; sensilla basiconica; sensilla coeloconica; sensilla chaetica; sensilla coelocapitular; surface ultrastructure; SEM;

author: Barsagade, D.D. and Nagarkar, D.A. and Masram, P.P. and Thakre, M.P.
title: Genetic relationship among Leptogenys chinensis and Myrmicaria brunnea (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) by RAPD molecular markers
abstract: *[Myrmicaria brunnea, & Leptogenys chinensis were used in this study as representatives of Myrmicinae & Ponerinae, respectively.  DNA markers were used for assessment of genetic integrity & variation between M. brunnea & L. chinensis.  Three RAPD markers, as P1, P2 and P3 generated 151 bands.  M. brunnae & L. chinensis generated 66 & 85 bands, respectively.  Maximum polymorphic bands were generated by P2 primer (37) & maximum monomorphic (17) bands were generated by primer P1.  Study of monomorphic and polymorphic bands was carried out & statistical data generated were used to construct phylogenetic tree & fluorograms.  M. brunnea & L. chinensis were found linked together at about 0.4 genetic distance.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Leptogenys chinensis; Myrmicaria brunnea; Myrmicinae; Ponerinae; Asia; India; scientific; genetics; genetic variability; DNA marker; RAPD; PCR;

author: Barsagade, D.D. and Nagose, S.B. and Kirsan, J.R. and Thakare, M.P.
title: SEM studies on the worker legs of arboreal bicoloured ant, Tetraponera rufonigra with reference to the sensilla present on it (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
abstract: *[Arboreal bicolored ants, Tetraponera rufonigra, were collected from a colony on a Ficus benghalensis tree in RTM Nagpur University Campus, Nagpur from January to February 2017.  The SEM study revealed that the entire surface of coxae consists of 2 types of sensilla, sensilla trichoidea & fine setae-like hairs, trichomes, while, trochanters contain sensilla trichoidea.  The femurs had sensilla trichoidea arising from the hexagonal cuticular plate.  The mid & hind tibia had a reduced spine-like tibial spur with fine cuticular bristles differentiated into CCB-I & CCB-II.  The metatarsus of foreleg showed three types of sensilla, sensilla trichoidea, trichomes, & comb like bristles, however; the metatarsus of mid & hind legs contains macrosetae, sensilla trichoidea, & trichomes.  All tarsomeres bear numerous bristles, setae, & trichomes on the entire surface while, surface of foreleg pretarsus had macrosetae and sensilla trichoidea curvata.  The pretarsi contain sensilla & the mid dorsal surface of claws shows sensilla trichoidea, sensilla trichoidea curvata, & trichomes.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Tetraponera rufonigra; Pseudomyrmecinae; Asia; India; scientific; workers; morphology; legs; foreleg; midleg; hindleg; coxa; coxae; sensilla; sensilla trichoidea; trichomes; trochanter; femur; hexagonal cuticular plate; mid tibia; hind tibia; tibial spur; cuticular bristles; metatarsus; foreleg; comb like bristles; macrosetae; tarsomeres; bristles; setae; sensilla trichoidea curvata; pretarsi;

author: Barsagade, D.D. and Tembhare, D.B. and Kadu, S.G.
title: SEM structure of mandibular sensilla in the carpenter ant Camponotus compressus (Fabricius) (Formicidae: Hymenoptera)
abstract: *[The moutparts in all forms of polymorphic carpenter ant, Camponotus compressus (Fabricius) are adapted for grasping & feeding on prey.  The mandibles are unsegmented, strongly sclerotized, large, shovel like, powerful cuticular structures.  The mandibles consist of dorsal sensilla trichoidea DT-I, DT -II, & DT-III & on the ventral side VT-I, VT-II, & the Sensilla basiconica VB in female & workers, while similar type of sensilla are found in male except sensilla basiconica.  Each mandible consists of 4 incisor & 3 molar teeth in female & workers, while only 2 incisor teeth are present in male.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Camponotus compressus; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; worker; female; male; morphology; mandibular sensilla; sensilla trichoidea; sensilla basiconica; SEM studies;

author: Barsagade, D.D. and Tembhare, D.B. and Kadu, S.G.
title: Microscopic structure of antennal sensilla in the carpenter ant Camponotus compressus (Fabricius) (Formicidae: Hymenoptera)
abstract: *[The antennae in all castes of the carpenter ant Camponotus compressus were examined using scanning electron microscopy.  The antennae are of geniculate type, consisting of a scape & funiculus.  The funiculus is subdivided into the pedicel & flagellum.  The flagellum consists of a number of segments, 10 in females & workers & 11 in males.  In all castes the scape is differentiated into a basal ball covered with 3 types of sensilla and a shaft with sensilla trichodea.  The pedicel bears sensilla trichodea densely in all castes, & sensilla basiconica in the female only.  The flagellum contains sensilla trichodea curvata, sensilla trichodea, sensilla basiconica, & sensilla chaetica in females, sensilla basiconica in workers, & sensilla chaetica in males.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Camponotus compressus; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; workers; females; males; morphology; antenna; sensilla; funiculus; scape; sensilla; sensilla trichodea; sensilla basiconica; sensilla trichodea curvata; sensilla chaetica;

author: Barsagade, D.D. and Thakare, R.P. and Anande, S.M. and Chankapure, P.N.
title: SEM structure of legs of ant, Componotus <sic> sericeus with special reference to antenna cleaner (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
institution: p. 168-174, Proc. National Level Seminar on Recent Trend in Bioinformatics and Biostatistics, Department of Zoology, Shri Dnyanesh Mahavidyalaya, Nawargaon, India, 27 March 2015
abstract: *[Three pairs of legs are well developed in ant, Camponotus sericeus.  Each leg is divided into 6 segments, the coxa, trochanter, femur, tibia, tarsus, & pre-tarsus with well developed paired claws.  The morphology of each leg & distribution of sensilla is studied with a scanning electron microscope (SEM).  SEM analysis of leg reveals that an antenna cleaner is present on the tibio-tarsal portion of the leg.  Tibio-tarsal antennal cleaner appeared in the form of a pore region on the surface of the basitarsus.  These pores are originating from a cluster of highly prismatic epidermal cells.]          *[Camponotus sericeus misspelled Componotus sericeus, in title & abstract.  Correctly spelled in body of paper.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Camponotus sericeus; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; morphology; legs; antenna cleaner; epidermal glands; legs; basitarsus; sensilla; SEM;

author: Barsagade, D.D. and Thakre, M.P. and Kirsan, J.R. and Nagose, S.B. and Nagarkar, D.A. and Bodele, A.M.
title: Mouthparts sensilla of the worker ant Leptogenys dentilobis (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
abstract: *[The mouthparts of the worker caste in the ant, Leptogenys dentilobis are directed forward & adapted for biting & cutting.  The mouth parts consist of a broad lobulated labrum, mandible with sclerotized incisors & molar cups, palps laterally placed on the maxillae, & the labium, which forms the lower lip.  Scanning electron microscopic (SEM) studies of the mouthparts revealed the presence of 2 major types of sensilla. i.e. sensilla trichoidea & sensilla trichoidea curvata.  These sensillae though present on all the mouth parts, exhibit variation in their morphology, density, & number & are site specific.]          *[caste misspelled cast.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Leptogenys dentilobis; Ponerinae; Asia; India; scientific; workers; morphology; mouthparts; labrum; mandibles; sclerotized incisors; molar cups; palps; maxillae; maxillary palpi; labium; labial palpi; sensilla; sensilla trichoidea; sensilla trichoidea curvata; SEM;

author: Barwal, R.N. and Thakur, N.S.A. and Rao, N.S.
title: Seasonal activity and control of rice root aphid, Rhopalosiphum rufiabdominalis (Sos) (Aphididae: Hemiptera) in upland paddy
abstract: *[A study on the seasonal activity of the rice root aphid (R. rufiabdominalis), its parasites & dispersing agents, as well as on the efficacy of insecticides against them, was undertaken in rice cv. Ngoba, sown in Barapani, Meghalaya, India. The activities of aphid dispersing agents, i.e. ants (Tetramorium bicarinatum, Pachycondyla sp., & Camponotus sp.) & termite (Pericapritermes sp.), were highest in 1 May to 1 June sowings & decreased in the latter sowings.]          *[Camponotus misspelled Components.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Camponotus; Pachycondyla; Tetramorium bicarinatum; Formicinae; Myrmicinae; Ponerinae; Asia; India; scientific; distribution; tending Hemiptera; Hemiptera; Aphididae; rice root aphid; Rhopalosiphum rufiabdominalis; impact; agricultural; rice; invasive species;

author: Basalingappa, S. and Kareddy, V.B. and Gandhi, M.R. and Shivakumar, M.
title: Foraging paths of the ant, Camponotus sericeus Fabricius
note: Part of FORMIS; from UCD Ant Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[From each nest of the ant Camponotus sericeus, as many as sixteen foraging paths were observed radiated in all directions.  Total distance of the foraging paths from nest to food source ranged from 1 to 78.45 meters.  Distance from the food source to the nest ranged from 1 to 74.15 meters.  Time taken to cover the distance from the nest to the food source and back was 4 to 112 min and 1 to 78 min respectively.  More time taken by the foragers to cover the distance from the nest to the food source was due to spending time in search of food source.  Longest paths were observed in February to May summer months, and the shortest during June to September rainy months.  The length of the foraging paths were directly proportional to the availability of food nearby the nest area.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Camponotus sericeus; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; behavior; food source; foraging; foraging distances; activity patterns; seasons;

author: Basalingappa, S. and Kareddy, V.B. and Matapathi, S. and Gandhi, M.R.

author: Basalingappa, S. and Kareddy, V.B. and Mathapathi, S.B. and Gandhi, M.
title: Colony-founding and life-cycle in the ant Camponotus sericeus Fabricius (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
note: Part of FORMIS; Compiled and verified by V.Kipyatkov; from-DPW,
abstract: *[After the nuptial flight, in September & October only dealate females were observed, searching for suitable nesting sites & excavating their nests.  Each dealate female made a vertical burrow & the broodchamber was formed at the blind end of the nest.  In 80% of the cases a single female was involved in colony founding under laboratory conditions, & in 20% of the cases multiple females were involved.  Duration of the life-cycle under natural conditions in the field & under laboratory conditions, with near natural conditions was more or less similar: 24 to 26 & 21 to 30 days, respectively.]

author: Basibuyuk, H. H. and Quicke, D. L. J. and Rasnitsyn, A. P. and Fitton, M. G.
title: Morphology and sensilla of the orbicula, a sclerite between the tarsal claws, in the Hymenoptera
note: Part of FORMIS 21; from NAL'S AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: *[The orbicula (manubrium) is a dorsal sclerite between the tarsal claws in the Hymenoptera.  Its detailed external morphology was surveyed throughout the order using scanning electron microscopy.  Four types of presumed mechanosensory sensilla were found: 2 sensilla trichodea & 2 sensilla campaniformia.  Variation in number, shape, orientation, & associated structures are discussed in the light of current phylogenetic hypotheses.  There are generally 2 sensilla trichodea A on each orbicula, & this is a putative synapomorphy for all of Hymenoptera excluding the Xyelinae. ]

author: Basu, D.N. and Churi, P. and Soman, A. and Sengupta, A. and Bhakare, M. and Lokhande, S. and Bhoite, S. and Huertas, B. and Kunte, K.
title: The genus Tarucus Moore, [1881] (Lepidoptera: Lycaenidae) in the Indian Subcontinent
abstract: *[In this study, we provide a taxonomic & nomenclatural review of these species based on morphology (male genitalia) & type specimens, & designate lectotypes in the Natural History Museum, London, & the Zoological Survey of India, Kolkata, for the following names: Tarucus callinara nigra Bethune-Baker, [1918], Tarucus callinara Butler, 1886, Tarucus venosus hazara Evans, 1932, Tarucus venosus Moore, 1882, Tarucus alteratus Moore, 1882, Tarucus extricatus Butler, 1886, Tarucus theophrastus indica Evans, 1932, Castalius ananda de NicÈville, [1884], & Tarucus dharta Bethune-Baker, [1918].  In addition, we identified the holotype of Tarucus bengalensis Bethune-Baker, [1918].  We also describe previously unrecognized variation within Tarucus balkanica nigra that has caused confusion in the past.  We discuss aspects of their natural history & spatio-temporal distribution.  We describe & illustrate early stages, larval host plants, mutualistic ants, parasitoids, & other aspects of the reproductive biology of Indian Tarucus.  We provide an identification key for all the Indian species based on wing color patterns & the male genitalia.]

author: Basu, D.N. and Kunte, K.
title: Tools of the trade: MicroCT reveals native structure and functional morphology of organs that drive caterpillar-ant interactions
abstract: *[Although the ecological, evolutionary, and behavioural aspects of tactile, acoustic, & chemical communication  are well studied, the mechanisms (i.e., the functional morphology) that drive the specialized interactive organs are poorly characterized.  We used advanced X-ray microtomography (MicroCT) to delineate internal, native morphology of specialized larval dew patches, nectar glands, & tactile ciliary organs that mediate interactions between Crematogaster hodgsoni & caterpillars of the obligate myrmecophilous Apharitis lilacinus butterfly.  Our non-destructive MicroCT analysis provided novel 3-D insights into the native structure & positions of these specialized organs in unmatched detail.  This analysis also suggested a functional relationship between organ structures & surrounding muscles & nervation that operate the glands & tactile organs, including a 'lasso bag' control mechanism for dew patches & muscle control for other organs.]

author: Basu, P.
title: Seasonal and spatial patterns in ground foraging ants in a rain forest in the Western Ghats, India
note: Part of FORMIS 99; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW; from PSW.
abstract: *[Seasonal variation & spatial distribution in ground foraging rain forest ants were studied in South Kannada-Kodagu District in Karnataka, India, between 1990 & 1991 by pit-fall trap sampling.  All ant species showed marked seasonality.  A total of 31 species were recorded from the primary forest over a period of 2 years.  More species were recorded from the closed canopy forest than from tree fall gaps in primary forest.  All ant species showed marked seasonality with fewer species & individuals sampled/plot during the wetter seasons.  The numerically dominant species, Pheidole sp., was markedly lower in abundance during the wet seasons.  Spatial patterns were also studied during a dry season both in the primary forest & an adjacent logged forest.  More species were recorded from the logged forest than the primary forest.  Community composition in primary forest was different from that in logged forest.  Common species were more ubiquitous than rarer species.  Species were distributed bimodally across sampling plots.  Probable underlying processes behind these seasonal & spatial patterns have been discussed.]

author: Baudry, E. and Peeters, C. and Brazier, L. and Veuille, M. and Doums, C.
title: Shift in the behaviours regulating monogyny is associated with high genetic differentiation in the queenless ant Diacamma ceylonense
abstract: *[In the queenless ant genus Diacamma, one mated worker (= gamergate) maintains reproductive monopoly in a colony by mutilating newly emerged workers.  However, in several populations from south India, referred to as 'nilgiri', gamergates do not mutilate their nestmates, but monopolize reproduction using dominance interactions.  Various lines of evidence indicate that 'nilgiri' populations are closely related to the neighboring species D. ceylonense.  To determine whether this important behavioural difference between 'nilgiri' & D. ceylonense is associated with significant genetic differentiation, we have used microsatellite & mitochondrial markers to examine genetic variation within & between 'nilgiri' & D. ceylonense.  We found a very high genetic differentiation between the 2 forms, which suggests a lack of gene flow.  There was an unexpected pattern of mitochondrial variation, because all 'nilgiri' populations show identical or very closely related COII sequences, except one population with a very different haplotype.  This divergent haplotype is genetically much more distant from the other 'nilgiri' haplotypes than are D. ceylonense haplotypes.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Diacamma ceylonense; Diacamma; Ponerinae; Asia; India; scientific; behavior; monogyny; genetic differentiation; queenless ant; regulation of reproduction; microsatellites; mtDNA introgression; gamergates;

author: Baumann, J.
title: Tiny mites on a great journey - a review on scutacarid mites as phoronts and inquilines (Heterostigmatina, Pygmephoroidea, Scutacaridae)
note: Part of FORMIS 21; Part of the Leaf-Cutting Ant Bibliography; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: *[I review the behavioral & morphological adaptations of scutacarid mites to living in different kinds of associations with other animal taxa.  Of the more than 800 scutacarid species that have been described so far, about the half of them can be found together with various animal taxa.  Scutacarid species can be phoretic using their hosts for dispersal, they can be inquilines of their hosts benefiting from favourable conditions in the hosts' nests, or they can be both.  The highest number of scutacarid species, (n = 214) is associated with ants.  The most frequent genera Archidispus, Imparipes, & Scutacarus show host preferences: Scutacarus & Imparipes tend to prefer ants, while Archidispus prefers beetles.  Usually, scutacarid species are rather specialized on one host genus or one host family, but some seem to be host generalists.  The possible influence of scutacarids on their hosts is not known yet, but they could play a sanitary role in their host nests.]          *[Acromyrmex lundii misspelled Acromyrmex lundi.]
