author: BednaYÌk, M. and Bocak, L.
title: New species of Paussus, subgenus Scaphipaussus (Coleoptera: Carabidae: Paussinae), from Southeast Asia reveal ambiguities in species group limits and high species diversity in the Oriental Region
note: Part of FORMIS 24; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Paussus, commonly known as ant nest beetles, is the most diverse genus of Paussinae (Coleoptera: Carabidae) with a very complex taxonomic history. Biodiversity research in Southeast and South Asia yields new species that can contribute to a better understanding of the morphological disparity and species-group or subgenus delimitation. Here, we describe nine new species from Southeast Asia and China: Paussus (Scaphipaussus) fencli sp. nov. (China), P. (S.) mawdsleyi sp. nov. (Borneo), P. (S.) bakeri sp. nov. (Philippines), P. (S.) jendeki sp. nov. (Laos), P. (S.) saueri sp. nov. (India), P. (S.) annamensis sp. nov. (Vietnam), P. (S.) phoupanensis sp. nov. (Laos, Vietnam), P. (S.) bilyi sp. nov. (Thailand), and P. (S.) haucki sp. nov. (Thailand). We also bring new data on P. (S.) corporaali Reichensperger, 1927 (Java) and P. (S.) madurensis Wasmann, 1913 (India). Besides formal descriptions, we provide photographs of the habitus in the dorsal and dorsolateral view, antennal club, head crest, and male genitalia if the male is available. Based on the comparison of new and earlier described species, we show that the antennae are highly diverse within the Scaphipaussus. Considering other characters, some species are placed in Scaphipaussus, but they differ from putative relatives in the antennal morphology. The presence of the frontal protuberances and crests is a more reliable character. Additional species show that Scaphipaussus is most diverse in southeastern Asia, especially in Indo-Burma. Concerning its supposed late Miocene origin, the group underwent rapid radiation. The species diversity of Scaphipaussus almost doubled in the last decade, and it is highly probable that further species will be described in the future.          *[Some previously recorded species of Scaphipaussus were collected from ant nests, mainly of the genus Pheidole Westwood, 1839, e.g., Pheidole ghatica Forel, 1902; P. javana Mayr, 1867,  P. latinota Roger, 1863; P.pallidula (Nylander, 1849); P. plagiaria Smith, 1860; & P. wroughtoni, Forel, 1902.

author: Beevi, P.S. and Mahapatro, G.K.
title: Species-spectrum and inter-relationship between ant and spider fauna in cashew agro-ecosystem
note: Part of FORMIS 21; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[In the species spectrum study, a total, 10 ant species & 35 spider species were identified.  Four spider-guild classes were observed - stalkers, orb weavers, foliage-runners, & ground-runners.  Web-making pattern of spiders were discussed, their predatory potential in laboratory were studied.  Prevalent ant-species in cashew, various types of ant-nests, & the associated insect-pest species were discussed.  Trophobiosis between ants verses aphids, mealy bugs, scales, & cow bugs were documented.  Positive correlations were observed between ant-populations, & spider-populations in different crop-phenophases, crop-flushing, flowering, & fruiting. This suggests that ants are compatible with spiders & not antagonistic, as both are generalist predators.]           *[Myrmicinae misspelled Myrmecinae.]

author: Begum, A. and Susheela, N. and Swarupa, B. and Sreenivasa, V. and Sai Sandeep, Y. and Umapati, Y.
title: Assessment of ants (Hymenoptera - Formicidae) species diversity and composition in VSK University Campus Ballari, Karnataka
note: Part of FORMIS 21; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[Rresearch on diversity & species composition of ants was carried out in Vijayanagara Sri Krishnadevaraya University campus, Ballari, Karnataka, India from October 2017 to March 2018.  Twenty-one species of ants, collected from different locations on university property belonged to 21 genera & 5 subfamilies.  Maximum species belonged to Myrmicinae (8 species) & Formicinae (8 species) followed by Dolichoderinae (3 species), Ponerinae (one) & Pseudomyrmecinae (one).  This study was carried out to determine the availability of ants in campus.  The number of species in these subfamilies indicates suitability of habitat along with their foraging pattern.  Minimum species representation from Ponerinae & Pseudomyrmecinae indicate the fragmented habitat or altered topographical features are affecting species distribution.]          *[Camponotus pennsylvanicus misspelled Camponotos pennsylvanicus; Leptogenys misspelled Leptogenus; Myrmicaria natalensis misspelled Myrmacaria natalensis; Myrmicinae inconsistently misspelled Myrimicinae; Oecophylla smargardina misspelled Oesophylla smargardina; Pseudomyrmecinae misspelled Psuedomyrmicinae; Solenopsis invicta misspelled Solenopsis Invicta; Tetramorium caespitum misspelled Tetramorium caespium.]          *[Dolichoderinae, Formicinae, Myrmicinae, Ponerinae, & Pseudomyrmecinae incorrectly called families; They are subfamilies of the family Formicidae.]          NOTE: These identifications need to be confirmed.  Camponotus castaneus, Camponotus vicinus & Tapinoma sessile are North American species & not reported from Asia.  Camponotus pennsylvanicus is a North American species with unconfirmed records from India & other locations from Asia.  Camponotus vagus is a Holarctic species with one dubious record from India.  Crematogaster melanogaster & Myrmicaria natalensis are Afrotropical species, not previously reported from India.  Iridomyrmex rufoniger is an Australasian species not previously reported from India.  Lasius niger is a Holarctic species not previously reported from India.  Pheidole navigans is a Neotropical species not previously reported from India.  India would be a significant range extension for the invasive species Solenopsis invicta.  Tapinoma megacephala & Tetraponera rufonigera are not valid species name according to Bolton, B. (2019) An online catalog of the ants of the world. Available from http://antcat.org.  (accessed 18Jun2019).

author: Begum, K.H. and Nath, R.K. and Ahmed, P.
title: Integrated pest management in potato with special reference to ITK
abstract: *[An experiment was conducted in the Horticultural orchard of Assam Agricultural University, Jorhat for the 2014-15 & 2015-16 seasons to develop IPM modules against pest & diseases of potato.  Of the 10 different IPM modules, the IPM module consisting of soil application of mustard oil cake, followed by high ridge planting & use of yellow sticky traps, & was followed by applications of 5 per cent dust & Ridomil MZ-72 @ 0.01%.  This module recorded lowest infestation of mole crickets ( 3.42%) & red ants (7.71%), with a highest yield of 248.61 q/ha.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Dorylus orientalis; Dorylinae; Asia; India; scientific; distribution; soil; impact; agricultural; potato; yield; damages; IPM; chemical control; malathion; ridomil MZ-72; red ant;

author: Begum, R. and Majagi, S.H.
title: Biodiversity of ant fauna in the campus of government degree college, Kalaburagi
note: Part of FORMIS 23; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: *[This study was conducted to collect ants from the Campus of Government First Grade Degree College, Kalaburagi, which has undergone with several changes in natural habitat because of urbanization.  The objective of the study was to prepare a preliminary checklist of the campus.  The study was carried out during January 2019 to May 2019.  Ants were collected randomly from indoor (class rooms, laboratory, rest rooms & washrooms) and outdoor (streets, botanical garden, barren ground and parking site) by using aspirators, pitfall traps, bait traps, & hand pick method.  A total of 12 species representing 9 genera & 3 subfamilies: Dolichoderinae, Formicinae, & Myrmicinae were identified during the study.  Formicinae was the most diverse subfamily with 3 genera (Camponotus, Lepisiota, & Paratrechina) & 6 species (Camponotus compressus, C. irritans, C. parius, C. sericeus, Lepisiota frauenfeldi, & Paratrechina longicornis).  Myrmicinae was represented by 5 genera & 5 species (Crematogaster sp.1, Monomorium subopacum, Pheidole sulcaticeps, Solenopsis geminata, & Tetramorium walshi). Only a single species, Tapinoma melanocephalum, was collected from Dolichoderinae.]          *[Solenopsis geminata misspelled Solenopsis geminate.]

author: Begum, R. and Majagi, S.H. and Vijaykumar, K.
title: Ants species richness and diversity in relation to different ecological habitat in selected localities of the semi-arid region of Karnataka, India
note: Part of FORMIS 21; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: We analysed the taxonomic position and species diversity of ants in four different habitats (agriculture, vegetative, dry land, and human habitats). A total of 11,038 ant workers belonging to 40 species, 25 genera of 10 tribes, and six subfamilies were recorded. The Simpson index of diversity (1-D) was 0.97, indicating greater diversity in both vegetative and human habitat. Similarly, the Shannon index was 3.40 and 3.50 for both vegetative and human habitats, respectively, indicating assemblage of similar ant species in both habitats. In contrast, for agricultural habitat, Simpson index of diversity (1-D) was 0.90, and for dry land habitat, the least diversity of 0.80 was reported. However, in pair-wise comparisons, no significant difference was observed between agriculture and dry land and vegetative and human habitats. The agriculture and arid land habitats tend to have fewer species compared with the vegetative and human habitats. Human-disturbed areas have an important role as reservoirs of biodiversity and should be included in landscape management practices to improve ant conservation in the tropics.          *[ Polyrhachis misspelled Polyrachis; Pseudomyrmecinae misspelled Pseudomyrmicinae.]

author: Begum, R. and Majagi, S.H. and Vijaykumar, K.
title: Habitat associations of ant species (subfamily: Myrmicinae) in a heterogeneous landscape of Kalaburagi district, Karnataka
note: Part of FORMIS 22; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: *[The present study analyzes the variations in ants' community, especially with the Myrmicinae subfamily studied with respect to human, vegetative, dry land, & teak plantation habitats.  The species richness remains the same in both human & vegetative habitats, while the abundance was high in vegetative habitat.  The Simpson index (1-D) for human (social) & vegetative habitats was 0.6274 and 0.3706, respectively, which is less than 1, indicating a low diversity regarding the Myrmicinae in these habitats.  However, Shannon Wiener index (H) was 1.398 & 0.8349 for both human & vegetative habitats, indicating the higher number of species quartered in human habitats compared to vegetative habitats.  Solenopsis geminata was the only species encountered in the dry land habitat, & no myrmicine ants were captured in the teak plantation.  These preliminary results define the effects of different land-use patterns & illustrate ants' sensibility to changing landscape & disturbance due to various anthropogenic activities, which encourages their inclusion of species-level interactions within the habitat in conservation orientated bio-monitoring.]          *[Solenopsis geminata misspelled Solenopsis germinata.]

author: Belamkar, N.V. and Jadesh, M.
title: A preliminary study on abundance and diversity of insect fauna in Gulbarga District, Karnataka, India
abstract: *[A preliminary study was conducted on the abundance & diversity of insects species in agriculture fields of Hadgil Harutti village, Gulbarga, Karnataka, India.  The presentis study aimed to determine the species richness, dominance, & evenness of insect fauna from agriculture fields.  The study was carried out from June 2013 to September 2013.  A total of 11,318 insects from 6 orders, 26 families, & 54 species were recorded.  This study shows that Hymenoptera (78.86%) was the most dominant order according to total number of individuals.  The Simpson's Reciprocal Index diversity was highest in Coleoptera (8.048) & lowest in Diptera (1.000).  The species richness, evenness, & diversity of insects were calculated by Margalef's Index, Pielou's Index, & Shannon-Wiener Index, respectively.]          *[Monomorium scabriceps misspelled Monomoriun scabriceps.]          *[Monomorium scabriceps is now called Trichomyrmex scabriceps; Ward, et al. 2015.]

author: Bhagat, M. and Ganguli, J. and Gauraha, R.
title: Predatory behaviour of red ant (Oecophylla smaragdina F.) on various insect pests of different crops
abstract: *[Studies on the feeding & predatory behavior of weaver ant, Oecophylla smaragdina Fabricius (Hymenoptera, Formicidae) were conducted in the IINET (In Vivo Insect Natural Enemies Testing) field beside the Biocontrol laboratory, Department of Entomology, IGKV, & Raipur, Chhattisgarh.  The ants were found to be active foragers, scavengers, & predators prevalent in the vicinity of several horticultural plantations & crops.  The workers ants preyed on many insect species & fed on nectar exudates from plants as well as sticky secretions produced by Homopteran & Lepidopteran insects.  Results of this study revealed that O. smaragdina attacked a number of species of aphids, mealy bug, lepidopteran larvae, & a few beetles.  It consumed 100% sucking pests tested such as Green stink bug, Chinavia hilaris & hibiscus mealy bug, Maconellicoccus hirsutus & moderately consumed different species of aphids, i.e., oleander aphid, Aphis nerii (71.2%), Aonla aphid, Setaphis bougainvilleae (71%), Cowpea aphid, Aphis Craccivora (62.5%), Mustard aphid, Lipaphis erysimi (72.5%), Cabbage aphid, Brevicoryne brassicae (70.4%), & 67% of chrysanthamum aphid, Macrosiphoniella sanborni, whereas, gundhi bug (0%) was not preferred for their feeding, perhaps due to the unpleasant odor, emitted by the bug.  Other than sucking pests, O. smaragdina highly preyed on larvae of lemon butterfly, Papilio demoleus (100%), chickpea pod borer, Helicoverpa armigera (100%), rice horn caterpillar, Melanitis leda ismene (100%), & while a lesser feeding preference was seen in case of tobacco cut worm larvae, Spodoptera litura (72%), red pumpkin beetle, Raphidopalpa foveicollis (70%), fall army worm larvae, Spodoptera frugiperda (68%), & in leaf defoliator larvae, Euproctis spp. (54%) consumption was noticed.  Tussock moth larvae, Lymantriidae (0.00%), Bihar hairy caterpillar larvae, Spilosoma oblique (0.00%) were not at all since preferred probably due to the presence of hairs /setae on their body.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Oecophylla smaragdina; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; workers; feeding potential; nectar; honeydew; predatory behavior; biocontrol; weaver ant;

author: Bhagavathula, N. and Venkateshwarlu, M. and Bourque, S. and Vimaladevi, R. and Kesavakurup, S. and Selvadurai, D. and Shrivastava, S. and Krishnappa, C.
title: Characterization of two novel antimicrobial peptides from the cuticular extracts of the ant Trichomyrmex criniceps (Mayr),(Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
note: Part of FORMIS 21; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) from cuticular extracts of worker ants of Trichomyrmex criniceps (Mayr, Hymenoptera: Formicidae) were isolated and evaluated for their antimicrobial activity. Eight peptides ranging in mass from 804.42 to 1541.04 Da were characterized using a combination of analytical and bioinformatics approach. All the eight peptides were novel with no similarity to any of the AMPs archived in the Antimicrobial Peptide Database. Two of the eight novel peptides, the smallest and the largest by mass were named Crinicepsin1 and Crinicepsin2 and were chemically synthesized by solid phase peptide synthesis. The two synthetic peptides had antibacterial and weak hemolytic activity.

author: Bharti, H.
title: Altitudinal diversity of ants in Himalayan Regions (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
abstract: *[The Himalayan region has been colonized by Indo-Malayan, Indian, & other elements, with a high degree of endemic species.   Most of the ant genera recorded originated much earlier than the Himalayas & basal forms of a few (e.g., Myrmica) are concentrated here. The number of endemic elements, about 46%, appears to be much higher as compared to other elements.  115 ant species out of 202 reach up to or cross an altitude of 2000 meters above mean sea level & penetrate into the Palaearctic zone, 71 of these species are endemic.]

author: Bharti, H. and Akbar, S.A.
title: Taxonomic studies on the ant genus Strumigenys Smith, 1860 (Hymenoptera, Formicidae) with report of two new species and five new records including a tramp species from India
abstract: *[The Indian species of the ant genus Strumigenys Smith, 1860 are keyed.  Twenty-four species are recognized, 2 of which are described as new (S. mukkaliensis sp.n., S. thanikkudyensis sp.n.) & 5 represent new records to India.  The 24 Indian species are: S. aduncomala de Andrade, 2007; S. assamensis de Andrade, 1994; S. emmae (Emery, 1890); S. exilirhina Bolton, 2000; S. fixata Bolton, 2000; S. godeffroyi Mayr, 1866; S. habropilosa Bolton, 2000; S. hemisobek (Bolton, 2000); S. hostilis Bolton, 2000; S. hypoturba Bolton, 2000; S. lyroessa (Roger, 1859); S. membranifera Emery, 1869; S. mitis (Brown, 2000); S. mukkaliensis sp.n.; S. mutica (Brown, 1949); S. nannosobek (Bolton, 2000); S. nanzanensis Lin & Wu, 1996; S. nepalensis de Andrade, 1994; S. peraucta Bolton, 2000; S. podarge (Bolton, 2000); S. rogeri Emery, 1890; S. smythiesii Forel, 1902; S. thanikkudyensis sp.n., &  S. virgila Bolton, 2000.   S. hemisobek; S. mitis; S. mutica; S. nannosobek, & S. rogeri represent first records from India, including the tramp species S. rogeri.]

author: Bharti, H. and Akbar, S.A.
title: Taxonomic studies on the ant genus Cerapachys Smith (Hymenoptera, Formicidae) from India
note: Part of FORMIS 14; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: The Indian species of the ant genus Cerapachys Smith are keyed. Twelve species are recognized of which 6 are described as new. The species are: Cerapachys aitkenii Forel, Cerapachys alii sp. n., Cerapachys anokha sp. n., Cerapachys besucheti Brown, Cerapachys biroi Forel, Cerapachys indicus Brown, Cerapachys longitarsus (Mayr), Cerapachys nayana sp. n., Cerapachys schoedli sp. n., Cerapachys seema sp. n., Cerapachys sulcinodis Emery and Cerapachys wighti sp. n. Geographic distribution and group affinities of the new species are discussed. A revised key to the Indian species is provided. The rare ergatoid queens of Cerapachys nayana, Cerapachys schoedli and Cerapachys seema are reported. Formed in response to selective pressures these ergatoid queens have a significant role in dispersal strategies and contribute much to our understanding of the biology of these ants.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Cerapachys aitkenii; Cerapachys alii; Cerapachys anokha; Cerapachys besucheti; Cerapachys biroi; Cerapachys indicus; Cerapachys longitarsus; Cerapachys nayana; Cerapachys schoedli; Cerapachys seema; Cerapachys sulcinodis; Cerapachys wighti; Cerapachyinae; Asia; India; scientific; workers; quuens; ergatoid queens; males; morphology; taxonomy; key; distribution; habitat; myrmecophagy; Winkler method;

author: Bharti, H. and Akbar, S.A.
title: First record of genus Protanilla (Hymenoptera: Formicidae: Leptanillinae) from India with description of a new species
note: Part of FORMIS 17; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Protanilla wardi sp. nov. from Kerala, India is described and illustrated, which also confirms first record of the genus from this country. The new species is somewhat close to P. rafflesi Bolton, 1990 for its anteriorly concave petiolar node but differs from the latter by its vertical, not anteriorly inclined postpetiolar node. The new species represents only the 9th known species of this rare ant genus to be described.

author: Bharti, H. and Akbar, S.A. and Singh, J.
title: Discothyrea periyarensis sp. n., a new proceratiine ant species (Hymenoptera: formicidae: Proceratiinae) from India
journal: Caucasian Entomol. Bull. = Kavkazskii Entomologicheskii Byulleten
note: Part of FORMIS 17; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Discothyrea periyarensis sp. n. is described from India. The new species represents the 10th valid species from Oriental region with D. banna Xu et al., 2014, D. bryanti (Wheeler, 1917), D. diana Xu et al., 2014, D. globa Forel, 1905, D. kamiteta Kubota et Terayama, 1999, D. sauteri Forel, 1912, D. sringerensis Zacharias et Rajan, 2004, D. stumperi Baroni Urbani, 1977 and D. yueshen Terayama, 2009 reported earlier. Among these, the new species shares most affinities with D. bryanti but with the frontal carinae only extending posteriorly to 1/2 length of head and anterior margin of clypeus not crenulate. The new species represents the 3rd valid species from India with D. sringerensis and D. stumperi reported earlier. A revised key to the known Oriental species is provided herewith.

An identification key based on the worker caste of Indian species is provided.]

author: Bharti, H. and Ali, S.
title: A new species of the ant genus Lordomyrma (Hymenoptera: Formicidae: Myrmicinae) from India
abstract: *[Lordomyrma taylori sp.n. is described from Silent Valley National Park, Kerala in SW India.  This is the second species of the genus known from India, with Lordomyrma lakshmi Taylor, 2012 reported earlier.  The new species resembles most the Bornean Lordomyrma reticulata Lucky & Sarnat, 2008 from which it can be separated by the less reticulated cephalic sculpture, larger & more upcurved propodeal spines & denser sculpture of gaster.]

author: Bharti, H. and Bharti, M. and Kaur, P. and Kaur, J.
title: On the description of the larval stages of Myrmica inezae Forel, 1902 (Hymenoptera: Formicidae: Myrmicinae), an endemic Himalayan species, with notes on its natural history
abstract: *[Of the known species groups in Myrmica, the M. inezae belong to the inezae-group, which is restricted between an altitude range of 1900-3000m in Himalayas.  The species in question is a relic of old fauna & closely resembles the primitive M. ritae-group species.  A detailed description of the 3 larval instars of Myrmica inezae Forel, 1902 is provided.  The ist larvae exhibit aphaenogastroid body profile.  The 2nd & 3rd larvae exhibit pheidoloid body profile, but is pogonomyrmecoid in the previously reported larval stages of genus Myrmica Latreille, 1804.  M. inezae differs from the earlier described larval stages of M. rugosa & M. rupestris (rugosa-group) based on number of occipital hairs (6 in M. inezae as compared to 8 in M. hecate & M. rupestris); mandibular teeth (2 in M. inezae as compared to one in M. hecate & M. rupestris), & shape of maxilla (conoidal in M. inezae as compared to paraboloidal in M. hecate & M. rupestris).]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Myrmica hecate; Myrmica inezae; Myrmica inezae gp.; Myrmica ritae gp.; Myrmica rugosa; Myrmica rugosa gp.; Myrmica rupestris; Myrmicinae; Asia; India; Himalayas; scientific; larval stages; larval shape; morphology; aphaenogastroid; pheidoloid; pogonomyrmecoid; taxonomy; distribution; relic forms; endemic species; SEM;

author: Bharti, H. and Bharti, M. and Pfeiffer, M.
title: Ants as bioindicators of ecosystem health in Shivalik Mountains of Himalayas: assessment of species diversity and invasive species
note: Part of FORMIS 17; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: *[The Northern-Indian Shivalik mountain range has recently come under strong anthropogenic pressure.  Ants were used as bioindicators to assess ecosystem health of the area.  We measured diversity, community patterns, species composition, & the influence of invasive species of ants by collecting at 75 sites from 44 locations in 3 habitats: primary forest, secondary forest, & non-forest areas using 6 collection techniques.  We obtained the most comprehensive dataset compiled for Indian ants to date (sample coverage 94 % to 97 %) & sampled 31,487 ant specimens, representing 181 species from 59 genera & 9 ant families.  Thirty of the 59 genera were represented by a single species, 12 genera by more than 5 species, & 26 species were new to science.  Species richness differed significantly between habitats, with 151 in secondary forest, 120 in primary forest, & 110 in non-forest areas.  Species richness rose with altitude & was influenced by precipitation, northern latitude, & eastern longitude.  As demonstrated by redundancy analysis & beta diversity, habitats also differed in species composition.  Nineteen invasive/tramp species, comprising ca. 13% of total abundance, were distributed among the 3 habitats (including primary forest).  Our findings point towards a disrupted, degraded ecosystem with high anthropogenic impact & reduced ecosystem health, even in the primary & protected forest areas.  Invasive species pose a serious threat to the native species of Himalaya.  At present the ant invasions are limited to lower mountain ranges, but with increases in global temperatures invasive species will soon spread to Himalayan highlands.]

author: Bharti, H. and Dhiman, N. and Bharti, M. and Wachkoo, A.A.
title: SEM studies on immature stages of Aphaenogaster beesoni Donisthorpe, 1933 (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
abstract: *[Larval instars of Aphaenogaster beesoni Donisthorpe, 1933 are described in detail by using scanning electron microscopy.  Based on the body profile, body size, types of body hairs, & head capsule size, a total of 5 larval stages are recognized.  All 5 instars show clear variations in their body shape & mouth parts.  Body of the first instar is Aphaenogastroid, while that of the second, third, & fourth is Pogonomyrmecoid, & in fifth it again becomes Aphaenogastroid type.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Aphaenogaster beesoni; Myrmicinae; Asia; India; scientific; larvae; instar number; morphology; SEM studies;

author: Bharti, H. and GuÈnard, B. and Bharti, M. and Economo, E.P.
title: An updated checklist of the ants of India with their specific distributions in Indian states (Hymenoptera, Formicidae)
note: Part of FORMIS 17; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: As one of the 17 megadiverse countries of the world and with four biodiversity hotspots represented in its borders, India is home to an impressive diversity of life forms. However, much work remains to document and catalogue the species of India and their geographic distributions, especially for diverse invertebrate groups. In the present study, a comprehensive and critical list of Indian ant species is provided with up-to-date state-wise distribution. A total of 828 valid species and subspecies names belonging to 100 genera are listed from India. Potential erroneous data, misidentifications and dubious distributional records that may exist in the literature are also identified. The present exhaustive listing of Indian ants will provide a holistic view about diversity and distribution and will also help to identify major undersampled areas where future sampling and taxonomic efforts should be directed.          *[NOTE: This identification needs to be confirmed.  India would be a significant range extension for the invasive species Solenopsis invicta.]          *[This Solenopsis invicta record is listed as dubious by https://www.antwiki.org/wiki/Solenopsis_invicta  checked 7 Sept. 2019.]

author: Bharti, H. and Gul, I.
title: Echinopla cherapunjiensis sp. n. (Hymenoptera, Formicidae) from India
note: Part of FORMIS 14; from NALs AGRICOLA; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: Echinopla cherapunjiensis Bharti et Gul, sp. n. is described from India. This represents the second species of genus reported in India, with only Echinopla lineata senilis Mayr, 1862 described earlier from Nicobar Islands. The species distinctly differs from all other known species of this genus by the following combination of characters: globose shape of head, presence of seven teeth on petiolar scale, flat dorsum of mesosoma with promesonotal and mesometanotal sutures obsolete, whole body surface (dorsum) rough due to sinuous sculpture, deep excavations and spiky elevations on head and mesosoma and excavations on gaster.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Echinopla cherapunjiensis; Echinopla lineata senilis; Formicinae; Asia; India; Nicobar Islands; scientific; worker; morphology; taxonomy; distribution; habitat; altitude;

author: Bharti, H. and Gul, I.
title: Lasius elevatus, a new ant species of the subgenus Cautolasius (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from the Indian Himalayas
abstract: *[A new species of Formicinae, Lasius elevatus sp.nov., is described from the Indian Himalayas.  This is the third species of the subgenus Cautolasius known from the Himalayas, with L. alienoflavus Bingham, 1903 & L. talpa Wilson, 1955 reported previously.  A key is provided for the 13 species reported from this region.  Listed in key are: Lasius alienoflavus Bingham, Lasius alienus (Foerster), Lasius bicornis Foerster, Lasius breviscapus Seifert, Lasius brunneus (Latreille), Lasius carniolicus Mayr, Lasius crinitus Smith, Lasius elevatus sp.nov., Lasius himalayanus Bingham, Lasius magnus Seifert, Lasius mikir Collingwood, Lasius niger (Linnaeus), & Lasius wittmeri Seifert.]

author: Bharti, H. and Gul, I.
title: First description of the male caste of the Himalayan endemic ant Lasius alienoflavus Bingham, 1903 (Hymenoptera: Formicidae), with re-description of the female and queen castes
note: Part of FORMIS 16; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: The present paper provides a description of the male caste and re-description of the worker and queen castes of the poorly known ant species Lasius alienoflavus Bingham, 1903. This species has hitherto been reported only from the Himalayas, and the present data are also based on specimens collected in the north-western part of the mountain range. Likewise other Himalayan ants, this species also shows restricted distribution, which suggests a rather high degree of endemism (45%) of this group in the Himalayas.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Lasius alienoflavus; Formicinae; Asia; India; Himalaya; scientific; workers; females; queen; males; morphology; taxonomy; distribution; endemism; altitude; Winkler extraction;

author: Bharti, H. and Gul, I. and Sasi, S.
title: Taxonomy of Temnothorax simlensis stat. nov. (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) with first description of sexual castes along with a mention of its plesiobiotic association with Himalayan species of genus Myrmica
abstract: *[The subspecies Temnothorax rothneyi simlensis (Forel) is raised to species rank as Temnothorax simlensis stat. nov.  All 3 castes are recorded, with the queen & male castes described for the first time.  This revision is based on the comparative data from morphometry, descriptions, digital images, & distribution.  In addition, we provide first-hand information about the plesiobiotic association of this species with Himalayan species of genus Myrmica.  A revised key to the worker caste of known Indian species of Temnothorax is also provided.]

author: Bharti, H. and Kaur, J. and Fox, E.G.P. and Bharti, M.
title: Larval instar estimation and ultrastructural analysis of Aphaenogaster cristata (Forel, 1902) and Aphaenogaster pachei (Forel, 1906) (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from the Himalayas
note: Part of FORMIS 24; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: The ontogeny of an organism provides fundamental insights into its life history and evolutionary background. Among insects, especially ants, relatively few observations have been formalized about the morphology of immature stages. Using light and scanning electron microscopy, this study presents the first description of the different larval instars of Aphaenogaster cristata (Forel, 1902) and Aphaenogaster pachei (Forel, 1906), species endemic to the Himalayas that predominate in areas where cold temperature stress and disturbances limit the presence of other ants. The existence of four larval instars was estimated based on the frequency distribution of their measured maximum head widths. We observed discrete alterations in the body constitution and parts among the different instars, suggesting they must follow similar habits until pupation. The two species, however, present noticeable particularities in their mandibles and hair types, suggesting intrinsic life adaptations. Observed traits complementary with previous descriptions with larvae of the genus and related taxa are suggestive of considerable evolutionary distance from Messor, considered the sister clade, which merits further taxonomic investigation in future studies.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Aphaenogaster cristata; Aphaenogaster pachei; Messor; Myrmicinae; Asia; India; scientific; larvae; larval instars; instars; morphology; ultrastructure; frequency distribution; head widths; life history; ontogeny; pupation; cold stress; Himalayan region;

title: Description of the ant larvae of two species of the genus Myrmica Latreille, 1804 (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from Indian Himalayas
abstract: *[We provide descriptions of 3 larval instars of 2 ant species: Myrmica hecate Weber 1947 & Mymica rupestris Forel 1902.   Myrmica rupestris larvae exhibit the 'pogonomyrmecoid' body shape (considered ancestral in the genus Myrmica), whereas M. hecate larvae exhibit the 'pheidoloid' shape.]

author: Bharti, H. and Kumar, R.
title: Lophomyrmex terraceensis, a new ant species (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) in the bedoti group with a revised key
note: Part of FORMIS 13; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: Lophomyrmex terraceensis sp. nov. is described from India. This species belongs to the bedoti group of the genus Lophomyrmex, which is characterized by a pronotum with lateral irregular marginations. The new species can be separated from other species within this group by the presence of sub-parallel, blunt and thick propodeal spines of almost uniform diameter and by an obliquely truncate petiolar node.

author: Bharti, H. and Kumar, R.
title: Taxonomic studies on genus Tetramorium Mayr (Hymenoptera, Formicidae) with report of two new species and three new records including a tramp species from India with a revised key
note: Part of FORMIS 14; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: Two new species of Tetramorium Mayr, namely Tetramorium shivalikense sp. n. and Tetramorium triangulatum sp. n. are described. Tetramorium triangulatum sp. n. belongs to the inglebyi-species group and is described based on worker, queen and male caste, while Tetramorium shivalikense sp. n. belongs to the ciliatum-species group and is described based on worker caste only. Three species viz., Tetramorium caldarium (Roger), Tetramorium tonganum Mayr and Tetramorium urbanii Bolton represent first records from India. The male caste is described for the first time in the case of Tetramorium tonganum. Among these, Tetramorium caldarium is a tramp species which extends its limit to India as well. A revised key to the Indian ants of this genus is also provided herewith.

author: Bharti, H. and Kumar, R.
title: Five new species of Dilobocondyla (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) with a revised key to the known species
abstract: *[Five new species of Dilobocondyla are described.  Dilobocondyla gasteroreticulatus sp.nov. is reported from India based on worker & female castes.  Dilobocondyla eguchii sp.nov. & D. propotriangulatus sp.nov. are reported from Vietnam, D. yamanei sp.nov. from Malaysia, & D. gaoyureni from China based on worker caste only.  Dilobocondyla fouqueti Santschi is redescribed, with reports of male & female castes.  A revised key to the genus is also provided.  With the addition of these five new species, the genus is now represented by 15 species & 2 subspecies globally.  These species are keyed in the key: D. bangalorica Varghese, D. borneensis Wheeler, D. cataulacoidea (Stitz), D. chapmani Wheeler, D. chapmani rufobrunnea Wheeler, D. didita (Walker), D. eguchii sp.nov., D. fouqueti Santschi, D. fulva Viehmeyer, D. gaoyureni sp.nov, D. gasteroreticulatus sp.nov., D. karnyi Wheeler, D. propotriangulatus sp.nov., D. sebesiana Wheeler, D. selebensis (Emery), D. selebensis simalurana Forel, D. yamanei sp.nov.]

author: Bharti, H. and Kumar, R.
title: Six new species of Carebara Westwood (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) with restructuring of world species groups and a key to Indian species
abstract: *[Six new species of the myrmicine ants Carebara Westwood are described: The monomorphic C. carinata sp.nov. & C. propomegata sp.nov. & the dimorphic C. dentata sp.nov., C. hornata sp.nov., C. rectangulata sp.nov., & C. spinata sp.nov.  Carebara carinata sp.nov. has a central long clypeal hair as an inusual trait, also present in other foreign Carebara.  Some of these new species support the previous synonymy of Oligomyrmex & Parvimyrma under Carebara & show mixed attributes that recall the restructuring of existing World species groups.  Separate keys for major worker, worker, & gyne are provided for Indian species.]

author: Bharti, H. and Kumar, R. and Dubovikoff, D.A.
title: A new species of the genus Tapinoma Foerster, 1850 (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from India
journal: Caucasian Entomol. Bull. = Kavkazskii Entomologicheskii Byulleten
note: Part of FORMIS 16; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: A new species of the genus Tapinoma Foerster, 1850 is described from the North-Western Himalayas, India. T. himalaica sp. n. belongs to the lugubre species-group, which includes, beside the type species, also T. wilsoni Sharaf, Aldawood, 2012. The main distinguishing feature of this species-group is the structure of propodeum. All discussed in this article species have a propodeum with a pointed apex. A new species described here, differs from another known species of this groups more narrow head and a longer scape
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Tapinoma himalaica; Tapinoma lugubre; Tapinoma wilsoni; Tapinoma lugubre gp.; Dolichoderinae; Asia; India; scientific; worker; morphology; taxonomy; key; distribution;

author: Bharti, H. and Radchenko, A. and Sasi, S.
title: Socially-parasitic Myrmica species (Hymenoptera, Formicidae) of Himalaya, with the description of a new species
note: Part of FORMIS 17; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: A new socially-parasitic species, Myrmica latra sp. n. is described based on a queen and male from Indian Himalaya. Its queen differs from other species by the distinctly narrower petiole and postpetiole, blunt and non-divergent propodeal spines, and a darker body colour. The taxonomic position of the three known Himalayan socially-parasitic Myrmica species is discussed, and Myrmica ereptrix Bolton 1988 is transferred to the smythiesii species-group. It is supposed that Myrmica nefaria Bharti 2012 is a temporary social parasite, but Myrmica ereptrix and Myrmica latra sp. n. are permanent social parasites, and a key for their identification is provided.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Myrmica aimonissabaudiae; Myrmica ereptrix; Myrmica latra; Myrmica nefaria; Myrmica smythiesii gp.; Myrmicinae; Asia; India; scientific; queens; males; morphology; taxonomy; key; distribution; nests; social parasitism; temporary social parasite; permanent social parasite;

author: Bharti, H. and Rilta, J.S.
title: A new species and a new record of the ant genus Stigmatomma Roger (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from India
abstract: *[Stigmatomma xui sp.n., a new species of the ant genus Stigmatomma Roger, 1859 collected from NE Himalaya is described.  Stigmatomma awa (Xu & Chu, 2012) is also reported for the first time from India & is formally transferred from Ambylopone to Stigmatomma.  A key is provided to distinguish the related species.]

author: Bharti, H. and Rilta, J.S.
title: Taxonomic studies on the ant genus Ponera Latreille, 1804 (Hymenoptera, Formicidae), with the description of a new species from India
note: Part of FORMIS 17; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Four species of the ant genus Ponera Latreille, 1804, are recorded from India. The present study reports one new species Ponera sikkimensis sp. n., a divergent population of Ponera indica Bharti & Wachkoo, 2012 and one new record, Ponera paedericera Zhou, 2001 from India. An identification key and distributions for the four known Indian species of Ponera based on the worker caste are provided.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Ponera indica; paedericera; Ponera paedericera; Ponera sikkimensis; Ponera taylori; Ponerinae; Asia; India; scientific; workers; queens; morphology; taxonomy; key; new record; new species; distribution; northeastern Himalaya;

author: Bharti, H. and Rilta, J.S. and Dhadwal, T.
title: Two new species of Ooceraea (Hymenoptera, Formicidae, Dorylinae) from India with ten-segmented antennae
note: Part of FORMIS 21; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Two new species, O. decamera sp. nov. and O. joshii sp. nov., of the ant genus Ooceraea are described from India. These species differ from other known congeners on the basis of number of antennal segments. An illustrated key to the known species based on the worker caste is also provided.

author: Bharti, H. and Sharma, Y.P.
title: Diversity and abundance of ants along an elevational gradient in Jammu-Kashmir Himalaya - I
abstract: *[Ant diversity was studied at an altitude of 1000-m & 2000-m above mean sea level along an elevational gradient in Jammu-Kashmir Himalaya.  Ants were collected with the help of pitfall traps, Winkler samples, & hand collection along a transect of 250-m at each site.  Species richness was estimated with the help of Colwell's EstimatorS.  The subfamily Myrmicinae has been found to be 66%, followed by Formicinae 26.81%, Ponerinae 4.84%, & Dolichoderinae 2.35%.  The data generated reflects that with decrease in temperature & humidity, composition of species changes as in case of Myrmicinae, the generalist species are replaced by more high altitude specialists like Myrmica & Aphaenogaster.  In case of Formicinae, the interpretation resembles Myrmicinae as cold specialist Formica increases in abundance. Interestingly, the overall abundance increases from 1000-m to 2000-m with number of species almost same at both the elevations.]

author: Bharti, H. and Sharma, Y.P.
title: Myrmica elmesi (Hymenoptera, Formicidae) a new species from Himalaya
note: Part of FORMIS 12; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Myrmica elmesi sp. n. is described from Himalaya. This species belongs to the pachei group of Myrmica speciesand is distinct from the species described in this group hitherto, which is represented by 14 species including three from Indian Himalaya. Myrmica elmesi is the fourth species of the diverse pachei group found in Himalaya; it was collected from the transitional zone and is described with notes on its ecology, this gains significance in the sense that ecology of most of the old world Myrmica is either unknown or poorly known.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Myrmica elmesi; Myrmica pachei gp.; Myrmicinae; Asia; India; scientific; worker; morphology; taxonomy; key; distribution; habitat; altitude;

author: Bharti, H. and Sharma, Y.P.
title: Myrmica radchenkoi a new species of ant (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from Indian Himalaya
abstract: *[Myrmica radchenkoi sp.nov. is reported from Indian Himalaya with discovery of workers & queen.  This new species reinforces the placement of its close ally, the earlier reported Myrmica rigatoi Radchenko and Elmes, 1998 in the inezae species group, where it had been provisionally placed.  The queen in Myrmica radchenkoi sp.nov. shows some close proximity with previously described Myrmica inezae queen.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Myrmica inezae; Myrmica radchenkoi; Myrmica rigatoi; Myrmica inezae gp.; Myrmicinae; Asia; India; scientific; workers; queen; morphology; taxonomy; altitude; distribution; Himalaya; Himalayan region;

author: Bharti, H. and Sharma, Y.P.
title: Myrmica longisculpta, a new species from Himalaya (Hymenoptera: Formicidae: Myrmicinae)
abstract: *[Myrmica longisculpta sp.nov. is described from SW slopes of Himalayas in the Jammu & Kashmir region of India.  It is most similar to species of the Myrmica rugosa Mayr, 1865 species group, but based just on workers, this species cannot be placed with certainty to any species group in the scheme provided by Radchenko & Elmes (2010).]

author: Bharti, H. and Sharma, Y.P.
title: Three new species of genus Myrmica (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from Himalaya
note: Part of FORMIS 13; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: Three new species of the genus Myrmica are described from the Himalayas. Myrmica curvispinosa sp. nov., Myrmica kothiensis sp. nov. and Myrmica religiosa sp. nov. belong to the Myrmica inezae species group, which is earlier represented by 4 species. Myrmica curvispinosa sp. nov. is described based on worker and gyne, with a report of ergatoid as well. Myrmica kothiensis sp. nov. and Myrmica religiosa sp. nov. are described based on worker caste only. A key to the species of the Myrmica inezae species group has been provided in the following.

author: Bharti, H. and Sharma, Y.P. and Bharti, M. and Pfeiffer, M.
title: Ant species richness, endemicity and functional groups, along an elevational gradient in the Himalayas
note: Part of FORMIS 13; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: *[In this study, we investigate variation in species density, species richness, abundance, & functional-groups composition along an elevational gradient in Jammu-Kashmir Himalaya.  We employed different sampling methods like pitfall traps, leaf-litter sifting, stick beating, soil cores, honey baits, & hand picking to sample ants.  Among the 144 species collected, the first 2-elevations (500, 1000 m) were dominated by Indo-Malayan elements, while above 2000 m assemblages were dominated by Palaearctic elements.  We observed that ant species richness increased with an initial increase in elevation, peaked at mid-elevation, & thereafter decreased, thus forming a mid-elevation peak.  The pattern observed could be attributed to the optimal climatic conditions present at mid-altitude.  While 7 functional groups of ants were collected at the lowest altitude, only 3 functional groups were detected at the highest altitude, namely General Myrmicinae, Opportunists, & Cold-climate Specialists.  Twenty-three% of the recorded species are endemic to the study region, with Myrmica species dominating this group.  The presence of invasive species at lower elevations indicates a high degree of disturbance in the Himalayan ecosystem.]

author: Bharti, H. and Sharma, Y.P. and Kaur, A.
title: Seasonal patterns of ants (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) in Punjab Shivalik
abstract: *[Seasonal patterns of ants were analyzed in 5 seasons in the Punjab Shivalik range of North-West Himalayas.  Various collection methods like pitfall traps, Winkler's, fish bait, & hand picking were used.  40 species belonging to 8 subfamilies have been observed for seasonal patterns.  The subfamilies Myrmicinae followed by Formicinae were found to be dominant.  Temperature & relative humidity have been correlated with seasonal patterns.]

author: Bharti, H. and Silla, S.
title: Notes on life history of Oecophylla smaragdina (Fabricius) and its potential as biological control agent
abstract: *[At the Horticulture Department, Punjabi University, Patiala, life history, nest building behavior, caste composition, & potential of Oecophylla smargadina as biological control agent were studied.  80 mango trees & 25 citrus trees were found with Oecophylla nests, & the number of nests per tree were observed.  Average yield per tree with & without ant nests was calculated.]

title: First Record of Genus Pristomyrmex Mayr 1866 (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from India
abstract: *[The genus Pristomyrmex Mayr, 1866 is recorded for the first time from India.  Pristomyrmex sulcatus Emery, 1895 has been collected from NE Himalaya.]

author: Bharti, H. and Wachkoo, A.
title: New combination for a little known Indian ant, Paraparatrechina aseta (Forel, 1902) comb. n. (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
abstract: *[A new combination is proposed for the little known Indian ant Paraparatrechina aseta (Forel, 1902) comb.n.  It was a misfit in its' earlier taxonomic position & therefore is transferred from Nylanderia to Paraparatrechina, & redescribed with illustrations.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Nylanderia aseta; Paraparatrechina aseta; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; morphology; taxonomy; systematics; edescription; distribution; Himalaya;

author: Bharti, H. and Wachkoo, A.
title: A new carpenter ant, Camponotus parabarbatus (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from India
note: Part of FORMIS 15; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: A new species of carpenter ant, collected in the Shivalik range of Himalaya is described and illustrated based on the worker and gyne castes under the name Camponotus parabarbatus sp. n. Presence of dense, short setae on gena and ventral surface of head resembles it most to Camponotus barbatus Roger, 1863 distributed in Southeast Asia. A regional identification key of Camponotus species is provided from the Shivalik hills of Indian Himalaya.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Camponotus parabarbatus; Formicinae; Asia; India; Himalaya; scientific; workers; major workers; minor workers; queens; morphology; taxonomy; key; distribution;

author: Bharti, H. and Wachkoo, A.A.
title: Amblyopone boltoni, a new ant species (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from India
abstract: *[Amblyopone boltoni sp.nov. is described from India.  This is the fourth species of the genus known in India with A. bellii Forel,1900, A. rothneyi Forel,1900, & A. pertinax Baroni Urbani,1978 reported earlier.  This also confirms the first record of the subfamily Amblyoponinae from Northwest Himalayas.  An identification key to the worker caste of Indian species is included.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Amblyopone bellii; Amblyopone boltoni; Amblyopone pertinax; Amblyopone rothneyi; Amblyoponinae; Asia; India; scientific; worker; morphology; taxonomy; key; distribution;

author: Bharti, H. and Wachkoo, A.A.
title: First record of Prionopelta kraepelini (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from India, with description of male caste
abstract: *[This is the first record of Prionopelta kraepelini from India, collected in foothills of Northwest Himalaya, the Shivalik. This is the first member of this genus from India.  The male of this species is also described here for the first time.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Prionopelta kraepelini; Amblyoponinae; Asia; India; scientific; worker; male; morphology; taxonomy; distribution; hand collecting;

author: Bharti, H. and Wachkoo, A.A.
title: First verified record of genus Ponera (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from India, with description of two new species
abstract: *[Ponera indica sp.n. (workers) & Ponera taylori sp.n. (workers& males) collected in lower Shivalik range of Northwest Himalaya, India, are described.  This finding represents the first verified record of the genus Ponera for India.  Ponera affinis Jerdon & Ponera pumila Jerdon were described inadequately from Malabar India are unidentifiable to genus & are considered incertae sedis.  Ponera indica most resembles Philippine P. oreas & distinctly differs from all already described species of this genus.  Ponera taylori resembles P. nangongshana from China & P. yuhuang from Taiwan, sharing with them the absence of posteroventral teeth of subpetiolar process in worker caste.  An identification key to the workers of Indian Ponera species is provided.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Ponera affinis; Ponera indica; Ponera pumila; Ponera taylori; Ponerinae; Asia; India; scientific; workers; male; morphology; taxonomy; incertae sedis; key; distribution; Winkler's extractor, soil core; hand collecting;

author: Bharti, H. and Wachkoo, A.A.
title: Prenolepis fisheri, an intriguing new ant species, with a re-description of Prenolepis naoroji (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from India
abstract: *[Prenolepis fisheri sp.n., an intriguing species described as new, is the second species of the genus known from India, with only Prenolepis naoroji Forel, 1902 reported earlier.  P. fisheri sp. n. resembles the Antillean Prenolepis albimaculata Santschi, 1930, Prenolepis gibberosa Roger, 1863, & Prenolepis karstica Fontenla, 2000, sharing with them the presence of ocelli in the worker caste. All castes of Prenolepis naoroji are described & a key is provided for the Indian species.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Prenolepis fisheri; Prenolepis naoroji; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; workers; queens; males; morphology; taxonomy; distribution; habitat; hand collecting;

author: Bharti, H. and Wachkoo, A.A.
title: First record of the genus Myopias (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from India, with description of new species
note: Part of FORMIS 14; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: Myopias shivalikensis Bharti et Wachkoo, sp. n. is described based on a single worker, collected in lower Shivalik range (700 m a. s. l.) of Northwest Himalaya by soil core method. The genus Myopias is recorded for the first time in India. M. shivalikensis is a cryptobiotic species with reduced body size and rudimentary eyes. It is similar to M. nops Willey et Brown, 1983, distinctly differing from all described species of this genus.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Myopias nops; Myopias shivalikensis; Ponerinae; Asia; India; Nepal; scientific; worker; morphology; taxonomy; distribution; habitat; altitude; cryptobiotic species; soil core;

author: Bharti, H. and Wachkoo, A.A.
title: Two new species of trap jaw ant Anochetus (Hymenoptera: Formicidae), with a key to known species from India
note: Part of FORMIS 13; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: A key to the Indian species of the ponerine ant genus Anochetus Mayr, 1861 is presented and two new species are described: Anochetus cryptus sp. nov. and Anochetus validus sp. nov. collected from foothills of Himalaya, the Shivalik. Anochetus cryptus is a cryptobiotic species with minute eyes, light-pigmented integument, relatively reduced size and feeble sculpture; it most resembles Anochetus evansi Crawley, 1922. Anochetus validus is a member of the wide spread graeffei group, with strong sculpture and highly pigmented integument.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Anochetus cryptus; Anochetus evansi; Anochetus graeffei;Anochetus kanariensis; Anochetus madaraszi; Anochetus myops; Anochetus obscurior; Anochetus pupulatus; Anochetus rufus; Anochetus sedilloti; Anochetus validus; Anochetus yerburyi; Anochetus graeffei gp.; Ponerinae; Asia; India; scientific; worker; gyne; morphology; taxonomy; key; distribution;

author: Bharti, H. and Wachkoo, A.A.
title: Two new species of the ant genus Leptogenys (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from India, with description of a plesiomorphic ergatogyne
abstract: *[Two new species of Leptogenys based on the worker caste are described under the names Leptogenys lattkei sp.nov. & Leptogenys transitionis sp.nov.  The ergatogyne of Leptogenys transitionis reported here is the first of its kind in Leptogenys, characterized by a highly enlarged gaster, 3 prominent ocelli & the absence of wing sclerites.  The ergatogyne of L. transitionis is intermediate between that of L. ergatogyna, with well-developed wing-base sclerites & ocelli, & the more usual ergatoid condition characterized by degenerate ocelli.  Includes a key to species of Leptogenys of India based on worker caste, including: L. assamensis Forel, L. binghamii Forel, L. birmana Forel, L. chinensis (Mayr), L. dalyi Forel, L. dentilobis Forel, L. diminuta (Smith, F.), L. diminuta deceptrix Forel, L. diminuta laeviceps (Smith, F.), L. diminuta diminutolaeviceps Forel, L. diminuta palliseri Forel, L. diminuta woodmasoni (Forel), L. emiliae Forel, L. hysterica Forel, L. jeanettei Tiwari, L. kitteli (Mayr), L. kitteli minor Forel, L. lattkei sp. nov., L. lucidula Emery, L. minchinii Forel, L. moelleri (Bingham), L. peuqueti (AndrÈ), L. processionalis (Jerdon), L. punctiventris (Mayr), L. roberti Forel, L. roberti coonoorensis Forel, L. transitionis sp. nov.  Leptogenys longiscapa Donisthorpe, 1943, & L. iridipennis (Smith, F., 1858), both based on males only, are excluded from key, as is Leptogenys stenocheilos (Jerdon, 1851) due to the inadequate description & unavailability of the material.]

title: Cerapachys browni and Cerapachys costatus, two new rare ant species (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from India
note: Part of FORMIS 15; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Descriptions of Cerapachys browni sp. n. and Cerapachys costatus sp. n. from India are provided. C. browni is the member of the wide spread dohertyi group while C. costatus represents the 3rd species of the rare crawleyi group, with C. sauteri Forel, 1913 and C. crawleyi Wheeler, 1924 reported earlier. An identification key to the worker caste of Indian Cerapachys species is provided.

abstract: Descriptions of two new species Aenictus indicus sp. nov. and Aenictus wilsoni sp. nov. are provided from India. author: Bharti, M. and Bharti, H.
title: Association and impact of ectoparasitic blowflies (Diptera: Calliphoridae) on Himalayan ants of genus Myrmica
note: Part of FORMIS 17; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Parasitism is an arms race, where host and parasite try to out-compete each other. Ants are no exception to parasitism and are parasitized by several organisms including ants themselves. Some blowflies use ants as a resource for the completion of their life cycle. For the first time, we report in detail such an association between species of blowfly genus Stomorhina and Himalayan ants of Genus Myrmica.

author: Bhatnagar, S. and Kumari, R.
title: Floral biology, pollination biology, and breeding mechanisms reveal challenges to restoration of Buchanania lanzan, a vulnerable plant species
note: Part of FORMIS 24; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Understanding a species' reproductive biology, which encompasses floral biology, pollination biology, and breeding system, is necessary for the restoration of endangered plant species. Buchanania lanzan is a vulnerable evergreen tree in IUCN Red Data Book due to excessive deforestation and over-exploitation. Light and scanning electron microscopy and histochemical analysis were used to study floral and pollination biology. Experiments were conducted to study floral and pollination biology, including pollen viability, stigma receptivity, and pollen-pistil interactions. Bisexual, pentamerous, complete yellowish-white flowers have an annual growth of 11 months and are arranged in terminal and axillary panicles. Anthers dehisce between 10.30 and noon, 9-10 hours after anthesis. Stigmas were receptive at the time of anther dehiscence and remained receptive for two days. The flowers contain sucrose-rich nectar and emit a mild scent to attract visitors, including Musca domestica, Apis cerena indica, and black ants. None of these visitors appeared to be an effective pollinator. The results of pollination trials showed that the species outcrosses with low levels of selfing. Cross-pollinated flowers had a higher percentage of fruit sets (74.4%) compared to self-pollinated (43.4%) and open (3%). The index of self-incompatibility (ISI) indicates partial self-incompatibility. Due to the probable loss of pollinators or the lack of efficient pollinators, the natural population of B. lanzan has not yet been restored. To achieve the required fruit or seed set cross-pollination facilitated by humans would be a feasible technique. Therefore, to prevent the extinction of this species, human management is required in terms of cross-pollination. As a result, the scientific knowledge produced by the current study may prove helpful in various breeding initiatives and the preservation of this medicinal plant species. Further, this knowledge forms the basis for taking measures for the conservation and management of forests.

author: Bhatta, M. and Thapa, R.B. and Pokharel, M.R. and Sharma, M.D.
title: Biorational management of red ant (Dorylus orientalis Westwood) of potato in Taplejung, Nepal
abstract: *[Several management approaches against Red ant (Dorylus orientalis Westwood) were studied in Fungling VDC-4 of Taplejung district, Nepal in 2012.  Field efficacy of botanicals (Azadirachta; Agave, Artemisa, Eupatorium, & Justicia) @ 1.44 kg/plot & chemical chlorpyrifos (pyrifos 20 EC @ 2 ml/litre of water) as treatments with 4 replications were tested using the susceptible variety, Kufri Jyoti.  The application of agave was effective to reduce the damage by 42.93 +- 1.20% as compared to control i.e. 68.39+-0.62%.  Among all the treatments, the application of chlorpyrifos gave lower mean yield damage than the control plot.]

author: Bhattacharya, A.
title: Flower visitors and fruitset of Anacardium occidentale
abstract: *[The flower visitors, pollination, & fruitset of cashew (Anacardium occidentale) were studied.  The investigation involved monitoring of flower visitors, assessment of floral rewards for pollinators, & breeding experiments to establish the role of flower visitors on fruitset.  Yield of fruits has been low due to the lack of appropriate pollinators & the possible role of ants in pollen damage.  Bees, flies, butterflies, beetles, & ants visited the flowers.  Relative abundance of visitors coincided with nectar availability.  Breeding manipulation by bagging experiments indicated that bees are efficient pollinators increasing fruitset, while ants decreased fruitset by damaging the viable pollen.]          *[No ant species identified]

title: Management of red ant, Dorylus orientalis (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) in potato
note: Part of FORMIS 23; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: Among eight treatments, soil drenching with chlorpyriphos 20 EC @ 0.06 per cent was best recording lowest per cent tuber damage (6.81 & 7.28 per cent based on weight and number basis respectively) and highest tuber yield (123.38 q/ha), followed by the application of banana trap @ 350-400 numbers/ha mixed with malathion 5 per cent dust recording 8.68 and 8.94 per cent a tuber infestation both on weight and number basis respectively with tuber yield of 119.33 q/ha. The highest benefit cost ratio (8.80) was obtained with soil drenched with chlorpyriphos 20 EC @ 0.06 per cent followed by banana trap @ 350-400 numbers/ha mixed with malathion 5 per cent dust (6.04).

author: Bhattacharyya, K. and Annagiri, S.
title: Characterization of nest architecture of an Indian ant Diacamma indicum (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
abstract: *[This study characterizes nest architecture of a tropical ponerine ant Diacamma indicum, which has small colony sizes & is a scavenger.  We also examined if these nests vary seasonally.  By examining the microhabitat in the vicinity of the nest, the nest entrance characteristics, & casting 77 natural nests across a year, we found that this species occupies relatively simple nests consisting of a single entrance that leads to a single chamber.  This chamber progressed to a secondary tunnel that terminated at a greater depth than the chamber.  The nest volume was not correlated with the number of adult members in the colony.  Even though the microhabitat around the nest & the entrance itself change across seasons, principle component analysis showed that the nest architecture remained similar.  Only one parameter, the entrance tunnel showed significant difference & was longer during postmonsoon.  Nests of colonies living in the immediate vicinity of human habitation were comparable to other nests.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Diacamma indicum; Ponerinae; Asia; India; scientific; colony size; nests; nest architecture; season; habitat; nest casts; aluminium casts; wax casts;

author: Bhattacharyya, K. and Kolay, S. and Annagiri, S.
title: The structure and importance of nest mounds in a tropical ant Diacamma indicum
note: Part of FORMIS 22; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: 1. Nest mounds are an integral part of many subterranean insect species, and they aid in thermoregulation, gaseous exchange, and flood prevention. Ants living in subterranean nests are prone to nest flooding particularly during monsoons and this will impact the colonies' fitness. 2. Diacamma indicum is a tropical Ponerine ant species that lives in simple, singlechambered nests with a single entrance. In this study, we characterised the mound architecture and performed field experiments to check functional significance of mounds. 3. On examining mound architecture (n = 19 nests), we found that mounds not only elevated the nest entrance by 3.39	cm on average, but they also made the entrance at the top of the mound significantly smaller than the nest entrance at the base of the mound. Both these features are likely to reduce rainwater from falling directly into the nest's entrance tunnel. 4. Upon performing partial (n = 18 nests) and complete destruction (n = 20 nests) in two different seasons, colonies were observed to actively rebuilt mounds to predestruction levels within 3	days in all cases. 5. Furthermore, examining the amount of water that entered the nest upon flooding in the presence and absence of mounds (n = 18 colonies) revealed that mounds prevented a minimum of 29.2% of water from seeping into the nest from the surrounding area, as mounds could act as a levee. This study highlights the active architectural adaptations to flooding by an organism that dwells in subterranean nests in a tropical habitat.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Diacamma indicum; Ponerinae; Asia; India; scientific; nests; nest architecture; nest flooding; flood control; gas exchange; habitats; rain; thermoregulation; Monsoon adaptations;

author: Bhoje, P.M and Kurane, S. and Sathe, T.V.
title: Diversity of ants (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from Kolhapur district of Maharashtra, India
note: Part of FORMIS 23; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[In all, 36 species of ants belonging to the genera Camponotus, Crematogaster, Dolichoderus, Dorylus, Formica, Monomorium, Myrmica, Oecophylla, Pheidole, & Solenopsis have been reported from Kolhapur district.  Their seasonal abundance & distribution are discussed in this paper.]

title: Biodiversity of ants (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) of Amba Reserve Forest of Western Ghats, Maharashtra
note: Part of FORMIS 18; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[We collected 65 species of ants, in 35 genera in 8 subfamilies.  The subfamily with the most species was Myrmicinae (26 species) followed by Formiciniae (16 species), Ponerinae (11 species), Pseudomyrmecinae (4 species), Dolichoderinae (3 species), Cerpachyinae, Aenictinae (2 species each), & Dorylinae (1 species).]          NOTE: numerous misspelled genera; species, & subfamily names. author: Bhosle, P.K. and Rankhamb, S.V.
title: Distribution and diversity of ant species (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) in Sonpeth Tehsil dist. Parbhani of (M.S.) India
journal: New Man Int. J. Multidiscipl. Stud.
abstract: *[The study explored the distribution from various localities in & around Sonpeth town, within 3 km of the bus stand of Sonpeth.  Three ecological habitats, river side, farms, & human habitat were chosen for sampling.   In this area, 34 species of ants in 19 genera & 5 subfamilies; Dolichoderinae, Formicinae, Myrmicinae, Ponerinae, & Pseudomyrmecinae.  The dominant genus was Crematogaster followed by Pheidole & Camponotus.  Among these 3 habitats, the similarity index of ant species between farms & human habitat was the highest.  The indices of dominance in farms & human habitat indicate that the genus Crematogaster is most adapted genera in farms & human habitat.]          *[Camponotus parius misspelled Camponotus paria or Camponotus pariya; Leptogenys (lobopelta) misspelled Leptogenys (labopelta); Polyrhachis rastellata misspelled Polyrchis rastrella; Tetramorium obesum AndrÈ 1887 misspelled Triglyphothtrix Obes (Andrye 1887); Pseudomyrmecinae misspelled Pseudomyrmicinae.  Uses the obsolete names Triglyphothtrix (since 1985) & Tetramorium guineese (Fabricus, 1793) has been in Pheidole since 1977 (meaning this Tetramorium is unidentified).  Camponotus taylori Forel, 1892 incorrectly listed as Camponotus taylori (Forel).  Crematogaster brunnea contemta Mayr 1879 incorrectly listed as Crematogaster brunnea contemta (Forel, 1902).   Crematogaster rothneyi Mayr, 1879 incorrectly listed as Crematogaster rothneyi (Mayr, 1878).  Crematogaster rogenhoferi Mayr, 1879 incorrectly listed as Crematogaster rogenhoferi (Mayr, 1878). Smith 1857) incorrectly listed as Leptogenys (labopelta) diminuta (Fred. Smith 1858).  All species authors incorrectly given in (); this is incorrect for some species.]

author: Bhowate, S. and Kumar, P.
title: Ethnoentomological practices by tribes and rurals of Satpura plateau of Madhya Pradesh, India
abstract: *[This paper focuses on the use of insects & their products in traditional healing practices & in food by the rural populations & tribes of Satpura plateau, India.  The ethnoentomological study was carried out from June 2017 to December 2018, in tribal areas of Satpura plateau.  Ten different species of insects are used in curing 16 ailments.  Tribals use mashed up live Oecophylla smaragdina ants as food in their diet, when availabile.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Oecophylla smaragdina; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; entomophagy; human food; cooking; cuisine;

author: Biawa-Kagmegni, M. and Foguieng-Saha, A.D. and Guetsop-Ngouadjie, R.P. and Tsekane, S., Jr. and Fouelifack-Nintidem, B. and Moumite, M.B. and Yetchom-Fondjo, J.A. and Ngamaleu-Siewe, B. and Kenne, E.L. and Tuekam Kowa, P.S. and Fantio, R.M. and Yomon, A.K. and Mbenoun Masse, P.S. and Kenne, M. and Fomena, A.
title: Ants community structure in the urban and the city suburbs areas of Douala (Littoral-Cameroon)
note: Part of FORMIS 22; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[We hypothesized that environmental perturbations around Douala have repercussions on the native litter-dwelling ants.  Collections conducted in 33 houses, six gardens of 225 m2 each, 41 plantations of one hectare each, & 34 2-year old fallows of one hectare each suggested lowly even communities, low species richness, low diversity, & low dominance by a few species.  Among 28 species recorded, 5 species were most common: 2 foreign origin species [S. geminata (Fabricius, 1804) & Trichomyrmex destructor (Jerdon, 1851), from tropical America & India respectively], one native species [Pheidole megacephala (Fabricius, 1793)] & 2 ambiguous native range species [Paratrechina longicornis (Latreille, 1802) & Tapinoma melanocephalum (Fabricius, 1793)] (since they have long been recorded as having a widespread distribution).  Alien species were more highly represented than native ones (52.9% & 47.1% respectively).  Inside houses, gardens, & plantations, the ant species were distributed according to the geometrical progression (Motomura's model), while in the old fallows, abundance distribution suggested an evolved ecosystem (Mandelbrot's model).  Between the 3 dominant species, Pa. longicornis, Ph. megacephala, & S. geminata, the first species was positively correlated with the third one ,while other associations were not significant.  These dominant species appeared to be influencing the abundance of the rare species.  Dominance & high abundance of a few species indicated, that areas were influenced mostly by interspecies competition and/or disturbance by human activities.]          *[Anochetus katonae & Odontomachus troglodytes incorrectly listed in Formicinae; they are Ponerinae.]

author: {BÌl˝, S. and Fik·
title: First record of myrmecophily in buprestid beetles: immature stages of Habroloma myrmecophila sp. nov. (Coleoptera: Buprestidae) associated with Oecophylla ants (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
abstract: *[The association of Habroloma myrmecophila sp.nov. (Coleoptera: Buprestidae: Trachydini) with Oecophylla smaragdina (Fabricius, 1775) ants has been observed on secondary shrubs in Goa Province, India.  After mating, adult beetles were found to invade damaged or newly constructed Oecophylla nests to lay eggs.  Larvae mine in the leaves forming the nest wall & pupate within the mines.  Only adult beetles interact directly with ants, potentially triggering their necrophoric behavior when caught.  The adults & larvae of the beetles are described in detail & the benefits of the ant association for the beetles are hypothesized.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Oecophylla smaragdina; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; nest; behavior; symbiont; myrmecophile; parasite; Coleoptera; Buprestidae; Habroloma myrmecophila;

author: Bingham, C.T.
title: The fauna of British India, including Ceylon and Burma. Hymenoptera, Butterflies 2
abstract: *[The Indian Lycaenid, Allotinus horsfieldi attends aphids in the butterfly stage, stroking them with its long fore-legs & sucking up the excreted honey-dew with its proboscis.]          *[Camponotus compressus tends Catochrysops cnejus & Chilades laius.  Camponotus mitis tends Lampides celeno race kinkurka.  Camponotus compressus & Pheidole latinoda tend Tarucus theophrastus.  Camponotus compressus, Prenolepis obscura, & Tapinoma melanocephalum tend Polyommatus boeticus.  Pheidole quadrispinosa tends Chilades trochilus.  Prenolepis (Nylanderia) longicornis, Crematogaster, & Monomorium speculare tend Catochrysops pandava.  Oecophylla smaragdina tends Liphyra brassolis.]

author: Bingqian, N. and Ali Shah, A. and Matra, M. and Wanapat, M. and Ullah Khan, R. and Ahmad, S. and Ullah, S. and Shuaib Khan, M. and Kamal Shah, M.
title: Insect bioactive compounds and their potential use in animal diets and medicine
note: Part of FORMIS 24; from NAL's AGRICOLA; Part of the Leaf-Cutting Ant Bibliography; from-DPW,
abstract: This study examined the effects of various insect species, such as those of Bombyx mori, Hermetia illucens and Tenebrio monitor, that have long been used in combination with medicinal plants and are an important alternative to modern medicine in many parts of the world. The current use of traditional pesticides from around the year 2010 and the characteristics of isolated biologically active molecules are also presented. Natural insect products were examined or isolated from ants, bees, beetles, cockroaches, termites, bees, etc. The biological activities of these natural products derived from insects include antimicrobial, antifungal, anticancer, antiviral, antioxidant and antiinflammatory effects. Insect additives to animal feed rarely distort the relevant physicochemical variables or sensory profile of the meat, whereas the fatty acid (FA) profile is discernibly changed. In fact, insect derivatives have great potential for future drug discovery in natural products, as well as for the production of nutritious foods for humans and for animals. It is concluded that the inoculation of insect powder in animal feeds results in the prevention and treatment of disease, enhances the growth of animals and promotes the bioactive compounds in animalbased products. Owing to the sustainability of their breeding, largescale cultures of these insects seem economically viable. Insect oil and protein as well as chitin ingredients are widely used in cosmetics, and these substances are considered highvalue coproducts. The major challenges associated with their use will be linked to the development of methods for separating industrialderived materials.

author: Blaimer, B.B.
title: Acrobat ants go global - Origin, evolution and systematics of the genus Crematogaster (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
note: Part of FORMIS 14; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: This study unravels the evolution and biogeographic history of the globally distributed ant genus Crematogaster on the basis of a molecular phylogeny, reconstructed from five nuclear protein-coding genes and a total of 3384 bp of sequence data. A particular emphasis is placed on the evolutionary history of these ants in the Malagasy region. Bayesian and likelihood analyses performed on a dataset of 124 Crematogaster ingroup taxa lend strong support for three deeply diverging phylogenetic lineages within the genus: the Orthocrema clade, the Global Crematogaster clade and the Australo-Asian Crematogaster clade. The 15 previous subgenera within Crematogaster are mostly not monophyletic. Divergence dating analyses and ancestral range reconstructions suggest that Crematogaster evolved in South-East Asia in the mid-Eocene (40-45 ma). The three major lineages also originated in this region in the late Oligocene/early Miocene (~24-30 ma). A first dispersal out of S-E Asia by an Orthocrema lineage is supported for 22-30 ma to the Afrotropical region. Successive dispersal events out of S-E Asia began in the early, and continued throughout the late Miocene. The global distribution of Crematogaster was achieved by subsequent colonizations of all major biogeographic regions by the Orthocrema and the Global Crematogaster clade. Molecular dating estimates and ancestral range evolution are discussed in the light of palaeogeographic changes in the S-E Asian region and an evolving ocean circulation system throughout the Eocene, Oligocene and Miocene. Eight dispersal events to/from Madagascar by Crematogaster are supported, with most events occurring in the late Miocene to Pliocene (5.0-9.5 ma). These results suggest that Crematogaster ants possess exceptional dispersal and colonization abilities, and emphasize the need for detailed investigations of traits that have contributed to the global evolutionary success of these ants.

author: Blumenfeld, A.J. and Eyer, P.A. and Helms, A.M. and Buczkowski, G. and Vargo, E.L.
title: Consistent signatures of urban adaptation in a native, urban invader ant Tapinoma sessile
note: Part of FORMIS 23; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Biological invasions are becoming more prevalent due to the rise of global trade and expansion of urban areas. Ants are among the most prolific invaders with many exhibiting a multiqueen colony structure, dependent colony foundation and reduced internest aggression. Although these characteristics are generally associated with the invasions of exotic ants, they may also facilitate the spread of native ants into novel habitats. Native to diverse habitats across North America, the odorous house ant Tapinoma sessile has become abundant in urban environments throughout the United States. Natural colonies typically have a small workforce, inhabit a single nest, and are headed by a single queen, whereas urban colonies tend to be several orders of magnitude larger, inhabit multiple nests (i.e., polydomy) and are headed by multiple queens (i.e., polygyny). Here, we explore and compare the population genetic and breeding structure of T. sessile within and between urban and natural environments in several localities across its distribution range. We found the social structure of a colony to be a plastic trait in both habitats, although extreme polygyny was confined to urban habitats. Additionally, polydomous colonies were only present in urban habitats, suggesting T. sessile can only achieve supercoloniality within urbanized areas. Finally, we identified strong differentiation between urban and natural populations in each locality and continentwide, indicating cities may restrict gene flow and exert intense selection pressure. Overall, our study highlights urbanization's influence in charting the evolutionary course for species.
