author: Morrison, H.
title: On some trophobiotic Coccidae from British Guiana
abstract: Representatives of all of the species of Coccidae discussed in the following pages were collected by Dr. W.M. Wheeler of Bussey Institution, Harvard University, in the course of his investigations at the Tropical Research Station of the New York Zoological Society in British Guiana and were recently submitted to the writer for  determination.  Critical study of the material available for examination in the National Collection of Coccidae has shown that two of these species have also been collected in certain of the West Indian islands by the writer and others, and this opportunity has been taken to add these records to those from British  Guiana.   (This article was written and prepared by U.S. Government employee(s) on official time, and is therefore in the public domain.)

author: Morrison, L.W.
title: The ecology of ants (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) on islands
abstract: *[Species may reach oceanic islands by 3 mechanisms: (1) mating flights of reproductives, (2) rafting, and (3) human-assisted dispersal.  Past land bridge connections may be important for continental shelf islands.  Patterns of species accumulation may be similar even when primary mechanisms of dispersal differ.  Colonizing propagules are limited primarily by the presence of suitable habitat & interspecific competition or predation from other ants.  Although island area is usually a significant predictor of species richness, the diversity of habitat types is often a better predictor.  Distance, or isolation, has often been found to be only a weak predictor of ant species richness, probably because many islands that have been studied are not very distant relative to most species' dispersal abilities.  Interspecific competition appears to result in mutually exclusive distributions within islands for some of the more aggressive species, although the effects of habitat affinities have not been well studied.  With the exception of very small islands, competition does not appear to result in exclusions of species from entire islands, & robust patterns of nestedness have been observed.  Populations go extinct from & immigrate to small islands in ecological time, although such turnover appears to be relatively low compared with other arthropods.  Only a few archipelagoes, however, have been the focus of turnover studies.  Some species may reach extremely high population abundances on islands, but subsequently decline.  The exact mechanisms underlying these population fluctuations are not known with certainty, although the presence of honeydew-producing insects has often been associated with the most dramatic cases.  Endemicity varies greatly and ranges from 0 to > 96%, peaking at intermediate distances in the Pacific & reaching the highest levels on islands in the Indian Ocean.  Anthropogenic disturbances appear to present the greatest driver of change to insular ant communities & result in increasing numbers & abundances of exotic ant species, which may have deleterious effects on the rest of the community.]

author: Moser, D. and Lenzer, B. and Weigelt, P. and Dawson, W. and Kreft, H. and Pergl, J. and Pyaek, P. and van Kleunen, M. and Winter, M. and Capinha, C. and Cassey, P. and Dullinger, S. and Economo, E.P. and GarcÌa-DÌaz, P. and GuÈnard, B. and Hofhansl, F. and Mang, T. and Seebens, H. and Essl, F.
title: Remoteness promotes biological invasions on islands worldwide
abstract: *[We analyzed a large dataset for alien & native plants, ants, reptiles, mammals, & birds on 257 (sub) tropical islands, & showed that, except for birds, the number of naturalized alien species increases with isolation for all taxa, a pattern that is opposite to the negative species-isolation relationship of native species.  We argue that the reversal of the species-isolation relationship for alien species is driven by an increase in island invasibility due to reduced diversity & increased ecological naivetÈ of native biota on the more remote islands.]

author: Mott, R. and Hodgson, J.C. and Herrod, A. and Clarke, R.H.
title: Nest-site fidelity in Red-tailed Tropicbirds informs costing a localised ant baiting strategy at Ashmore Reef
note: Part of FORMIS 21; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: In many animal species, individuals re-use the breeding site they used in the previous breeding season. Consequently, they accrue benefits including reduced time searching for a territory, and enhanced predator avoidance. Many seabirds display high levels of nest-site fidelity. We sought to determine whether nest-site fidelity occurs in Red-tailed Tropicbirds (Phaethon rubricauda) breeding at Ashmore Reef (eastern Indian Ocean) by recording the nest location of individually-marked birds across three years (20122014). We found that Red-tailed Tropicbirds at this surface-nesting colony were highly faithful to their previous nest-site, with a median distance between successive nests of just 13.4 m. By using digitised vegetation maps for Ashmore Reef, we provide quantitative evidence that Red-tailed Tropicbird nest-site fidelity is not driven by a lack of suitable vegetated sites. These findings have important management implications because breeding success at this small, regionally-significant Red-tailed Tropicbird colony is negatively affected by an invasive species, the tropical fire ant (Solenopsis geminata). Using localised ant baiting around known Red-tailed Tropicbird nest-sites may confer benefits on current and future tropicbird breeding attempts. We estimated the financial cost per treatment to bait the 0.85 ha within 13.4 m of known Red-tailed Tropicbird nest-sites, an area expected to encompass half of all subsequent breeding attempts, to be low. This represents a cost-effective interim management strategy prior to any island-wide eradication programme. Therefore, we recommend localised ant baiting around tropicbird nests within an adaptive management framework such that optimum baiting parameters can be resolved (e.g., baiting frequency, most effective baiting radius).
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Solenopsis geminata; Myrmicinae; Oceania; Ashmore Reef; Indian Ocean; scientific; impact; ecological; wildlife; Aves; bird; Red-tailed Tropicbirds; Phaethon rubricauda; site faithfulness; nesting sites; bird nests; predator avoidance; vegetation; chemical control; invasive invertebrate control; cost effectiveness; invasive species management; island conservation; adaptive management; invasive species;

author: Mozhui, L. and Kakati, L.N. and Changkija, S.
title: A study on the use of insects as food in seven tribal communities in Nagaland, Northeast India
abstract: *[This paper documents the use of insect as food among 7 tribal communities of Nagaland.  Information was obtained through personal field interviews with 240 informants with the help of semi-structured questionnaires.  It was found that 82 species of insects belonging to 9 orders (Odonata, Orthoptera, Mantodea, Isoptera, Hemiptera, Coleoptera, Hymenoptera, Lepidoptera, Diptera) are an important traditional food item principally consumed by the tribal people.  Insects are preferred as eggs, larvae, nymphs, pupa, or adult which are cooked, roasted, or consumed raw.]          *[All stages of weaver ants are consumed, from May to July.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Oecophylla smaragdina; Formicinae; Asia; India; Nagaland; scientific; entomophagy; food security; tribal communities; use value; utilization; weaver ant;

author: Mozhui, L. and Kakati, L.N. and Kiewhuo, P. and Changkija, S.
title: Traditional knowledge of the utilization of edible insects in Nagaland, North-East India
abstract: *[This study documents the existing knowledge of entomophagy in the region, emphasizing the currently most consumed insects in view of their marketing potential as possible future food items.  Assessment was done with the help of semi-structured questionnaires, which mentioned a total of 106 insect species representing 32 families & 9 orders that were considered as health foods by the local ethnic groups.  While most of the edible insects are consumed boiled, cooked, fried, roasted/toasted, some insects such as Cossus sp., larvae & pupae of ants, bees, wasps, & hornets as well as honey, bee comb, bee wax are consumed raw.]          *[ The weaver ant, Oecophylla smaragdina is considered as an important food item by all members of the Naga tribes.  While, the immature stages (eggs, larvae, & pupa) of the ant are boiled or cooked (with local spices) for consumption, the adult ants are prepared as chutney in a mixture of chilly, salt, & dry fish is ground to powdered form & are also preserved for longer use.]

author: Mukherjee, A. and Roy, U.S.
title: Role of physicochemical parameters on diversity and abundance of ground-dwelling, diurnal ant species of Durgapur Government College Campus, West Bengal, India
note: Part of FORMIS 21; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: *[The present study was conducted to discern the diurnal, ground dwelling ant species from Durgapur Government College Campus, West Bengal, India.  Seven different physicochemical parameters were analyzed to comment on the possible influence of these parameters on the occurrence pattern, abundance, & niche breadth of the ant species.  Pitfall traps were used to collect 31 ant species in 18 genera & 5 subfamilies within a study span of 3 months (April-June).  The most diverse ant subfamily recorded in this study was Myrmicinae (47% species) followed by Formicinae (28% species).  The most diverse genus was Camponotus (6 species) followed by the genera Crematogaster (4 species) & Monomorium (3 species).  Camponotus compressus (Fabricius) was recorded as the most abundant ant species, followed by Monomorium pharaonis (Linnaeus).  Positive correlations were found between ant diversity & ambient relative humidity, soil moisture, soil conductivity, & soil organic carbon, whereas negative correlations were noted between ant diversity & ambient temperature, solar irradiance, & pH.  These findings were verified with one-way ANOVA, Cluster analysis, & CCA plot.  Pseudoneoponera rufipes (Jerdon) followed by Tetraponera rufonigra (Jerdon) & Camponotus compressus occupied the maximum niche breadth reflecting their adaptability to forage in a larger area from the present study location.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Anoplolepis gracilipes; Camponotus compressus; Camponotus dolendus; Camponotus irritans; Camponotus invidus; Camponotus rufoglaucus; Camponotus sericeus; Carebara diversa; Carebara lignata; Cardiocondyla nuda; Crematogaster aberrans; Crematogaster rogenhoferi; Crematogaster rothneyi; Crematogaster subnuda; Diacamma rugosum; Diacamma rugosum sculptum; Monomorium floricola; Monomorium latinode; Monomorium pharaonis; Oecophylla smaragdina; Paratrechina longicornis; Pheidole roberti; Pheidole sharpi; Platythyrea parallela; Pseudoneoponera rufipes; Solenopsis geminata; Tapinoma melanocephalum; Technomyrmex albipes; Tetramorium walshi; Tetraponera allaborans; Tetraponera rufonigra; Trichomyrmex destructor; Dolichoderinae Formicinae; Myrmicinae; Ponerinae; Pseudomyrmecinae; Asia; India; scientific; community; distribution; diversity; diversity indices; occurrence pattern; abundance; niche breadth; habitat selection; urban; physicochemical parameters; relative humidity; soil moisture; soil conductivity; soil organic carbon; temperature; solar irradiance; pH; pitfall traps;

author: Mukherjee, I. and Das, S. and Paul, B. and Annagiri, S.
title: The impact of prior and current information of a new nest on relocation dynamics in an Indian ant
note: Part of FORMIS 24; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Animals are known to acquire and store information of their environment in order to enhance their performance in different tasks like foraging, migration and breeding. Having information regarding nesting sites would be particularly useful when they have to relocate. In the current study, we asked if having information of a new nest prior to or at the onset of relocation has a positive impact on the ability of ant colonies to relocate. We performed five sets of experiments on a ponerine ant species Diacamma indicum that recruits nestmates solely by tandem running. By analyzing data of 4756 unique ants across 61 colonies, we found that, access to information of the new nest for 1 day prior to the relocation did not give any significant advantage as compared to no prior information of the new nest. However, access to information for 7	days prior to relocation resulted in 50% increase in the number of tandem leaders and reduction of the transport time by an average of 49%. Our data on providing information at the onset of relocation indicates that introducing explorers to the new nest did not aid the process of relocation but when information of a new nest was selfacquired, there was a reduction in discovery time by 50% and also in the transport time per unit distance for relocation into a new nest. Having information regarding only the surroundings and not the nest at the onset of a relocation did not give any significant advantages. Further, the manner in which work was organized during the relocation process was not significantly influenced by prior information across any of the treatments. Our findings suggest that information of new nest is important and when such information is selfacquired at the onset of relocation or is available for a long enough duration, it has a positive influence in the process of relocation in this ant species.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Diacamma indicum; Ponerinae; Asia; India; scientific; colony relocation; nests; nesting sites; behavior; tandem running; navigation; recruitment; decision making; latent learning; prior information; current information;

author: Mukhopadhyay, A. and Quader, S.
title: Ants on Clerodendrum infortunatum: Disentangling effects of larceny and herbivory
note: Part of FORMIS 21; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Nectar larcenists extract nectar from flowers without pollinating them. A reasonable expectation is that any form of nectar larceny should have a detrimental effect on the plants reproductive success. However, studies reveal an entire range of effects, from highly negative to highly positive. This variation in effect may be partly explained by additional, unmeasured, effects of nectar larcenists on plants. In a study system where two ant species Tapinoma melanocephalum (Fabr.) (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) and Trichomyrmex destructor (Jerd.) (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) act as nectar larcenists, we examined the effect of larceny on the female reproductive success of Clerodendrum infortunatum Gaertn. (Lamiales: Lamiaceae) in rain forest fragments of the Western Ghats, India. This was done through a combination of field observations and a series of field experiments looking at the effects of excluding ants from inflorescences. We found that T. destructor reduces fruit set considerably. Rather than this being a consequence of nectar larceny, however, our experiments show that the negative effect arises instead from the herbivorous behavior of the ant. At a population level, both ant species prefer edges over interiors of forest patches, spatially concentrating the interaction zone to forest edges. Simultaneously considering multiple ecological interactions and disentangling their relative contributions might explain the large variation across species in the observed effect of larceny. The overall population effect of nectar larceny and herbivory is likely to depend on the spatial structuring of plants and ants.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Tapinoma melanocephalum; Trichomyrmex destructor; Dolichoderinae; Myrmicinae; Asia; India; scientific; ecological competition; edge effects; habitat; rain forests; habitat fragmentation; behavior; nectar thievery; nectar; ant-plant interactions; Lamiales; Lamiaceae; Clerodendrum infortunatum; reproductive success; females; flowers; fruit set;

author: Mukhopadhyay, S. and Annagiri, S.
title: Importance of vision in tandem running during colony relocation in an Indian ant
note: Part of FORMIS 22; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Visual inputs are important for navigation, and several studies have investigated its importance in ants in the context of foraging. Little is known about the importance of visual cues when the whole colony engages in the goaloriented task of colony relocation. In this study, we investigated the role of vision for a tandemrunning tropical ant Diacamma indicum during colony relocation by impairing the vision in both eyes of all colony members and comparing our findings with ants having unimpaired vision. Colonies relocated successfully under zerolux conditions and when all colony mates were visually impaired, without compromising their colony cohesion. On examining 265 tandem runs performed by visually impaired ants, we found that they had lower efficiency as compared to ants with normal vision. They traveled along longer routes at lower speeds and often lost their followers, leading to significant increase in transportation time. The absence of visual inputs did not influence the number of tandem leaders that participated nor did it negatively impact their ability to recruit their visually impaired followers from becoming tandem leaders. Visually impaired tandem leaders were not able to minimize their relocation path in an open arena but were capable of doing so in defined paths. Our results suggest that these ants use thigmotactic or proprioceptive cues in order to navigate to their new nest in the absence of visual inputs. Our understanding of tandemrunning recruitment would be incomplete until we delineate the role of multiple sensory inputs involved in conducting this mode of recruitment successfully.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Diacamma indicum; Ponerinae; Asia; India; scientific; colony relocation; vision; vision disorders; visually impaired; nests; behavior; cohesion; tandem running; navigation; recruitment; visual inputs; thigmotaxis; thigmotactic cues; proprioceptive cues;

author: Mukhopadhyay, S. and Pathak, M.K. and Annagiri, S.
title: Path minimization in a tandem running Indian ant in the context of colony relocation
abstract: *[In this study, we investigated whether ants that use only tandem running to recruit their nestmates can minimize their path, while relocating their entire colony into a new nest.  As colony relocation directly impacts the survival of the whole colony, it would be particularly important to optimize their path to the new nest.  Using the ponerine ant Diacamma indicum, we conducted relocation experiments, in which ants had to choose between different defined paths, & contrasted our findings with open arena experiments, as they navigated to their new nest.  After following 4100 unique transports by 450 different transporters, we found that these ants do minimize their path.  Individual leaders, as well as colonies, chose the shorter path significantly more than the longer path, & they showed a significant preference for the shorter arm at multiple decision points on encountering a combination of paths.  Thus, we concluded that tandem leaders are capable of path minimization based on the information they themselves collect.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Diacamma indicum; Ponerinae; Asia; India; scientific; workers; colonies; nests; behavior; navigation; path minimization; tandem running; colony relocation; non-trail laying ants; ant colony optimization;

author: Muniaraj, M. and Rajamannar, V. and Venkatesh, A. and Leo, S.V.J. and Venkatasubramani, K. and Paramasivan, R. and Kumar, A.
title: Predation of Aedes aegypti eggs by foraging ants Solenopsis invicta, Myrmicaria brunnea, Diacamma rugosum, and Monomorium minimum
note: Part of FORMIS 24; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[We have observed the predatory potential of ants on Aedes eggs in urban breeding habitats, & their impact on Aedes mosquito breeding was determined by a field experiment that mimicked the natural breeding habitats.  It was found that 99.4% of eggs were removed from the experimental containers by foraging ants in 4 days.  The present study demonstrates the role of ants as a natural regulator, limiting Aedes mosquito breeding.]          *[NOTE: These identifications need to be checked.  Monomorium minimum is a North American species.   All records of Solenopsis invicta from india are suspect & need verification, https://www.antwiki.org/wiki/Solenopsis_invicta  checked 3Nov 23.   Solenopsis invicta Buren was not described until 1972.  Therefore, the references ((Dunn 1926, Buxton & Hopkins 1927, James 1966) could not possible refer to Solenopsis invicta.  Solenopsis geminata is widespread in India, https://www.antwiki.org/wiki/Solenopsis_geminata  checked 3Nov 23.]

author: Muniz, V.I.M. de S. and Braga, P.E.T. and Alves, J.E.
title: FrequÍncia de coletores florais do Coqueiro (Cocos nucifera L.) no litoral do municÌpio de Acara˙ (Cear· - Brasil)
abstract: *[This study verified the relative frequency of insects that visited the flowers of Cocos nucifera, in Acara˙-CE.  The species frequency was determined by the percentage participation of the number of individuals in each family in relation to the total collected: f = (ni / N) x 100 where ni = number of species / family & N = total number of species (n = 101).  We found 101 specimens that were identified, belonging to 4 Orders.  Among the visiting Hymenoptera, the most frequent bees were Apis mellifera, Trigona spinipes, & Plebeia minima (61.45% of the frequency), followed by the ant Camponotus compressus F. (6.93%).  Other visitors found included 5 species of flies (Diptera), 3 species of beetles (Coleoptera) & one species of earwig (Dermaptera).]          *[NOTE: this identification needs to be confirmed: Camponotus compressus is a ground-nesting species of ant found in India & Southeast Asia]

author: Munj, A.Y. and Zote, V.K. and Raut, R.A. and Salvi, B.R.
title: Survey and surveillance of pollinators of mango in South Konkan coastal region of Maharashtra
abstract: *[This study was conducted to record the major pollinators of mango in South Konkan coastal region of Maharashtra during the flowering season of 2011 & 2012.  he results revealed that the stingless bee (Tetragonula sp.), blow fly (Chrysomya sp.), Indian honey bee (Apis indica Fab.), syrphid fly (Syrphus sp.), gaint honey bee (Apis dorsata Fab.), wasp (Vespula orientalis Lin.), house fly (Musca sp.), red ant (Oecophylla smaragdina Fab.), black ant (unidentified), & lady beetle (Cheilomenes sexmaculata Fab.) were the important pollinators of mango in Konkan region.  The study on intensity of the major pollinators indicated that the intensity of stingless bee Tetragonula sp. was high (11.50/hour) followed by honey bee, Apis indica Fab. (6.40/panicle/hour), & blow fly, Chrysomya sp. (5.85/panicle/hour) during flowering period & the peak intensity of these pollinators was observed during 4th to 6th standard meteorological week.]

author: Mysore, K. and Shyamala, B.V. and Rodrigues, V.
title: Morphological and developmental analysis of peripheral antennal chemosensory sensilla and central olfactory glomeruli in worker castes of Camponotus compressus (Fabricius, 1787)
note: Part of FORMIS 10; from NAL'S AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: The antennal lobes of different castes of the ant species Camponotus compressus show a marked diversity in the organization of their olfactory glomeruli. Notably, there is a significant difference in the number and size of glomeruli between the reproductives and the workers and among the different worker castes. In this report, we investigate the notion that these caste-specific differences in glomerular number might be accounted for, at least in part, by the differences in numbers of olfactory sensilla that target the antennal lobe. For this, we examine the number of sensilla on the antennal flagella of all the individual castes of C. compressus. This analysis reveals a striking correlation between sensillar number and the number of antennal glomeruli in a given caste. As a first step in investigating the causal mechanisms that might give raise to this correlation, we carry out an initial characterization of olfactory system development in the minor workers of C. compressus. We analyze the temporal pattern of innervations of the developing antennal lobe by olfactory sensory neuron axons. We document the development of the olfactory glomeruli in the antennal lobe during this process, which occurs during early pupal stages. Our findings provide the basis for future manipulative developmental studies on the role of sensory afferent number in glomerular development of different castes within the same species.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Camponotus compressus; Camponotus sericeus; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; workers; reproductives; caste; morphology; nervous system; olfactory organs; antennae; sensilla; chemoreceptors; antennal lobe; axons; sensory neurons; pupal development; morphogenesis; innervation; worker; caste determination; antennal lobe glomeruli;

author: Mysore, K. and Subramanian, K.A. and Sarasij, R.C. and Suresh, A. and Shyamala, B.V. and VijayRaghavan, K. and Rodrigues, V.
title: Caste and sex specific olfactory glomerular organization and brain architecture in two sympatric ant species Camponotus sericeus and Camponotus compressus (Fabricius, 1798)
note: Part of FORMIS 10; from NAL'S AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: We use monoclonal antibodies against synaptic proteins and anterograde tracing with neurobiotin to describe the architecture of the antennal lobes in different castes of two ant species - Camponotus sericeus and Camponotus compressus. The reproductives and worker classes are readily categorized based on size and external morphology. The overall organization of brain neuropile is comparable between castes with differences only in the visual ganglia. Males have a larger fraction of neuropile occupied by the medulla and lobula than females. In the diurnal species, C. sericeus these regions are more highly represented, than in the nocturnal species C. compressus. The most striking differences are in the antennal lobe where males possess a macroglomerulus, which is about ten times larger in volume than the other glomeruli; such a specialization is absent in females. Minor workers possess a significantly larger number of glomeruli than the majors despite the smaller overall volume of the lobe. These caste-specific differences occur mainly within glomerular clusters that receive input from sensory neurons that project in tracts - T4 and T5 - within the antennal nerve. The comparative anatomy of different castes of ants provides an entry point into a future systematic analysis of how divergent brain architectures can arise within a single species.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Camponotus compressus; Camponotus sericeus; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; workers; reproductives; females; males; caste; morphology; smell; brain; antennal lobe; morphometry; sensory neurons; peripheral nerves; neuropile; olfactory glomeruli; macroglomerulus; neuronal projections; antennal nerve; species differences; gender differences;

author: Nag, S. and Bhat, A.S.
title: A colony-level optimization model provides a potential mechanism for the evolution of novel castes in eusocial ant colonies
note: Part of FORMIS 23; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Ant species often have multiple morphologically distinct 'castes' within a single colony. Given that most of these castes are involved in non-reproductive tasks, and since such individuals thus never reproduce, the question of how ant castes can evolve is a non-trivial one. Over the years, several models have been proposed in order to explain the evolution of castes in ant colonies. Here, we attempt to answer this question using an economics-based approach, developing an optimization model that implements adaptation and selection at the colony level. We argue that due to the nature of ant colonies, selection is shifted to the group level, and, due to this, individual ants are sheltered from negative selection. We show that our framework can explain the evolution of novel castes in ant colonies, and discuss the novelty of our model with regard to previous models that have been proposed. We also show that our model is consistent with several empirical observations of ant colonies.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Asia; India; scientific; castes; caste ratio; colonies; adaptation; selection; optimization; evolution; group selection; models;

author: Nagel, P.
title: Ant nest beetles of the Carnegie Museum (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Paussinae, Paussini)
abstract: *[The species are mainly from Africa, with one each from the Middle East & India.  The collection consists of long series from different localities but is especially rich in specimens from Malawi with 8 species recorded from there for the first time.  The paper also presents first records for many other African countries.  In the framework of a revisionary treatment of the Paussus cucullatus Group sensu stricto, type material of Paussus semicucullatus Wasmann, Paussus pseudocucullatus Nagel, & Paussus conradti Kolbe were studied.  It is shown that Paussus elizabethae PÈringuey, 1897, is a valid species & not a synonym of P. conradti Kolbe, 1896.  Paussus phyllocerus Reichensperger, 1925, is recognized as a new synonym of Paussus excavatusWestwood, 1833.  Paussus buettikeri, n.sp., & Paussus rawlinsi, n.sp. from Malawi are described as new species.  One key each is provided for identification of species closely related to P. cucullatus Westwood & Paussus manicanus PÈringuey.   Pheidole punctulata major & minor worker mounted on pin with Paussus semicucullatus.  Some Paussus pseudocucullatus specimens collected with "ants".]

author: Nagulapalli, S.L. and Kunal, G. and Das, R. and Jha, S.
title: Insect pollinators and their abundance in West Bengal
abstract: *[This study undertook observations on the number of pollinators visiting the flowers/ m2 for 5 min at 10 randomly selected spots in the agroecosystems in West Bengal.  A total number of 55 individuals of insect pollinators belonging to 19 families & 4 orders were observed of which Hymenoptera were maximum (47.25%) followed by: Coleoptera (24.68%), Lepidoptera (11.26%), & Diptera (8.29%).  Simpson's index ranged from 0 to 1. & maximum species richness was found in Lower Bongbasti, Kalimpong (0.995), & the least at AB-Block farm BCKV Kalyani (0.751).  Among the surveyed areas, species evenness was found maximum in Khelia North 24 Parganas (1.34) & the least in Jhanti Pahari Bankura (0.14).  So far as pollinator species richness is concerned, it was maximum in hilly terrains of Kalimpong followed by North 24 Parganas, Bankura, & Nadia.]          *[Lasius niger was the predominant species with an population of 10 insects/ m2 representing 35.37% of all insects.  On ornamentals during the blooming period, L. niger was the most predominant (4.66 insects/ m2 & 25.50%).  Lasius niger was important in ecosystems: crop, weed, & ornamental ecosystems.  On the basis of insect visitors recorded/ m2, Oecophylla sp. were the most predominant (5 insects/ m2, 25.48%).  Oecophylla was important in the weed ecosystem.]

author: Naik, C.M. and Chakravarthy, A.K.
title: Sustainable management practices for tea mosquito bug Helopeltis antonii Signoret (Miridae: Hemiptera) on cashew
abstract: *[Studies on exploitation of natural enemies & their role in suppression of Tea mosquito bug Helopeltis antonii Signoret were carried out in the cashew plantations of Zonal Agricultural Research Station, Brahmavar & Pethri village, Udupi district & in maidan tracts of Chintamani, Karnataka during 2006-2008.  The ant, Oecophylla smaragdina Fabricius was the most effective predator against H. antonii.  Cashew trees fully colonized by O. smaragdina received the least H. antonii damage of 11.40+-1.87% & 8.71+-1.23% during 2006-08 in coastal & maidan Karnataka, respectively.  H. antonii damage colonized with O. smaragdina were 23.40+-2.16% in coastal & 20.12+-2.05% in maidan part.  The unsprayed cashew trees, with no ants, recorded maximum damage of 47.42+-3.71% & 52.36+-3.86% in coastal & maidan tracts, respectively.  Higher nut yield of 3.70 kg/tree in coastal & 2.43 kg/tree in maidan tract was recorded from the trees fully colonized with O. smaragdina.]

author: Nair, V.M.
title: The response behaviour of ant Pheidologeton diversus on encountering an obstacle along its trail
abstract: *[The response behavior of ant, Pheidologeton diversus was studied following interruption of the trail line with an elongate & a circular object across its path.  It was observed that ants could not continue to move along the trail line in case of both the obstructions causing chaos & crowding at the point of intersection with the object.  However, in the case of the linear object, they were found to rejoin the broken trail by creating 2 distinct paths, one parabolic, & another straighter one with a acute U turn along the object.  In both cases, the paths were created towards the shorter section of the obstacle.  In the case of the circular object, a semicircular path was formed along the circumference of the object.  There was no distinct bifurcation as in the case of the linear object.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Pheidologeton diversus; Myrmicinae; Asia; India; scientific; foraging; encountering obstacle; trail line; path selection; bifurcation;

author: Najar, I.A. and Bashir, A.
title: Insect diversity of Doodhpathri (Budgam), Jammu and Kashmir, India
abstract: *[The study reports on the insect diversity of Doodhpathri.  A total of 15 species were recorded belonging to 13 families & 7 orders.  Maximum number of species were recorded at site-II (12), followed by site-III (10), & least at site-I (8).  Significant variation in density of different species was recorded among the months at site-I (F5 = 10.92, P < 0.05), Site-II (F5 = 11.45, P < 0.05), & Site-III (F5 = 22.69, P < 0.05) & among the species at site-II (F11 = 6.17, P < 0.05), & site-III (F9 = 7.61, P < 0.05).]          *[Myrmica sp. collected at site-I & site-III.]

author: Nalini, T. and Ambika, S.
title: Studies on population dynamics of weaver ant, Oecophylla smaragdina Fabricius (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) nests in Prunus dulcis and Morinda citrifolia
abstract: *[A study was conducted to assess the population dynamics of Oecophylla smaragdina nests from the trees with ant nests in Prunus dulcis & Morinda citrifolia in Faculty of Agriculture, Annamalai University, Annamalainagar, Tamil Nadu at fortnightly intervals.  In Prunus dulcis, the highest number of green nests, dry nests, leaf pavilions were found in April, May, & March, respectively.  Total number of nests were highest during April, March, & May.  In Morinda citrifolia, the highest number of green nests & dry nests were found in July & October, respectively.  Leaf pavilions were highest in January.  The total number of nests were highest during October, April, & August.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Oecophylla smaragdina; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; nests; leaf nests; green nests; dry nests; leaf pavilions; season; population dynamics; Morinda citrifolia; Prunus dulcis;

author: Nalini, T. and Ambika, S.
title: Temporal variation of Oecophylla smaragdina Fabricius (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) nest density and nest longevity in different horticultural crops
editor: Devivasigamani, B. and Sundaresan, A.
abstract: *[A study was conducted to assess temporal variation of Oecophylla smaragdina nest density & nest longevity in the orchard & fields of Faculty of Agriculture, Annamalai University, Annamalainagar, Tamil Nadu, India.  Nest densities were monitored in 9 horticultural crops for the period of one year (March 2017 to February 2018) at fortnightly intervals.  The highest number of large nests was found during March, September, October & small nests during March, September, April, July, & October.  The highest number of large nests was recorded in Manikara zapota & Mangifera indica.  The highest number of small nests was found in Manikara zapota followed by Prunus dulcis, Morinda citrifolia, & Mangifera indica.  Maximum nest longevity of Oecophylla smaragdina in Prunus dulcis & Mangifera indica were recorded as 47.14 & 45.68 days, respectively.  In Azadiracta indica, Oecophylla smaragdina nests were recorded for shortest duration as 25.66 days.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Oecophylla smaragdina; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; nests; nest size; nest density; nest longevity; season; population dynamics; temporal variation; impact; agricultural; Azadiracta indica; Citrus limon; Hibiscus rosa sinensis; Mangifera indica; Manikara zapota; Morinda citrifolia; Polyalthia longifolia; Pongamia pinnata; Prunus dulcis; horticultural crops;

author: Nalini, T. and Ambika, S.
title: Population dynamics of Oecophylla smaragdina Fabricius (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) in mango (Mangifera indica) and sapoya (Manilkara zapota)
abstract: *[A study was conducted to assess the population dynamics of Oecophylla smaragdina Fabricius on mango & sapota trees in the orchard of Faculty of Agriculture, Annamalai University, Annamalainagar, Tamil Nadu, India.  From the study, it was evident that in highest number of green nests (13.10/tree) & dry nests (6.00) were found in mango during February & March.  The number was minimum in December, May, & June.  Leaf pavilion was 0.10 in June & 0.00 in all other months.  Total number of nests were higher during February (17.70) & less in December (0.60).  In sapota, highest number of green & dry nests were found in September & March as 19.75 & 17.75, respectively.  Lowest number of green nest & dry nest were present in April & October as 1.00 and 0.50 respectively.  Leaf pavilion was 0.00 in all the months.  Total number of nests were highest during September (26.25) & lowest during November (1.25).]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Oecophylla smaragdina; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; population dynamics; impact; agricultural; Mangifera indica; sapota; Manilkara zapota;

author: Nalini, T. and Ambika, S.
title: Colony inhabitation of weaver ant, Oecophylla smaragdina Fabricius (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) in different plant hosts and their impact on the yields of selected horticultural crops
abstract: *[A survey was conducted to assess the colony inhabitation of weaver ant, Oecophylla smaragdina in different plant hosts & their impact on the yields of selected horticultural crops in Faculty of Agriculture, Annamalai University, Annamalainagar, Tamil Nadu.  Colony inhabitation of O. smaragdina was found in 17 plant hosts in 14 families: Anacardiaceae, Annonaceae, Cucurbitaceae, Fabaceae, Lecythidaceae, Malvaceae, Meliaceae, Moraceae, Myrtaceae, Poaceae, Rosaceae, Rubiaceae, Rutaceae, Sapotaceae, & one unidentified host.  New record of a creeper plant host, Coccinia indica was recorded from India.  Fifty four plants not harboring O. smaragdina were identified.  Colony inhabitation of O. smaragdina was the highest in Mangifera indica for all the 12 months.  In Morinda citrifolia, Manilkora zapota, Prunus dulcis, & Citrus limon the months of occupancy of O. smaragdina were 10, 9, 8, & 6, respectively.  Satisfactory control of coleopterans & lepidopterans by O. smaragdina was achieved in trees with ant nests in Mangifera indica.  Homopteran levels were higher than other arthropods in trees with ant nests.  The yields of Mangifera indica, Manilkara sapota, Citrus limon, & Anacardium occidentale were 43.64, 73.16, 1.00, & 22.28 Kgs per tree respectively in the presence of O. smaragdina nests, whereas in trees without ant nest the yields were 36.08, 65.28, 0.80, & 19.60 Kgs per tree, respectively.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Oecophylla smaragdina; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; colony; nests; season; impact; agricultural; Anacardiaceae; Mangifera Indica; Annonaceae; Polyalthia longifolia; Cucurbitaceae; Coccinia indica; Fabaceae; Cassia fistula; Lecythidaceae; Couroupita guianensis; Malvaceae; Hibiscus rosa sinensis; Thespesia populnea; Meliaceae; Azadiracta indica; Moraceae; Ficus carica; Myrtaceae; Psidium guajava; Pongamia Pinnata; Poaceae; Kinabaluchloa nebulosa; Rosaceae; Prunus dulcis; Rubiaceae; Ixora coccinea; Rutaceae; Citrus limon; Sapotaceae; Manilkara Zapota; horticultural crops; new plant host record; yield; biocontrol;

author: Nalini, T. and Ambika, S. and Kanagarajan, R.
title: Studies on abundance of Qecophylla smaragdina Fabricius (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) and their nest formation in Mangifera indica and Manilkara sapota
abstract: *[A study was conducted to determine the abundance of Oecophylla smaragdina nests in plant hosts at Annamalainagar, Tamil Nadu, India.  It is evident that the highest percentage of nests were recorded in March, April of 2017 & February 2018.  Smallest percentage of nests were found during July, November, & December 2017.  The highest Offenberg index of Oecophylla smaragdina on Mangifera indica was recorded during April, March, Feburary, & May as 58.93, 52.45, 41.83, & 40.57, respectively.  In the nest formation process on Mangifera indica & Manilkara zapota, the maximum number of workers were involved in chain formation & the minimum numbers of workers were involved in walking & moving behaviors.  Comparatively more workers were involved on Manilkara zapota (2413) than Mangifera indica (240) nest formation.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Qecophylla smaragdina; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; abundance; nests; nest formation; season; behavior; chain formation; weaving behavior; holding behavior; brood tending behavior; staying behavior; walking behavior; moving behavior; host trees; Mangifera indica; Manilkara sapota; Offenberg index;

author: Nalini, T. and Jayanthi, R.
title: First record on interaction between ants, other insect visitors and extrafioral nectaries (EFNS) in selected crops from India
note: Part of FORMIS 21; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[A study was conducted to determine the interactions between ants, other insect visitors, & extrafloral nectaries in selected crops at experimental farms of Faculty of agriculture, Annamalai University, in 6 extrafloral nectary-bearing crops: Vigna mungo, Vigna radiata, Gossypium hirsutum, Hibiscus cannabinus, Dolichos lablab var. typicus, & Ricinus communis.  Among the herbivores Phenacoccus sp., Aphis sp., & Helicoverpa sp. were highest & among predators Coccinellidae & Vespidae was highest.  Camponotus compressus was highest in Vigna mungo, V. radiata, & Gossypium hirsutum.  In Hibiscus cannabinus, Ricinus communis,  Dolichos lablab var. typicus, Myrmicaria brunnea & Solenopsis geminata was highest respectively.  In ant-exclusion experiment, in both control & treatment Phenacoccus solenopsis showed gradually decreasing pattern from the first week to fourth week.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Camponotus compressus; Camponotus irritans; Camponotus rufoglaucus; Camponotus seriseus; Monomorium scabriceps; Myrmicaria brunnea; Solenopsis geminata; Tetraponera nigra; Formicinae; Myrmicinae; Pseudomyrmecinae; Asia; India; scientific; field incidence; herbivores; predators; extrafloral nectaries; EFN-bearing crops; ant-exclusion;

author: Nalini, T. and Jayanthi, R. and Selvamuthukumaran, T.
title: Studies on morphology, distribution of EFNS and the association of ants with extra-floral nectaries bearing plants
note: Part of FORMIS 21; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[Morphology (location, shape) & distribution of extrafloral nectaries for 62 plants were listed for the first time in India.  Fabaceae possessed nectaries on peduncle, on petiole, on Interpetiolar region, on last pair of paripinnately compound leaflets, & on lower portion of petiolule.  Among Cucurbitaceae, extrafloral nectary location was on abaxial surface of leaf, bract, bracteoles, flower bud, & calyx.  Among Malvaceae, extrafloral nectaries are present mostly on abaxial surface of leaf & one species has extrafloral nectaries on digitate leaf base & bottom of petiole & stem (Ceiba pentandra).  In Euphorbiaceae, nectaries were present on different sites: abaxial surface of leaf, petiole, stem, & calyx.  Convoluvalaceae have nectaries mostly on abaxial surface of leaf on midrib & base of leaf.  Six morphotypes of extrafloral nectaries were found in 62 plants.  Distribution of extrafloral nectaries on different plant parts falls within the 4 categories: single, paired, uniform, & scattered.  The study on association of ants with 56 extrafloral nectary-bearing plant species was done for the first time in India.  Fabaceae found to be associated with all the 3 subfamilies of ant.  Plant species in the family Cucurbitaceae were linked with 6 species of ants.  Malvaceae are associated with only 2 ant subfamilies.  Euphorbiaceae were associated with 4 ant species, all in Myrmicinae.  Five ant species were associated with Convoluvalaceae.]          *[Meranoplus bicolor inconsistently misspelled Meranoplus bicolour; Solenopsis geminata inconsistently misspelled Solenopsis geminate].

author: Nalini, T. and Manickavasagam, S.
title: Influence of Weaver ant, Oecophylla smaragdina Fabricius (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) on mealybug parasitism by encyrtids (Chalcidoidea: Encyrtidae)
abstract: *[The influence of Oecophylla smaragdina Fabricius on parasitism of Phenacoccus solenopsis Tinsley & Ferrisia virgata Cockerell by Aenasius arizonensis (Girault) (= Aenasius bambawalei Hayat) & A. advena Compere were studied under laboratory conditions.  The number of surviving A. arizonensis & A. advena was 3.40 & 5.20 at 20th minute, & 1.0 and 0.8 at 60th minute, respectively.  Per cent parasitism was 13.60% & 10.00% in treatment with O. smaragdina for A. arizonensis & A. advena, respectively.  Per cent mortality due to O. smaragdina attack was 93.33% & 94.67% for A. arizonensis & A. advena, respectively.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Oecophylla smaragdina; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; behavior; aggression; interspecific interactions; tending Hemiptera; Coccoidea; Pseudococcidae; Hemiptera; Ferrisia virgata; Phenacoccus solenopsis; impact; agricultural; biocontrol; parasite interference; mortality; parasites; Hymenoptera; Chalcidoidea; Encyrtidae; Aenasius arizonensis; Aenasius advena; Aenasius bambawalei;

author: Nalini, T. and Sasinathan, S.
title: First record on incidence of tropical fire ant Solenopsis geminata (Fabricius) (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) in agricultural ecosystems from Tamil Nadu
note: Part of FORMIS 21; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[A Survey was conducted to assess the field incidence of Solenopsis geminata during the year 2017 & 2018 at the experimental farms of Faculty of Agriculture, Annamalai University& farmers' fields in Sivapuri in black gram & sunflower respectively in relation to abiotic factors.  From the study, it is evident in black gram the maximum number of S. geminata population was recorded in 14th standard week (61.46) at maximum temperature 33.6 degreesC, minimum temperature 22.1 degreesC, & rainfall 0.00mm.  Aphid population was also maximum in the same period (55.23).  In sunflower the highest S. geminata, mealybug incidence was recorded in the 52nd standard week as 9.95, 12.69 at maximum temperature 28.3degreesC, minimum temperature 21.2 degreesC, & rainfall 0.00 mm.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Solenopsis geminata; Myrmicinae; Asia; India; scientific; distribution; population; temperature; tending Hemiptera; aphids; mealybugs; impact; agricultural; agricultural ecosystems; black gram; sunflower;

author: Nalini, T. and Sasinathan, S.
title: First record on incidence and damage of tropical fire ant Solenopsis geminata (Fabricius) (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) in horticultural ecosystems from Tamil Nadu
note: Part of FORMIS 21; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[A Survey was conducted to observe the field incidence of Solenopsis geminata during the year 2017 & 2018 in farmers field at Therkumangudi & experimental farms of Faculty of agriculture, Annamalai University in brinjal (Solanum melongera), bhendi (Abelmoschus esculantus), & mesta (Hibiscus spp.) in relation to abiotic factors.  It is the first attempt to record damage caused by S. geminata on brinjal & bhendi in Tamil Nadu.  Ants occurred & caused damage on both the crops even without the association of Homopterans.  From the study, it is evident that in brinjal, S. geminata incidence was maximum in 22nd standard week (56.30).  The maximum shoot damage was noticed in the same standard week (3.51%), when the abiotic factors such as maximum temperature, minimum temperature, rainfall were 38.6 degreesC, 27.6 degreesC, & 000.0 mm rainfall. In bhendi, maximum S. geminata population (61.66%) was observed as maximum in 22nd standard week.  The maximum bud & flower damage of 6.45%, 4.21% was noticed in the same standard week.  In mesta, maximum number of S. geminata was noticed in 46th standard week (45.64), when the weather parameters were such as maximum temperature, minimum temperature, & rainfall were 31.2 degreesC, 23.4 degreesC, & 006.8 mm rainfall.  Mealybug incidence noticed during the same period was 65.47.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Solenopsis geminata; Myrmicinae; Asia; India; scientific; impact; agricultural; agricultural ecosystems; brinjal; Solanum melongera; bhendi, Abelmoschus esculantus; mesta; Hibiscus; damages;

author: Nalini, T. and Sasinathan, S.
title: First record on population dynamics of Solenopsis geminata (Fabricius) (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) in selected coastal districts of Tamil Nadu from India
note: Part of FORMIS 21; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[A Survey was conducted to observe the population dynamics of Solenopsis geminata in selected coastal districts of Tamil Nadu in relation to abiotic factors.  This is the first attempt to record the population dynamics of Solenopsis geminata in selected coastal districts of Tamil Nadu from India.  Solenopsis geminata mounds were present in Faculty of Agriculture, Administration area, Thiruvetkulam area, Sivapuri east, Sivapuri west, Sivapuri south, Sivapuri north, Kilagundalapadi south, Kilagundalapadi north, Therkumangudi west, Panchanthikulam east, Panchanthikulam west, Ayakkaranpulam, & Maruthur during 12 months.  In Therkumangudi north they were totally absent in all 12 months.  Maximum density of Solenopsis geminata mounds occurred during March followed by July, November, December, January, May, June, & October in locations of Cuddalore district.  During October, November, & December the mound density did not decrease.  In locations of Nagapattinam district maximum mound density of Solenopsis geminata occurred during May.  Minimum number of mounds occurred during April.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Solenopsis geminata; Myrmicinae; Asia; India; scientific; distribution; density; mounds; nests; season; new record; population dynamics; abiotic factors; temperature; rainfall;

author: Nalini, T. and Sasinathan, S.
title: Evaluation of toxicity of botanicals and essential oils against Solenopsis geminata (Fabricius) (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
note: Part of FORMIS 21; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[Laboratory experiments were carried out to test the toxicity of botanicals (clove, cinnamon, coriander powder, & essential oils: pepper mint, clove, eucalyptus) in the Department of Entomology, Faculty of Agriculture, Annamalai University.  In toxicity tests on S. geminata with botanicals, 100% mortality was caused by clove powder at the dose of 81mg after 120 minutes; cinnamon powder at 108 mg dose after 240 minutes; & coriander powder at the dose of 108 mg after 240 minutes.  In toxicity tests on S. geminata with essential oils, 100% mortality was obtained in clove oil at 2 & 2.5% concentrations after 30 minutes; Peppermint oil at 1.5, 2, & 2.5% concentrations after 60 minutes; & Eucalyptus oil at 2 & 2.5% concentrations after 120 minutes.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Solenopsis geminata; Myrmicinae; Asia; India; scientific; impact; agricultural; chemical control; plant extracts; botanicals; cinnamon powder; clove powder; coriander powder; essential oils: clove; eucalyptus; pepper mint; mortality;

author: Nalini, T. and Sasinathan, S.
title: Evaluation of efficacy of entomopathogens against Solenopsis geminata (Fabricius) (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
note: Part of FORMIS 21;from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[Experiments were carried out at Annamalai University to test the efficacy of Beauveria bassiana & Metarhizium anisopliae against S. geminata mounds.  One day after the treatment of B. bassiana, there was reduction of original mounds in 3 doses: 10, 7, & 5g.  New mounds appeared in doses of 10 & 7g.  Disappearances of new mounds were found in doses of 7 & 10g at 2 & 3 days after treatment.  Dead S. geminata workers were observed 2 days after treatment in the dose of 5g.  Maximum number of new mounds was found in the 10g dosage.  In M. anisopliae treated mounds 3 days after treatment, control was evident in 10g dose on S. geminata original mounds.  Also 7 & 5g doses obtained control at 5 days after treatment, while 3g dose did not showed any effect on original mounds.  No new mounds were found in 3, 5, 7, & 10g doses.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Solenopsis geminata; Myrmicinae; Asia; India; scientific; workers; mounds; nests; impact; agricultural; biocontrol; microbial control; Beauveria bassiana and Metarhizium anisopliae; mortality;

author: Nancy, N.P. and Amin, M.R. and Mia, M.R.U. and Miah, M.G.
title: Diversity of insects in sweet gourd field of Bangladesh
abstract: *[The study was conducted at Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman Agricultural University, Gazipur, Bangladesh during September 2016 to June 2017 to observe abundance & diversity of insects in sweet gourd Cucurbita moschata.  The pest, predator, pollinator, & other category insects visited in the field showed significant difference in their abundance, richness, & diversity, & the pests & predators were statistically similar & higher compared to pollinators & other category.  In total 409 insects were collected of which 130 were in winter & 279 were in summer.  Of the total collected species, 11 species were pest & their relative abundance varied from 0.05 to 2.57 per 30 sweeps.  In total 8 species of insects were predator & their relative abundance ranged from 0.24 to 2.24 per 30 sweeps.  The pollinator insets showed the highest & lowest abundance was at 09.00 and 13.00 h of the day, respectively both in winter and summer]          *[NOTE: Formica rubra Linnaeus, 1758 is an obsolete combination of Myrmica rubra (Linnaeus, 1758).  It is not a valid taxa.  There are no Myrmica rubra records from anywhere near Bangladesh.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Formica rubra; Myrmica rubra; Formicinae; Myrmicinae; Asia; Bangladesh; scientific; abundance; diversity; richness; predator; impact; agricultural; sweet gourd; pest; Bactrocera cucurbitae;

author: Nandhakumar, V.
title: Angioedema following ingestion of fried flying red fire ants
note: Part of FORMIS 15; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: *[Red ant sting anaphylaxis was rarely reported from India, but angioedema due to ingestion of fried flying red fire ants in children is almost never reported from India & also very rarely reported from outside India.  We report a case of recurrent non allergic angioedema following ingestion of fried flying red ants.]

title: Genetic variation of thief ants, Solenopsis molesta (Say) (Hymenoptera: Formicidae).  [abstract]

keywords: ant; Formicidae; Solenopsis carolinensis; Solenopsis molesta; Solenopsis molesta validiuscula; Myrmicinae; North America; USA; Indiana; Kansas; Louisiana; Nebraska; New Jersey; New York; South Dakota; Tennessee; Washington; scientific; genetics; genetic variation; mitochondrial DNA sequences; cytochrome oxidase I; taxonomy; distribution;

author: Narain, R.B. and Kamble, S.T. and Powers, T.D. and Harris, T.S.
title: DNA barcode of thief ant complex (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
note: Part of FORMIS 15; from NAL'S AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: The thief ant, Solenopsis molesta (Say): a common nuisance species found through-out the United States is genetically related to red imported fire ants, S. invicta Buren. Therefore, its identification at the molecular level is very important. The deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) barcoding, a recent technique was used to identify thief ant complex at species and subspecies levels using short DNA sequence from the cytochrome oxidase subunit 1 (COI) mitochondrial region. The DNA from thief ants collected from 9 states was extracted using Qiagen's Gentra PUREGENE DNA Isolation Kit. The polymerase chain reactions (PCR) were run on the extracted DNA to amplify partial sequence of COI using primers Lep-Fl (forward) and Lep-Rl (reverse). The resulting DNA products were concentrated, purified and sequenced. The 600 bp sequences of the COI generated were submitted to GenBank that issued accessions numbers from HM179641 to HM179653. The sequences associated with these accession numbers were used as DNA barcodes for distinguishing species and subspecies. Based on this molecular analysis, thief ants collected from New York, Indiana and 1 location in Nebraska were separated in 1 group as S. molesta validiuscula (Emery) and another with ants from Louisiana identified as S. carolinensis (Forel). The third group was comprised of ants from South Dakota, Washington, New Jersey, Tennessee, Kansas and 2 other locations in Nebraska was identified as S. molesta molesta (Say).

author: Narain, R.B. and Kamble, S.T. and Powers, T.O.
title: Morphological characterization and molecular mediated genetic variation of thief ant, (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
abstract: *[The morphological characterization & molecular genetic variation were determined in populations of thief ants, Solenopsis molesta (Say).  The genetic variations were elucidated using mitochondrial deoxyribonucleic acid (mDNA) sequences of cytochrome oxidase I.  DNA from thief ants was extracted with Qiagen's Gentra PUREGENEÆ DNA Isolation Kit using their solid tissue protocol.  Polymerase chain reactions (PcR) were run on the extracted DNA using primers Lep-F1 (forward) & Lep-R1 (reverse).  The DNA products were concentrated & purified by Microcon centrifugal Filter Unit YM-100.  Purified DNA samples were sequenced at the University of Arkansas Medical Sciences (UAMS) DNA Sequencing core Facility.  The sequences were edited & aligned using codon code Aligner.  The contigs wee uploaded to www.Phylogeny.fr & phylogenetic trees were produced (Neighbor joining, Maximum likelihood, Bayesian).  The trees displayed variation in genetic makeup of the thief ants from various geographic regions & genetic variation corresponded to the morphologic identification.  The thief ants collected from different states were separated into 3 groups.  Ants collected from New York, Indiana, & one location in Nebraska formed one group identified as S. molesta validiuscula, a second group formed with ants from Louisiana identified as S. carolinensis, & the third group consisted of ants from South Dakota, Washington, New Jersey Tennessee, Kansas, & 2 other locations in Nebraska identified as S. molesta molesta.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Solenopsis carolinensis; Solenopsis molesta; Solenopsis molesta molesta; Solenopsis molesta validiuscula; Myrmicinae; North America; USA; Indiana; Kansas; Louisiana; Nebraska; New Jersey; New York; South Dakota; Tennessee; Washington; scientific; genetics; DNA; DNA barcoding; cytochrome-c oxidase; nucleotide sequences; polymerase chain reaction; taxonomy; distribution;

Under South Indian conditions, in the tall type of palms, this exudation occurs before stigmatic receptivity, and does not exclude ants from reaching the stigma.]

author: Narendra, A. and Gibb, H. and Musthak Ali, T.M.
title: Structure of ant assemblages in Western Ghats, India: role of habitat, disturbance and introduced species
abstract: *[This study provides new information on ant assemblages in a little-studied region.  As in other parts of the world, ant assemblages in Western Ghats were strongly influenced by habitat & disturbance, with different functional groups associated with different habitats & levels of disturbance.  No functional group showed evidence of being influenced by the abundance of introduced species.  In addition, predictions of negative interactions between functional groups were not supported. Our findings suggest that abiotic factors are universal determinants of ant assemblage structure, but that competitive interactions may not be.]

author: Narendra, A. and Ramachandra, T.V.
title: Remote detection and distinction of ants using nest-site specific LISS-derived Normalised Difference Vegetation Index
abstract: *[This study in Western Ghats, India, investigates the relation between nesting sites of ants and a single remotely sensed variable, the Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (= NDVI).  We carried out sampling in 60 plots each measuring 30 X 30 m & recorded nest sites of 13 ant species.  We found that NDVI values at the nesting sites varied considerably between individual species & also between the 6 functional groups the ants belong to.  The functional groups cryptic species, tropical climate specialists, & specialist predators were present in regions with high NDVI.  Hot climate specialists & opportunists were found in sites with low NDVI.  As expected, we found that low NDVI values were associated with scrub jungles & high NDVI values with evergreen forests.  Interestingly, we found that Pachycondyla rufipes, an ant species found only in deciduous and evergreen forests, established nests only in sites with low NDVI (range = 0.015 - 0.1779).  Our results show that these low NDVI values in deciduous & evergreen forests correspond to canopy gaps in otherwise closed deciduous & evergreen forests.  Subsequent fieldwork confirmed the observed high prevalence of P. rufipes in these NDVI-constrained areas.]
