author: Ramaswamy, K. and Peeters, C. and Yuvana, S.P. and Varghese, T. and Pradeep, H.D. and Dietemann, V. and Karpakakunjaram, V. and Cobb, M. and Gadagkar, R.
title: Social mutilation in the ponerine ant Diacamma: Cues originate in the victims
abstract: *[In the queenless ponerine ant genus Diacamma, all workers eclose with a pair of innervated thoracic appendages termed gemmae.  The gamergate (= mated egg laying worker) maintains reproductive monopoly by mutilating the gemmae of all eclosing individuals.  Such mutilation leads to irreversible behavioral & neurological changes such that the individual lacking gemmae becomes incapable of appropriate sexual calling & mating.  In one population related to Diacamma ceylonense from India, Diacamma sp. from Nilgiri (hereafter referred to as 'nilgiri'), gamergates do not mutilate their nestmates & yet maintain reproductive monopoly.  To understand what triggers mutilation, we exchanged cocoons between the mutilating D. ceylonense colonies & the non mutilating 'nilgiri' colonies.  'nilgiri' callows were not mutilated even in D. ceylonense colonies, while D. ceylonense callows were mutilated even in 'nilgiri' colonies, suggesting that the cues for mutilation originate in the victims (callows), presumably in the gemmae themselves.  This finding should facilitate understanding the proximate mechanism & evolutionary significance of mutilation of gemmae as a method of resolution of reproductive conflicts in the genus Diacamma.]

author: Ramesh, A. and Vijayan, S. and Sreedharan, S. and Somanathan, H. and Uma, D.
title: Similar yet different: differential response of a praying mantis to antmimicking spiders
note: Part of FORMIS 17; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Batesian mimics typically dupe visual predators by resembling noxious or deadly model species. Ants are unpalatable and dangerous to many arthropod taxa, and are popular invertebrate models in mimicry studies. Ant mimicry by spiders, especially jumping spiders, has been studied and researchers have examined whether visual predators can distinguish between the ant model, spider mimic and spider nonmimics. Tropical habitats harbour a diverse community of ants, their mimics and predators. In one such tripartite mimicry system, we investigated the response of an invertebrate visual predator, the antmimicking praying mantis (Euantissa pulchra), to two related antmimicking spider prey of the genus Myrmarachne, each closely mimicking its model ant species. We found that weaver ants (Oecophylla smaragdina) were much more aggressive than carpenter ants (Camponotus sericeus) towards the mantis. Additionally, mantids exhibited the same aversive response towards ants and their mimics. More importantly, mantids approached carpenter antmimicking spiders significantly more than often that they approached weaver antmimicking spiders. Thus, in this study, we show that an invertebrate predator, the praying mantis, can indeed discriminate between two closely related mimetic prey. The exact mechanism of the discrimination remains to be tested, but it is likely to depend on the level of mimetic accuracy by the spiders and on the aggressiveness of the ant model organism.

author: Ramesh, T. and Jahir Hussain, K. and Satpathy, K.K. and Selvanayagam, M. and Prasad, M.V.R.
title: Diversity, distribution and species composition of ants fauna at Department of Atomic Energy (DAE) Campus Kalpakkam, South India
note: Part of FORMIS 13; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[A survey of ant faunal diversity, species composition, & the effect of microhabitat were studied in Department of Atomic Energy Campus, Kalpakkam, South India during dry season (March-June 2008).  Ants were collected by pitfall traps & handpicking in 5 habitats with different vegetation types.  A total of 35 species of ants belonging to 5 subfamilies were collected.  The Myrmicinae was the dominate subfamily with respect to species diversity (18 species) & abundance, whereas 10 Formicinae species were found.  The 5 most species-rich genera were Monomorium, Camponotus, Tetraponera, Crematogaster, & Tetramorium.  Results indicate that the scrub jungle & riparian woods were most diverse habitats followed by monoculture & sandy area.  Vegetation type, soil characteristics, & anthropogenic disturbances are chief factors influence the ant assemblage of DAE campus.]          *[Pseudomyrmecinae consistently misspelled Pseudomyrmicinae.]          *[NOTE: The identification of Solenopsis invicta needs to be confirmed.  India would be a significant range extension for the invasive species Solenopsis invicta.]          *[This Solenopsis invicta record is listed as dubious by https://www.antwiki.org/wiki/Solenopsis_invicta  checked 7 Sept. 2019.]

author: Ramesh, T. and Jahir Hussain, K. and Selvanayagam, M. and Satpathy, K.K.
title: Diversity of the ground inhabiting ant fauna at Department of Atomic Energy campus, Kalpakkam (Tamil Nadu)
note: Part of FORMIS 13; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[Ant sampling was carried out in different locations of the Department of Atomic Energy Campus at Kalpakkam during dry season (March June 2008).  Pitfall traps & hand-picking methods were used to collect ants from 20 different sampling sites.  A total of 31 species, 15 genera, & 5 subfamilies of ants were collected.  The Myrmicinae were the most common, with 7 genera & 16 species, followed by the Formicinae (4 genera & 8 species), the Ponerinae (2 genera & 2 species), the Pseudomyrmecinae (1 genus & 4 species), & the Dolichoderinae was represented by only 1 species.  Interestingly 86.6% of the genera, 83.8% of the species, & 92.4% of the individuals collected belonged to 3 subfamilies (Myrmicinae, Ponerinae, Formicinae).  The 5 most species-rich genera were Monomorium, Camponotus, Tetraponera, Crematogaster, & Tetramorium.  The taxonomic structure of the myrmecofauna sampled, resembles that of Western & Eastern Ghats & other tropical regions in 2 ways: first, many rare species & a few abundant species, second, the dominance of subfamilies such as Myrmicinae, Ponerinae, & Formicinae.  The species accumulation curve indicated that the likelihood of getting more number of species in the campus, which was supported by the rarefaction curve.]          NOTE: Solenopsis invicta has not been previously reported from India.  This identification needs to be confirmed.

author: RamÌrez, M. and EnrÌquez, M.L.
title: Riqueza y diversidad de hormigas en sistemas silvopastoriles del Valle de Cauca, Colombia
note: Part of FORMIS 07; from Fire Ant Literature Database; Part of the Leaf-Cutting Ant Bibliography; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: *[We compared ant diversity & richness in 2 silvopastoral systems, Cynodon plectostachyus associated with Algarrobo trees, Prosopis juliflora, & Estrella, Cynodon plectostachyus associated Leucaena shrubs, Leucaena leucocephala, & a fragment of tropical dry forest, located in the Natural Reserve El Hatico, El Cerrito municipality, Valle del Cauca, Colombia.  Two 100-m lineal transects were placed in each system, with sampling stations at 10-m intervals in order to collect ground foraging ants.  One pitfall trap & one tuna baits were placed in each station.  Additionally, we measured the vegetation vertical structure & the canopy cover at each site.  We collected 62 ant species, in 26 genera & 6 subfamilies, Myrmicinae was the most  commly collected.  In order to ascertain survey efficiency, we calculated the richness by mean ACE, Jacknife 1, & Michaelis Menten Mean estimators, which indicated that the surveyed ants were 62 to 88% of the total number of species in both agroecosystems.  Richness, diversity, & exclusive ant species were 38, 1.33, & 23 for the forest fragment; 35, 1.08, & 10 for the Prosopis silvopastoral system; & 21, 0.92, & 7 for the Leucaena silvopastoral system.  With a Hutchenson "t" test we found differences in ant diversity values between all ecosystems (p less than 0.05).  Pitfall traps were the most effective survey method since this method captured more species.  There was no correlation between vegetation volume, vegetation layer, & canopy cover with ant richness & diversity.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Acropyga; Apterostigma; Atta cephalotes; Azteca; Brachymyrmex; Camponotus abdominalis; Camponotus indianus; Camponotus novogranadensis; Camponotus; Cardiocondyla; Cephalotes; Crematogaster; Cyphomyrmex rimosus; Dolichoderus bispinosus; Dolichoderus; Ectatomma tuberculatum; Ephebomyrmex; Labidus; Leptothorax; Linepithema dispertitum; Linepithema; Macromischa; Monomorium; Mycocepurus smithii; Odontomachus chelifer; Pachycondyla harpax; Pachycondyla obscuricornis; Pachycondyla unidentata; Pachycondyla; Paratrechina; Pheidole sussanae; Pheidole; Procryptocerus regularis; Pseudomyrmex elongatus; Pseudomyrmex boopis; Pseudomyrmex; Solenopsis geminata; Solenopsis; Wasmannia auropunctata; Dolichoderinae; Ecitoninae; Ectatomminae; Formicinae; Myrmicinae; Attini; Ponerinae; Pseudomyrmecinae; South America; Colombia; scientific; species diversity; species richness; transects; pitfall traps; tuna baits; silvopastoral systems;

author: RamÌrez, M. and Montoya-Lerma, J. and Armbrecht, I.
title: Fodder banks: Does cyclic pruning influence soil ant richness (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)?
note: Part of FORMIS 10; Part of the Leaf-Cutting Ant Bibliography; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: *[The present study evaluated whether drastic disturbances on vegetal cover (= pruning) alter ant communities in terms of their assemblage richness & movement.  Ants were sampled monthly from 2 fodder banks, regeneration areas, & open pasture lands, using tuna baits & litter samples in permanent transects.  Concomitantly, vegetation & litter thickness measurements were obtained.  The Bray-Curtis index was calculated to determine ant species turnover in fodder banks & neighboring sites.  None of the most abundant ant species appeared to be affected by pruning.  Although ant species richness fluctuated during the study period, reduction in species richness were not due to fodder bank pruning.  In addition, massive displacement of ants to neighboring places did not coincide with fodder bank trimming.  It was clear that ant turnover was determined instead by seasonality. A total of 6,127 ant specimens were collected, 3,001 at El CiprÈs & 3,126 at El Cambio.  These were classified into 67 morphospecies, belonging to 10 subfamilies.]

title: A coat of many scents: fig wasp cuticular compounds as potential cues for prey recognition by ants.  [abstract]

author: Ranganathan, Y. and Bessiere, J.M. and Borges, R.M.
title: A coat of many scents: Cuticular hydrocarbons in multitrophic interactions of fig wasps with ants
note: Part of FORMIS 17; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: The fig-fig wasp system of Ficus racemosa constitutes an assemblage of galler and parasitoid wasps in which tritrophic interactions occur. Since predatory ants (Oecophylla smaragdina and Technomyrmex albipes) or mostly trophobiont-tending ants (Myrmicaria brunnea) were previously shown to differentially use volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from figs as proximal cues for predation on fig wasps, we examined the response of these ants to the cuticular hydrocarbons (CHCs) of the wasps. CHC signatures of gallers were distinguished from those of parasitoids by the methyl-branched alkanes 5-methylpentacosane and 13-methylnonacosane which characterised trophic group membership. CHC profiles of wasp predator and wasp prey were congruent suggesting that parasitoids acquire CHCs from their prey; the CHC composition of the parasitoid Apocrypta sp 2 clustered with that of its galler host Apocryptophagus fusca, while the CHC profile of the parasitoid Apocryptophagus agraensis clustered with its galler prey, the fig pollinator Ceratosolen fusciceps. In behavioural assays with ants, parasitoid CHC extracts evoked greater response in all ant species compared to galler extracts, suggesting that parasitoid CHC extracts contain more elicitors of ant behaviour than those of plant feeders. CHCs of some wasp species did not elicit significant responses even in predatory ants, suggesting chemical camouflage. Contrary to earlier studies which demonstrated that predatory ants learned to associate wasp prey with specific fig VOCs, prior exposure to fig wasp CHCs did not affect the reaction of any ant species to these CHCs.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Myrmicaria brunnea; Oecophylla smaragdina; Technomyrmex albipes; Dolichoderinae; Formicinae; Myrmicinae; Asia; India; scientific; workers; cuticular hydrocarbons; alkanes; alkenes; chemical camouflage; polyenes; volatile organic compounds; fig wasp cuticular compounds; potential cues; prey recognition; differential predation pressure; multitrophic interactions; Ficus racemosa;

author: Ranganathan, Y. and Borges, R.M.
title: Predatory and trophobiont-tending ants respond differently to fig and fig wasp volatiles
abstract: *[We found that Oecophylla smaragdina predatory ants patrolling Ficus racemosa trees were attracted to the odor from fig syconia at different developmental phases, as well as to the odors of fig wasps, whereas Technomyrmex albipes predatory ants responded only to odors of syconia from which fig wasps were dispersing & to fig wasp odor.  However, Myrmicaria brunnea trophobiont-tending ants patrolling the same trees & exposed to the same volatiles were unresponsive to fig or fig wasp odors.  The predatory ants demonstrated a concentration-dependent response towards volatiles from figs receptive to pollinators & those from which wasps were dispersing while the trophobiont-tending ants were unresponsive to such odors at all concentrations.  Naive predatory ants failed to respond to the volatiles to which the experienced predatory ants responded, indicating that the response to fig-related odors is learned.]

author: Ranganathan, Y. and Ghara, M. and Borges, R.M.
title: Temporal associations in fig-wasp-ant interactions: diel and phenological patterns
abstract: *[We focused on temporal resource partitioning among members of the fig wasp community over the development cycle of the fig syconia during which wasp oviposition & development occur, studing the activity rhythm of the ants associated with this community.  Ant activity on the fig syconia was correlated with wasp activity & was dependent on whether the ants were predatory or trophobiont-tending species.  Only numbers of predatory ants increased during peak arrivals of the wasps.]

author: Rani, S. and Sanju
title: Schedules of foraging activity and micronutrient food proclivity in black carpenter ants, Camponotus pennsylvanicus
abstract: *[Schedules of foraging activities & food preferences in black Carpenter ants, Camponotus pennsylvanicus were investigated in the field in April 2015, when temperature before sun-rise & after sun-set was comparatively lower than rest of the day.  These parameters were examined by attracting carpenter ants to different food materials like jam (apple jam) source of sugar; wheat flour source of carbohydrates, Moong dal (namkeen) source of fats, lipids, & salt; jaggery; source of minerals.  Ant foraging activity was recorded over 72 hours in one week along with ambient temperature to examine correlations with ant activity patterns.  Results indicated that foraging activity may be influenced by both time & temperature.  In April, when temperatures were generally higher, foraging activity was greater during relatively cooler times of the day & night.  Results indicated that carpenter ants consistently preferred sugar over lipids.  Carbohydrates & lipids were generally ignored by carpenter ants & in most cases decreased consumption of the sample.]          *[NOTE: This identification needs to be CONFIRMED.  India would be a significant range extension for the North American species Camponotus pennsylvanicus.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Camponotus pennsylvanicus; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; diet; food preferences; foraging activity; carpenter ants;

author: Ranjit Singh, A.J.A. and Padmalatha, C.
title: Ethno-entomological practices in Tirunelveli district, Tamil Nadu
abstract: *[Kanikars & Paliyars (the tribal people living in Western Ghats of Tirunelveli district) & village physicians use insects to prepare medicine.  In this study, 11 species of insects used to prepare traditional medicine were identified & details about their therapeutic value are enumerated.  Dorylus labiatus are collected, put into honey & after a fortnight the honey is taken to strengthen nervous system & to restore good health.  The household black ants, Componotus compressus & Monomorium spp. are also used as medicine.   Oecophylla smaragdina 'eggs' are used to prepare medicine with medicinal herbs & administered to patients suffering from tetanic fever, ear pain, high fever, & malarial fever.  The eggs are also used to prepare an aphrodisiac.  The secretion used by this  ant to build the nest has antibacterial activity.]          *[Camponotus compressus misspelled Componotus compressus.]

author: Rao, K.S. and Kumar, Y. and Yadav, S. and Rawal, R.
title: Diversity and abundance of flower visiting insects associated with sesame
note: Part of FORMIS 23; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: A field experiment was conducted at the Research farm of Department of Entomology, CCS Haryana Agricultural University (CCSHAU) Hisar, Haryana to determine the diversity and abundance of insect pollinators on two varieties of sesame HT-1 and HT-2 during 2017 and 2018. A total of 34 insect species belonging to 18 families from four orders were observed. Of these Apis dorsata (4.76 bees/ m≤/ 5 min; 26.92% of total flower visitors) followed by A. mellifera (2.34 bees/ m≤/ 5 min), M. lanata (2.23 bees/ m≤/ 5 min) and A. florea (1.32 bees/ m≤/ 5 min) were predominant. Peak activity of the insect visitors was observed at 1000-1200 hr of the day

title: Biodiversity of Nallamalai Hill Ranges, Eastern Ghats, India
institution: p. 214-221, In: Proc. National Seminar on Conservation of Eastern Ghats
abstract: *[This study presents an upto date account of the flora & fauna of Nallamalais, in the Eastern Ghats in Andhra Pradesh, India.  The vegetation is broadly divided into forest, grassland, & hydrophytic categories.  Floristic & faunistic surveys were carried out since 1999.  The  floristic survey results in recording of total of 1541 angiosperm taxa.  The faunistic survey resulted in a detailed checklist of mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, fishes, & some orders of arthropods.]

author: Rao, N.S. and Veeresh, G.K.
title: Management of crazy ant, Anoplolepis longipes (Jerdon)
abstract: *[Field studies were carried out in Karnataka, India, in 1985-86 to develop an effective management strategy for Anoplolepis longipes, a general pest.  Of 4 traps tested, pits dug at 45 x 45 x 20 cm & filled with material such as litter & dried leaves were the most effective.  Banding tree trunks with 'Tree Tangle Foot' or grease prevented the ants from attacking trees.  Emulsifiable concentrates of chlorpyrifos, aldrin, & pirimiphos-methyl, all at 0.05%, gave complete control of the ant.  Dusting with methyl parathion [parathion-methyl] or quinalphos at 1.0 kg a.i./4000 m2 was also effective.]

author: Rao, N.S. and Veeresh, G.K.
title: Nesting and foraging habits of crazy ant Anoplolepis longipes (Jerdon) (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
abstract: *[In field studies in Karnataka, India, in 1984-86, 4 types of nests of Anoplolepis longipes were identified.  Permanent nests were constructed under structures such as foundations & walls.  Temporary nests were constructed at the base of trees & crops, or in compost & farm waste.  Seasonal nests were made under small stones & bricks.  Other nests were made in the bare soil without any vegetation.  Foraging was affected by heavy rain, wind, & hot temperatures.  There was little foraging in the early afternoon in summer, but no differences were found apart from this.  Foragers collected sugary substances from fruits, honeydew from Homoptera, plant exudates, & small animals.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Anoplolepis gracilipes; Anoplolepis longipes; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; nest site; foraging;

author: Rao, N.S. and Veeresh, G.K.
title: Some observations on the biology and behaviour of crazy ant, Anoplolepis longipes (Jerdon) (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
note: Part of FORMIS; from TEK; from-DPW,
abstract: *[The biology & behavior of Anoplolepis longipes were studied.  Queens laid 7-22 eggs/day & the total number of eggs laid was 1960-2249 in 116-145 days under laboratory conditions.  The mean duration of the egg, larval, & pupal stage was 18.6, 19.4, & 21.6 days, respectively.  The total duration of the life cycle of workers was 59.6 days.  The longevity of worker ants, males, & the queen was 84.3, 10.5 and 137.5 days, respectively.  More than 98% of the colony (21 g) was made up of worker ants.  Colony biomass was low during the production of sexual brood.  Alate males & females were only produced 2 months after the first showers or at the beginning of the wet season (April-May) in India.  The worker caste was produced throughout the year, & peaked during and after the wet season, while females were only produced during March-June.]

author: Rao, N.S. and Veeresh, G.K. and Viraktamath, C.A.
title: Dispersal and spread of crazy ant Anoplolepis longipes (Jerdon) (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
abstract: *[In field studies in Karnataka, India, in 1985-86, the spread of colonies of Anoplolepis longipes was found to be aided by the budding of colonies & were multi-queened.  Hostility between conspecific members of different colonies was not observed.  Radiolabelling studies indicated that nests within a radius of 1.5-2.0 m were always interconnected with the main nest.  Budded colonies dispersed form the original nest to a maximum distance of 3.2 m.]

An identification key & distribution map of the known Pakistani Temnothorax is presented.  Summaries of the taxonomic history & biology of the 3 Temnothorax species of Pakistan is included.]

author: Rastogi, N.
title: Prey concealment and spatiotemporal patrolling behaviour of the Indian tree ant Oecophylla smaragdina (Fabricius)
abstract: *[Oecophylla smaragdina workers conceal prey with leaves & twigs on discovering large prey on their ground territory.  The prey concealment behavior occurs concurrently with prey capture & killing.  Ants were observed conducting spatiotemporal patrolling around large prey.  The garden lizard Calotes versicolor & at least 2 predatory ant species were found to forage in the same area as O. smaragdina.  It is suggested that the prey concealment behavior of Oecophylla may be a strategy to prevent prey detection by vertebrate predators, which use vision to prey on similar large prey species.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Camponotus; Oecophylla smaragdina; Pheidole; Formicinae; Myrmicinae; Asia; India; scientific; prey; colony; behavior; prey concealment; foraging; territory; spatiotemporal patrolling;

author: Rastogi, N.
title: Seasonal pattern in the territorial dynamics of the arboreal ant Oecophylla smaragdina (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
abstract: *[A 30-month field study on territorial dynamics of Oecophylla smaragdina (Fabricius) colonies in Varanasi, India, revealed a regular seasonal pattern in territorial organization.  Each colony exhibited a circannual rhythm pertaining to the size of the central territory (nesting trees) & the secondary territory (ground area).  Incorporation of new nesting trees in the central territory reached a major peak in September & a smaller peak during March-April.  In each colony, only one tree, located near the centre of the territory, was used continuously for a maximum duration (28 & 30 months in colony I & II respectively).  In both the colonies, trees located at a distant from the center of the colony territory were found to be incorporated in the central territory, during March-April and/or September each year. Ground area used by each colony was largest during September.  The circannual rhythm of territorial organization may be related to the brood development & food requirements of the Oecophylla smaragdina colony.  Thus, territorial expansion during September, each year, may be a fine-tuned evolutionary adaptation of the growing colony to the availability of insect prey during the SW monsoon rains.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Oecophylla smaragdina; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; nests; nesting trees; arboreal ant; territorial dynamics; circannual rhythm; polydomy; nest organization;

author: Rastogi, N.
title: Provisioning services from ants: food and pharmaceuticals
note: Part of FORMIS 12; Part of the Leaf-Cutting Ant Bibliography; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: *[This review assesses the role of ants in providing ecosystem provisioning services in the form of products such as food & medicine.  Many species of ants constitute an inexpensive, protein-rich & mineral-rich, unconventional human food source.  Some ant species are also utilized in traditional entomotherapy by indigenous people, or as a complementary and/or alternative medicine, in many parts of the world.  Recent biochemical & pharmacological investigations are increasingly providing evidence regarding the medicinal significance of ant species.  The well-developed immune system & anti-microbial chemicals that evolved in ants for defense against pathogens can be exploited for the treatment of human diseases.]

author: Raza, M. and Tukshipa, S.D. and Chakravorty, J.
title: Oecophylla smaragdina (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) and Odontotermes sp. (Isoptera: Termitidae) a potential source of antioxidant: the two most preferred edible insects of Arunachal Pradesh, India
abstract: *[We studied the antioxidant potential of weaver ant Oecophylla smaragdina (adult & brood) & termite Odontotermes sp., the 2 common species of insects used as food by tribes of Arunachal Pradesh & elsewhere in India.  DPPH* scavenging activity IC50 (µg/mL) ranged from 59.56 (weaver ant adult) to 66.30 (termite).  Termite species scored higher ABTS*+ scavenging activity (IC50: µg/mL), Ferric reducing power (TPEE µg/g) & phenolics (mg GAE/g) (18.70, 36.60 and 626.92) than weaver ant adult (52.57, 211.21, & 369.69) & weaver ant brood (33.34, 114.32, & 486.04).   Weaver ant adults scored higher flavonoids (mg RTE/g) (663.43) than its brood (387.19) & termite species (58.04).  Weaver ant brood contained substantial amounts of phenolics & flavonoids, comparatively higher than phenolics of weaver ant adult & flavonoids of termite.  These 2 insects may serve as an ideal dietary food supplement for handling oxidative stress & as a replacement for some conventional food products.]

author: Reddy, M.V. and Ao, M.A. and Tiwary, S.P.
title: On the damage of ants to plastic tubes and insect store boxes
note: Part of FORMIS; from CBU; verified-DPW.
abstract: Two species of ants, Paratrechina sp. and Pheidole sp. (Formicidae; Hymenoptera), were recorded damaging transparent plastic specimen tubes (Tarsons product, Calcutta) made of polystyrene and the covers made of polyethylene, in the entomology research laboratory of the NEHU College of Agriculture, Medziphema (Nagaland). The former species was a more abundant and serious pest. In addition, it damaged the synthetic spongy pinning material of the insect store boxes used for pin-mounting the dry, preserved insects engraving cavities inside and cutting specimens of Stromatium barbatum Fabr. (Coleoptera) into pieces. The damage is described and discussed.

author: Reddy, M.V. and Venkataiah, B.
title: Seasonal abundance of soil-surface arthropods in relation to some meterological and edaphic variables of the grassland and tree-planted areas in tropical semi-arid savanna
note: Part of FORMIS; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: *[Seasonality of relative population abundance in different groups of soil-surface arthropods was investigated monthly by pit-fall traps during a 2-year period in the grassland & tree-planted areas of a tropical semi-arid savanna at Warangal (S India).  Densities of most groups were lowest during summer & highest during the rainy season.  They were less abundant during winter.  Arthropods were recorded in higher numbers in tree-planted compared to grassland areas.  Certain arthropods that were found only during part of the year were recorded for a longer period in the tree-planted area.  Monomorium indicum Forel, Crematogaster sp., & Pachycondyla? tesserinoda (Emery), & Pachycera sp. (Coleoptera) reached maximum densities in the rainy season & minimum numbers during winter & summer in the grassland area.  However, these species had lower densities during the rainy season & reached maximum densities during winter & summer in the tree-planted area.  The seasonal abundance of arthropods showed significant linear correlations with different abiotic environmental variables such as rainfall, soil moisture, organic matter, soil and air temperatures, soil pH, & relative humidity at the soil surface, & potassium & phosphorus of surface soil.  Soil moisture & rainfall were generally the strongest correlates with densities, particularly in the grassland area.]

author: Regupathy, A. and Ayyasamy, R.
title: Ants in biofuel, Jatropha ecosystem: pollination and phoresy
note: Part of FORMIS 12; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[Jatropha ecosystem is associated with an array of organism showing great bio-diversity. The organisms include defoliators, visitors, predators of other species and pollinators.  During roving survey in 42 locations in Tamil Nadu & one in Kerala, India for the occurrence of pests, observations were made on the ants visiting Jatropha & feeding on nectar & other insects, & spreading insect pests (specifically coccids).  Nine species of ants (Camponotus compressus (Fabricius), Camponotus sericeus (Fabricius), Camponotus parius Emery, Crematogaster sp., Solenopsis geminata (Fabricius), Pheidole spathifera Forel, Oecophylla smaragdina (Fabricius), Monomorium sp., & Tapinoma melanocephalus Fabricius)) were visiting Jatropha.  The species composition & predominance of particular species varied with location.  Due to its characteristic behavior exhibiting strong territorial defense & aggression, O. smaragdina prevented/repelled the approach of the Jatropha visitors including the pollinators.  Other species visited flowers & coccid infested parts to collect nectar & honeydew secretions respectively.  The positive effects of the ants are that they remove herbivorous insects like shoot webber & defoliating caterpillars & aiding in incidental pollination while collecting nectar.  Pollen grains were observed on ventral side of Camponotus spp., & on both ventral & dorsal sides of Crematogaster sp., S. geminata, & P. spathifer.  Ants visit mostly confined to the flowers of the same plant, thus the possibility of effecting cross pollination is very remote.  However, they aid in pollination within the same plant.  Jatropha is affected by coccid pests like tailed mealy bugs Ferrisiana (Ferrisia) virgata, C., Jatropha Scale, Hemilecanium imbricans N., & neem Scale, Pulvinaria maxima G. & recently by the invasive papaya mealy bug Paracoccus marginatus Williams & Granara de Willink.  The negative effect was more pronounced especially when a mealy bug infestation is present, as they often care for fluid-sucking homopterans that damage the plants & indirectly cause sooty mould.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Camponotus compressus; Camponotus parius; Camponotus sericeus; Crematogaster; Monomorium; Oecophylla smaragdina; Pheidole spathifera; Solenopsis geminata; Tapinoma melanocephalus; Dolichoderinae; Formicinae; Myrmicinae; Asia; India; scientific; prey; distribution; species richness; species diversity; tending Hemiptera; honeydew; impact; agricultural; Jatropha; pollination, phoresy, biofuel;

author: Reid, B.L. and Klotz, J.H.
title: Oral toxicity of abamectin, dechlorane, and sulfluramid to free-foraging workers of Camponotus pennsylvanicus (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
note: Part of FORMIS; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from JHK; verified JHK; verified-DPW, USDA-CMAVE M-2647.
abstract: Oral toxicities of delayed-action insecticides abamectin, dechlorane, and sulfluramid were characterized in free-foraging Camponotus pennsylvanicus (DeGeer) workers gathering insecticide-laced, sugar-milk baits.  Abamectin acted significantly faster than either dechlorane or sulfluramid.  When workers fed upon 500-ppm baits, abamectin killed the ants faster (LT50 [95% CL] = 1.06[0.88-1.23] d) than either dechlorane (5.82 [5.62-6.00] d) or sulfluramid (6.20 [5.76-6.65] d).  All toxicants were readily transferred by trophallaxis.  In ants that were exposed to a single forager that had fed upon a 500-ppm bait, abamectin caused death more rapidly (LT50 [95% CL] = 2.56 [2.29-2.81] d) than did dechlorane (6.71 [6.35-7.05] d) or sulfluramid (6.96 [6.06-8.42] d).  In both direct and indirect exposures, significant concentration-dependent time delays before mortality were observed for all toxins.  Based on the effective lethal time for 90% (ELT90) of the exposed workers, the concentration dependence of the time delays for dechlorane and sulfluramid were equivalent, and both were active over a wider range of concentrations than abamectin.   (abstract provided by author)
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Camponotus pennsylvanicus; Formicinae; North America; USA; Indiana; trophallaxis; scientific; chemical control; delayed action toxicant; toxic bait; mortality; abamectin; insecticides; sulfonamides;

author: Rekha and Goswami, D. and Arya, D. and Kaushal, B.R.
title: Insects diversity in an agroecosystem of Bhabar region of Uttrakhand
abstract: *[Species diversity & abundance of insects associated in an agricultural ecosystem was studied in Bhabar region of district Nainital in Uttarakhand from March 2018 to February 2020.  Data revealed a total of 148 insect species belonging to 47 families & 9 orders (Lepidoptera, Coleoptera, Hemiptera, Orthoptera, Hymenoptera, Odonata, Diptera, Dictyoptera, Phasmida), identified from 2007 specimens.  These were classified into 5 functional trophic groups: phytophagous, predators, omnivores, saprophages, & decomposers. The diversity indexes showed significance- Diversity (Hπ=1.778), Evenness (E=0.9689), and Margalef;s Index (d=1.924).]          *[NOTE: Their are no records for Lasius niger given in https://www.antwiki.org/wiki/Lasius_niger for Uttarakhand state, India.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Lasius niger; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; diversity; relative abundance; trophic guilds; diversity; species richness; season; trophic level; pollinators; visitors; agroecosystem; Bhabar region; insect pollinators;

author: Rekha, D.G. and Kaushal, B.R. and Arya, D.
title: Relative abundance and insect biodiversity in crop land of Ramnagar (Corbett city), Uttarakhand, India
abstract: *[This study investigated the species richness, diversity, abundance, & distribution of insects in the field crops of Ramnagar (Corbett City), Uttarakhand, India, from 1 January to 30 January 2017.  A total of 601 individuals of insects belonging to 3 orders & 4 families were recorded during the study period.  On the basis of total number of recorded species, Pieridae was the most dominant family contributing 3 species followed by Apidae, Formicidae, & Acrididae (1 species each), respectively.  Among the different species of insects, Apis dorsata (Fabricius) was the most abundant individuals in the study area which constituted 71.04% of the total individuals.  Lasius niger constituted 17.97% of the total individuals.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Lasius niger; Formicinae; Asia; India; scientific; distribution; abundance; diversity; species richness; habitat; impact; agricultural; crop land; field crops; Shannon diversity index; Evenness; Margalef index;

author: Remadevi, O.K. and Rao, K.S. and Ananda, K. and Veeranna, R. and Tarakanadha, B.
title: Status of insects and fungi intercepted from wood imported into India
note: Part of FORMIS 13; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[Logs of many species are imported into India either in dry or semi dry condition for uses ranging from structural material for construction to finished products including panel products & furniture.  The common timber species imported are Tectona grandis (Teak), Intsia palembanica (Merbau), Dipterocarpus indicus (Gurjan), Shorea spp. (Sal), Nauclea diderrichii (Kussia), & Pinus radiata (Pine).  32 species of insects belonging to Coleoptera and Hymenoptera & 22 species of fungi reported on imported timbers were analyzed for their distribution in India.  Acanthomyrmex luciolae Emery is a new introduction to India as Acanthomyrmex as a genus itself is not known from India.  The other ant species have been previously reported from India.]          *[Myrmicaria brunnea misspelled Myrmicaria brunniaa; Solenopsis geminata misspelled Solenopsis geminate.]

author: Richter, A. and Schoeters, E. and Billen, J.
title: Morphology and closing mechanism of the mandibular gland orifice in ants (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
note: Part of FORMIS 23; Part of the Leaf-Cutting Ant Bibliography; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[The mandibular gland of ants releases chemical compounds with functions ranging from nestmate alarm & nestmate recognition to antimicrobial defense.  While the morphology of this ethologically important gland is well investigated in several species, the mechanism of secretion release in ants is not explicitly addressed to date.  To clarify this question, we examined the anatomy of the gland orifice in ant species from 14 different subfamilies employing different techniques.  The orifice close to the mandibular base is located on an area called mandalus.  Our investigations revealed variation in mandalar shape, with clear trends in different subfamilies.  In contrast, the internal organization is remarkably congruent across all investigated species.  The thin external mandalar cuticle is always connected to the mandibular gland duct by a cuticular lamella, visible as a characteristic anchor-shaped structure in cross section.  The slit-like gland orifice at the distal end of the mandalus is usually crescent-shaped.  In some ant species with specialized mandibles such as trap-jaws, the organization of the orifice area is adapted to the mandibular shape, but always retains the general internal organization.  No muscles were found in association with the orifice, nor with any other part of the mandibular gland.  However, the base of the mandalus is connected to the prepharyngeal sucking pump by a cuticular ligament.  Additionally, it is continuous with the conjunctiva connecting the mandible to the head capsule.  We propose that retraction of the sucking pump by the muscle M. tentoriobuccalis, potentially in concert with opening of the mandible, stretches out the ligament & thus pulls on the mandalus & mandalar lamella to open the gland orifice, & allow for secretion release.  This hypothesis is congruent with findings on other aculeate Hymenoptera.         *[Cryptopone taivanae misspelled Crypotopone taivanae; Eciton misspelled Echiton.]

author: Rickson, F.R. and Rickson, M.M.
title: The cashew nut, Anacardium occidentale (Anacardiaceae) and its perennial association with ants: extrafloral nectary location and the potential for ant defense
note: Part of FORMIS 99; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Cashew nut trees are consistently ant-visited throughout the year, with the ants attracted to a large number of extrafloral nectaries on the leaves, inflorescences, flowers, and developing nuts. The commercial production of cashew nut, for example, in India, Brazil, and east Africa, consistently applies pesticides, especially insecticides, in large monoculture plantings. Each year prophylactic spraying begins with the first flush of new leaves, continues through flowering, ending at about mid-nut development. We surveyed for ant diversity in sprayed and unsprayed cashew monocultures of various sizes and ages in Sri Lanka, India, and Malaysia to document the ant-cashew relationship and to explore the potential of ants replacing chemical pesticides in insect control. Using for-profit, commercial-size plantations as examples, we present information that cashew has a strong potential for arthropod-dependent protection from pests and suggest important habitat considerations for encouraging ants within cashew plantings.          *[Pheidole misspelled Pleidole.  Tetraponera spp. misclassified as Ponerinae; they are Pseudomyrmecinae.]

author: Rigato, F.
title: Revision of the myrmicine ant genus Lophomyrmex, with a review of its taxonomic position (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)
note: Part of FORMIS; from TEK; from ANTBIB; verified-PSW; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: *[The myrmicine ant genus Lophomyrmex is fully revised & transferred from tribe Pheidologetonini to Pheidolini (tribal transfer: Pheidolini, senior synonym of Lophomyrmecini syn.n.).  Ten species are recognized, which are placed into 2 species groups.  The quadrispinosus group, characterized by the presence of pronotal teeth or spines, includes birmanus, kali sp.n., opaciceps stat.n. (=javana syn.n.), quadrispinosus (=taprobanae syn.n.), & taivanae stat.n. The bedoti group, in which the pronotum is dorsolateraly marginate, includes ambiguus sp.n., bedoti, longicomis sp.n., lucidus stat.n., & strialulus sp.n.  A key to the worker caste is presented & descriptions of known sexual forms are given.   Lophomyrmex quadrispinosus v. taprobanae is a n.syn. of Lophomyrmex quadrispinosus; Lophomyrmex bedoti v. lucidus n.stat. as Lophomyrmex lucidus; Lophomyrmex quadrispinosus v. opaciceps n.stat. as Lophomyrmex opaciceps; Lophomyrmex quadrispinosus v. javana is a n.syn. of Lophomyrmex quadrispinosus v. opaciceps; Lophomyrmex quadrispinosus opaciceps taivanae n.stat. as Lophomyrmex taivanae.]

author: Rink, W.J. and Dunbar, J.S. and Tschinkel, W.R. and Kwapich, C. and Repp, A. and Stanton, W. and Thulman, D.K.
title: Subterranean transport and deposition of quartz by ants in sandy sites relevant to age overestimation in optical luminescence dating
abstract: An artificial layered sandy site was created using a combination of native sand and colored sand (3 parts native uncolored quartz, 1 part colored quartz) in Apalachicola National Forest near Tallahassee, Florida. Twelve layers of sand, each 1 by 1 m in horizontal extent by 10 cm in thickness were emplaced to a depth of 2 m followed by implantation at the surface of a Florida harvester ant (Pogonomymrex badius) colony (the lower two layers were 50 cm thick). The colony excavated a nest, and after 7 months, the sand layers were excavated to the base to test the hypothesis that sand grains were moved upward within the ant nest without reaching the surface. The ants penetrated 11 of the 12 colored layers reaching a depth of 130 cm. Thirty nine sticky-acetate peels of ant chamber floors were collected and colored sand grains were counted under a microscope. More than 16,000 grains were identified in layers that did not originally host them. Of these, more than 80% were unambiguously moved upward. This means that possibly as many as 54,000 upwardly mobile grains were present (ratio of 3:1 uncolored to colored). In relation to optical luminescence (OSL) dating, this means that grains that would not have been optically zeroed by transport to the surface (defined here as subterranean-transported) were present in abundance, and that if the site was ancient, there would have been found many grains that were older than the layers they presently reside in, even if only one colony of harvester ants had disturbed the layers. This is in addition to the fact that backfilling of chambers and tunnels may contribute even more significantly to the presence of a subterranean-transported component of an OSL sample. We conclude that ants can significantly affect the age distributions in sandy archaeological sites. Multiple examples of such disturbances have been documented in the literature. Most relevant to our results are recent studies of the OSL chronology of Pre-Clovis-age and Palaeoindian age archaeological sites in sandy environments in North America that may have been compromised by ant bioturbation of quartz sand grains. Here we have examined in detail the potential effects of one episode of ant nest-building on the age overestimation of affected sediments. From this we found that as few as 12 episodes of bioturbation involving backfilling of chambers in the same volume of sand could lead to the presence of 1 contaminant grain per 50 grains of sample.   (This article was written and prepared by U.S. Government employee(s) on official time, and is therefore in the public domain.)

author: Robertson, J.A. and Moore, W.
title: Phylogeny of Paussus L. (Carabidae: Paussinae): unravelling morphological convergence associated with myrmecophilous life histories
note: Part of FORMIS 18; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Ant nest beetles (Paussus L.) are ecologically fascinating and phenotypically bizarre. Obligate myrmecophiles, Paussus have undergone extreme adaptations for life with ants and their profound range of phenotypic diversity has been difficult to reconcile in a systematic framework. We conducted a detailed morphological study of Paussus utilizing novel techniques and character systems in order to discover anatomical apomorphies diagnostic of the major clades of Paussus strongly supported by molecular data. Bayesian inference (BI) of molecules alone, morphology alone and varying combinations of the two data types reveal that morphology is informative for placing Paussus species, despite the extreme phenotypic diversity and convergence prevalent in the group. We propose a new classification for Paussus based on this phylogeny. The genus Paussus is revised to include all genera, subgenera and species formerly classified as Paussus by Nagel (2003) in addition to Hylopaussus syn.n., Hylotorus syn.n. and Granulopaussus syn.n. The following species are transferred to Paussus: Paussus sebakuanus (PÈringuey) comb.n., Paussus gracilis (Reichensperger) comb.n., Paussus bucephalus Gyllenhal, Paussus caroli (Reichensperger) comb.n., Paussus uelensis (Reichensperger) comb.n., Paussus hottentottus (Westwood) comb.n., Paussus blanchardi (Raffray) comb.n., Paussus basilewskyi (Luna de Carvalho) comb.n., Paussus granulatus Westwood, Paussus sankuruensis Reichensperger, Paussus leleupi (Reichensperger) comb.n., Paussus reichenspergeri (Luna de Carvalho) comb.n. We formally delineate and diagnose the following major subgroups of Paussus: Paussus I series, comprising the subgenera Bohemanipaussus Luna de Carvalho stat. rev. sensu n., Bathypaussus Wasmann stat. rev. sensu n., and Edaphopaussus Kolbe stat. rev. sensu n.; the Paussus II series comprising the subgenera Paussus L. stat. rev. sensu n., Klugipaussus Kolbe stat. rev. sensu n., Scaphipaussus Fowler stat. rev. sensu n., Hylotorus Dalman stat.n. sensu n., and Anapaussus Wasmann stat. rev. sensu n.; and the Paussus III series comprising the subgenera Lineatopaussus Kolbe stat. rev. sensu n. and Shuckardipaussus Kolbe stat. rev. sensu n.

author: Romeis, J. and Shanower, T.G.
title: Arthropod natural enemies of Helicoverpa armigera (H¸bner) (Lepidoptera: Noctuidae) in India
note: Part of FORMIS 16; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[Helicoverpa armigera (H¸bner) (Lepidoptera: Noctuidae) is one of the most serious insect pests in the Old World.  In India, it causes substantial losses to legume, fibre, cereal, oilseed, & vegetable crops.  This paper reviews the literature on the biology, ecology, efficacy, rearing, & augmentation of endemic parasitoids & predators, as well as exotic parasitoids introduced & released in India.  It also provide s updated lists of H. armigera natural enemies native to India.  In addition, reports of augmentative releases of Trichogramma spp., the most extensively studied natural enemies of H. armigera are summarized.]

author: Roonwal, M.L.
title: Plant-pest status of root-eating ant, Dorylus orientalis, with notes on taxonomy, distribution and habits (Insecta: Hymenoptera)
note: Part of FORMIS; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from ANTBIB; verified-PSW; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: *[Because of the controversy about the status of the ant Dorylus orientalis as a plant-pest (some authors maintaining that it is exclusively carnivorous), all the available information has been re-examined & new observations added.  It is established that in India, Burma, & Sri Lanka the ant (worker stage) is a definite, sometimes serious pest, attacking the underground portions of plants including economic ones such as vegetables, potatoes, groundnuts, coconut seedlings, citrus, & sugarcane setts.  Information on its taxonomic status is summarized.  There are 4 synonyms: D. curtis; (Shuckard), D. fuscus Emery, D. longicornis (Shuckard), & D. oberthueri (Emery).  The geographical distribution is, India (except N & NW parts), S. Nepal, Sri Lanka; Burma, & S. China (Kweichow).  Notes on habits & swarming are given.]

author: Rosselli, D. and Wetterer, J.K.
title: Stings of the ant Wasmannia auropunctata (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) as cause of punctate corneal lesions in humans and other animals
note: Part of FORMIS 21; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Numerous researchers have observed a form of punctate corneal lesions causing leukomas (corneal opacities) in humans, domestic animals, and wild animals in different parts of the world.This condition has been reported under different names, including West Indian (or Caribbean) punctate keratopathy, West Indian dots, tropical punctate keratopathy, Rice's keratopathy, Florida keratopathy, and Florida spots. Many of these cases, appear to have a common cause, the stings of a small red ant, Wasmannia auropunctata (Hymenoptera: Formicidae), originally from the Neotropics, but spread to other parts of the world through human commerce. The purpose of this article is to link disparate literature on punctate or nummular corneal lesions published in medical, veterinary, wildlife, and entomology journals, because many researchers seem largely unaware of the literature from disciplines other than their own. Recognizing a common cause of this corneal condition is important to insure proper medical treatment and foster efforts to limit the spread and negative impact of W. auropunctata.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Wasmannia auropunctata; Myrmicinae; North America; South America; review; stings; distribution; impact; medical; cornea; punctate corneal lesions; corneal disease; corneal opacity; dog disease; cat disease; human disease; domestic animals; humans; medical treatment; medicine; veterinary medicine;

author: Rˆssler, W. and Zube, C.
title: Dual olfactory pathway in Hymenoptera: Evolutionary insights from comparative studies
note: Part of FORMIS 16; from NAL's AGRICOLA; Part of the Leaf-Cutting Ant Bibliography; from-DPW,
abstract: In the honeybee (Apis mellifera) and carpenter ant (Camponotus floridanus) the antennal lobe output is connected to higher brain centers by a dual olfactory pathway. Two major sets of uniglomerular projection neurons innervate glomeruli from two antennal-lobe hemispheres and project via a medial and a lateral antennal-lobe protocerebral tract in opposite sequence to the mushroom bodies and lateral horn. Comparison across insects suggests that the lateral projection neuron tract represents a special feature of Hymenoptera. We hypothesize that this promotes advanced olfactory processing associated with chemical communication, orientation and social interactions. To test whether a dual olfactory pathway is restricted to social Hymenoptera, we labeled the antennal lobe output tracts in selected species using fluorescent tracing and confocal imaging. Our results show that a dual pathway from the antennal lobe to the mushroom bodies is present in social bees, basal and advanced ants, solitary wasps, and in one of two investigated species of sawflies. This indicates that a dual olfactory pathway is not restricted to social species and may have evolved in basal Hymenoptera. We suggest that associated advances in olfactory processing represent a preadaptation for life styles with high demands on olfactory discrimination like parasitoism, central place foraging, and sociality.

author: Roura-Pascual, N. and Suarez, A.V. and GÛmez, C. and Pons, P. and Touyama, Y. and Wild, A.L. and Peterson, A.T.
title: Geographical potential of argentine ants (Linepithema humile) in the face of global climate change
journal: Proc. R. Soc. London B Biol. Sci.
note: Part of FORMIS 06; from NAL'S AGRICOLA; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: *[We assembled a dataset of over 1000 occurrences of the Argentine ant, Linepithema humile, one of the world's worst invasive ant species.  We used this dataset to assess the species potential geographical & ecological distribution, & to examine changes in its distributional potential associated with global climate change, using techniques for ecological niche modelling.  Models developed were highly predictive of the species overall range, including both the native distributional area & invaded areas worldwide.  Despite its already widespread occurrence, L. humile has potential for further spread, with tropical coastal Africa & southeast Asia apparently vulnerable to invasion.  Projecting ecological niche models onto 4 general circulation model scenarios of future (2050's) climates provided scenarios of the species potential for distributional expansion with warming climates.  Generally, the L. humile was predicted to retract its range in tropical regions, but to expand at higher latitude areas.]

title: A preliminary study on the succession of insect visitors and their symbiotic interaction for effective pollination in Brassica juncea (L.) of southern West Bengal
abstract: *[A preliminary study was conducted for 9 days in a commercial crop field at Haripal in Hooghly district of West Bengal during the flowering phase of Brassica juncea L. to observe the periodical occurrence of insect visitors & their role in pollination.  Twenty-nine insect species belonging to 16 families in 7 orders were recorded as visitors of Brassica.  Lepidoptera had maximum number of species occurrence followed by Coleoptera & Hymenoptera.  It was observed that species were found to visit in different parts of plant, but most of them had a common location with flowers.  This indicated that most of the insect species had specific intension of nectar collection, which led the pollination efficiency.]

author: Roy, S. and Gayen, A.K. and Mitra, B. and Duttagupta, A.
title: Diversity, foraging activities of the insect visitors of mustard (Brassica juncea Linnaeus) and their role in pollination in West Bengal
note: Part of FORMIS 23; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW,
abstract: *[The study was carried out at agricultural land of Phaldi, near Duttapukur (North 24 parganas, West Bengal, India) during 2012-2013 to document the diurnal insect diversity, their activities, roles, & abundance in mustard (Brassica juncea L.) flowers.  24 insect species belonging to 14 families in 6 orders were found during the day time in mustard blooms among which 4 species (Apis dorsata, Apis cerena, Apis florea, Vespa sp.) are pollen & nectar collectors (pollinators), 13 insects were only nectar collector, & the rest of the species were only visitors.  The number of species of Lepidoptera & Hymenoptera were high during the day time.  The abundance of Hymenoptera was observed maximum followed by Coleoptera & Lepidoptera during this study.  Peak activity of the insect visitors was mainly observed at the middle of the day (from 12 noon to 2 P.M).]          *[Solenopsis geminata & Diacamma rugosum are nectar foragers.  Solenopsis geminata represented 15% of the mustard flower visitors]

author: Roy, S. and Sen, J.
title: Use of zootherapy in the treatment of malaria by different ethnic groups of North-East India
abstract: *[This review addresses the application of zootherapy in cases of malaria among different tribes residing in the NE states of India.]          *[The women of Adi tribe collect larvae of ants Oecophylla smaragdina to administer to a patient suffering from malaria.  The adults of these ants are left on the back of a malaria patient.  It is believed that these ants after coming in contact with the patient's body frequently bite & inject some acids or hormones into the body of the patient.  This process eventually reduces the body heat which further aids to cure malaria.  Like Adi tribe, the Mishings tribe & the Ahom Community of Assam also use Oecophylla smargdina as one of the food items during the Assamese Bohag Bihu Festival in the month of April.  It is presumed that consuming these ants might keep their health free from various diseases including malaria.  Nyishi & Galo tribes of Arunachal Pradesh prescribe intake of crushed black ants (Bothroponera rufipes) along with other edibles during morning hours as a great remedy in case of malaria.]

author: Roychoudhury, N.
title: New record of natural enemies of sal heartwood borer, Hoplocerambyx spinicornis Newman (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae)
abstract: *[Hoplocerambyx spinicornis Newman (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae), commonly known as sal borer, is responsible for large scale damage of sal (Shorea robusta Gaertn. F.) forests.  During the recent emergence of borer beetles (2012-2015) in sal forests of Dindori & East Mandla Forest Divisions of Madhya Pradesh & Kabirdham Forest Division of Chhattisgarh, surveys were carried out in search of natural enemies of sal borer both in sal forests & timber depots.  I collected & identified a total of 7 species of natural enemies of sal borer.  Among the predators, 3 species of ants were found: Oecophylla smaragdina Fabricius, Camponotus compressus Fabricius, & a small red ant (Myrmicinae) were found feeding on eggs/grubs/pupae of the sal borer in nature.  Feeding holes of woodpeckers were observed on the borer affected tree trunk of sal & moles were observed feeding on borer beetles on tree traps in sal forests.]

author: Rusina, L.Y.
title: The impact of ants on spatial and ethological structure of eusocial polistine wasps.  [in Russian, English abstract]
institution: p. 75-78, In: Ants and forest protection, Materials of the 13th All-Russian Myrmecological Symposium, Nizhni Novgorod, 26-30 August 2009
abstract: *[The study analyzes specific features of spatial & ethological organization of the ant-host system in heterogeneous environments.  All independent-founding polistines, whose nests are single, open combs suspended from a petiole, appear to rely on a combination of visial detection, removal of scouting ants, & rubbing of an ant repellent secretion on nest petiole.  Myrmica bergi attacks on Polistes gallicus colony (southern Ukraine) & Tapinoma sp. attacks on Ropalia marginata (Bangalore, India) showed that chemical defense & active defense the colony by lone fondresses is not effective before worker emergence.  The effectiveness of the repellent against different ant species is disscussed.]

author: Rust, J. and Singh, H. and Rana, R.S. and McCann, T. and Singh, L. and Anderson, K. and Sarkar, N. and Nascimbene, P.C. and Stebner, F. and Thomas, J.C. and Kraemer, M.S. and Williams, C.J. and Engel, M.S. and Sahni, A. and Grimaldi, D.
title: Biogeographic and evolutionary implications of a diverse paleobiota in amber from the early Eocene of India
note: Part of FORMIS 25; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: For nearly 100 million years, the India subcontinent drifted from Gondwana until its collision with Asia some 50 Ma, during which time the landmass presumably evolved a highly endemic biota. Recent excavations of rich outcrops of 50-52-million-year-old amber with diverse inclusions from the Cambay Shale of Gujarat, western India address this issue. Cambay amber occurs in lignitic and muddy sediments concentrated by near-shore chenier systems; its chemistry and the anatomy of associated fossil wood indicates a definitive source of Dipterocarpaceae. The amber is very partially polymerized and readily dissolves in organic solvents, thus allowing extraction of whole insects whose cuticle retains microscopic fidelity. Fourteen orders and more than 55 families and 100 species of arthropod inclusions have been discovered thus far, which have affinities to taxa from the Eocene of northern Europe, to the Recent of Australasia, and the Miocene to Recent of tropical America. Thus, India just prior to or immediately following contact shows little biological insularity. A significant diversity of eusocial insects are fossilized, including corbiculate bees, rhinotermitid termites, and modern subfamilies of ants (Formicidae), groups that apparently radiated during the contemporaneous Early Eocene Climatic Optimum or just prior to it during the Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum. Cambay amber preserves a uniquely diverse and early biota of a modern-type of broad-leaf tropical forest, revealing 50 Ma of stasis and change in biological communities of the dipterocarp primary forests that dominate southeastern Asia today.           **[Apparently do not distinguish between Myrmecinae & Myrmicinae (or mispell Myrmicinae).  Fig. 2. Representative insects in Cambay amber of biogeographic ...... (B) Sculptured "myrmecine" ant (Formicidae), near the Recent southeast Asian genus Lordomyrma. ....  Lordomyrma is in the subfamily Myrmicinae.]

author: Sabitha, V. and Harsha, K. and Lekshmi, R. and Gopinath, K. and Balalakshmi, C.
title: Checklist of ants (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) of Silent Valley National Park, Western Ghats, Kerala, India
note: Part of FORMIS 23; from Fire Ant Literature Database; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: *[The present study investigates the ground inhabiting ant diversity in Silent Valley National Park (SVNP).  Sampling was carried out in 6 different locations in the valley.  Bait traps & an intense all-out search were used to collect ground dwelling ants.  A total number of 30 genera representing 40 species of ants belonging to the 6 subfamilies were collected & identified.  Among the subfamilies recorded, Myrmicinae was the most abundant with 12 genera & 14 species, followed by Formicinae with 7 genera & 12 species, Ponerinae with 6 genera & 9 species, Dolichoderinae with 3 genera & 3 species &, Aenictinae & Cerapachyinae with 1 genus & 1 species each.  Myrmicinae, Formicinae, & Ponerinae were dominant representing 83.33% of the genera & 87.50% of the species.  The 2 most species rich genera were Pachycondyla (3 species) & Polyrhachis (4 species) similar to the observed pattern in the Western Ghats.  Four invasive ant species: Anoplolepis gracilipes, Monomorium sp., Paratrechina longicornis, & Tapinoma melanocephalum were identified from the study area.]           *[Solenopsis geminata is not native to India.  It is a new world species, which has been introduced around the world.]

author: Sabu, T.K. and Shiju, R.T.
title: Efficacy of pitfall trapping, Winkler and Berlese extraction methods for measuring ground-dwelling arthropods in moist-deciduous forests in the Western Ghats
abstract: *[The present study provides data to decide on the most appropriate method for sampling of ground-dwelling arthropods measured in a moist-deciduous forest in the Western Ghats in South India.  The abundance of ground-dwelling arthropods was compared among large numbers of samples obtained using pitfall trapping, Berlese, & Winkler extraction methods.  Highest abundance & frequency of most of the represented taxa indicated pitfall trapping as the ideal method for sampling of ground-dwelling arthropods.  However, with possible bias towards surface-active taxa, pitfall-trapping data is inappropriate for quantitative studies, & Berlese extraction is the better alternative.  Berlese extraction is the better method for quantitative measurements than the other 2 methods, whereas pitfall trapping would be appropriate for qualitative measurements.  A comparison of the Berlese & Winkler extraction data shows that in a quantitative multigroup approach, Winkler extraction was inferior to Berlese extraction because the total number of arthropods caught was the lowest; & many of the taxa that were caught from an identical sample via Berlese extraction method were not caught.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Asia; India; scientific; abundance; frequency; forest floor arthropods; soil-litter arthropods; quantitative sampling; qualitative sampling; pitfall traps; Berlese samples; Winkler samples;

author: Sabu, T.K. and Shiju, R.T. and Vinod, K.V. and Nithya, S.
title: A comparison of the pitfall trap, Winkler extractor and Berlese funnel for sampling ground-dwelling arthropods in tropical montane cloud forests
note: Part of FORMIS 12; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: Little is known about the ground-dwelling arthropod diversity in tropical montane cloud forests (TMCF). Due to unique habitat conditions in TMCFs with continuously wet substrates and a waterlogged forest floor along with the innate biases of the pitfall trap, Berlese funnel and Winkler extractor are certain to make it difficult to choose the most appropriate method to sample the ground-dwelling arthropods in TMCFs. Among the three methods, the Winkler extractor was the most efficient method for quantitative data and pitfall trapping for qualitative data for most groups. Inclusion of floatation method as a complementary method along with the Winkler extractor would enable a comprehensive quantitative survey of ground-dwelling arthropods. Pitfall trapping is essential for both quantitative and qualitative sampling of Diplopoda, Opiliones, Orthoptera, and Diptera. The Winkler extractor was the best quantitative method for Psocoptera, Araneae, Isopoda, and Formicidae; and the Berlese funnel was best for Collembola and Chilopoda. For larval forms of different insect orders and the Acari, all the three methods were equally effective.
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Asia; India; scientific; abundance; frequency; forest floor arthropods; soil-litter arthropods; forest litter; habitats; surveys; tropical montane cloud forests quantitative sampling; qualitative sampling; trapping; funnel traps; pitfall traps; Berlese samples; Winkler samples; floatation method;

author: Sabu, T.K. and Vineesh, P.J. and Vinod, K.
title: Diversity of forest litter-inhabiting ants along elevations in the Wayanad region of the Western Ghats
note: Part of FORMIS 08; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW, verified-DPW.
abstract: Litter ant diversity and abundance in relation to biotic and abiotic factors were analyzed at five primary forest sites lying between 300 to 1650 meter above mean sea level in the Wayanad region of the Western Ghats in Kerala, southern India. Ant abundance and species richness peaked at mid-elevations influenced by the presence of favourable physical conditions and abundance of prey resources. Dominance of ants preferring termites and Collembola as prey at sites rich in their specific prey resources indicate the influence of local prey resource availability in determining ant distribution. Dominant species (Tapinoma sp. and Solenopsis sp.) had wider distributions, being present at all elevations. Physical factors (slope of the terrain, rainfall, moisture, humidity, temperature) and prey resource availability (insect larvae, termites, Collembola) influenced ant species abundance at a regional scale, whereas at local scales, site specific variations in the relationship between abundance of ants and prey-predators and physical factors were recorded. The present study highlights the need to consider site-specific abiotic and biotic factors while examining the distribution patterns of litter ants along altitudinal gradients in other regions of the Western Ghats, which is a recognised hot spot of biodiversity with wide regional variation in vegetation types and faunal distribution patterns.          **Myrmicinae incorrectly labeled Myrmecinae; Pheidole misspelled Phidole.

author: Sadasivan, K. and Kripakaran, M.
title: A new species of Tyrannomyrmex Fern·ndez 2003 (Formicidae, Myrmicinae, Solenopsidini) from Western Ghats, Kerala, India
abstract: *[A new species of Tyrannomyrmex (Hymenoptera, Formicidae), T. alii sp.nov., is described from the Western Ghats of Kerala State in S India.  This new species can be distinguished from other Tyrannomyrmex species using morphological characters: from T. dux by the petiolar shape, & from T. legatus & T. rex by surface sculpture & pilosity.  The gyne of the genus is described for the first time.  We provide detailed morphological descriptions of the gyne & worker castes, images from scanning electron microscopy, a key to all 4 known species of Tyrannomyrmex, & a note on the ecology of this rare genus. ]

author: Sadasivan, K. and Kripakaran, M.
title: First record of Proceratium Roger, 1863, Zasphinctus Wheeler, 1918, and Vollenhovia Mayr, 1865 (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from the Western Ghats of peninsular India, description of three new species, and implications for Indian biogeography
abstract: *[Three new ant species from the genera Proceratium Roger, 1863, Zasphinctus Wheeler, 1918, & Vollenhovia Mayr, 1865 are described from the Western Ghats of S India.  This is the first report of Proceratium & Zasphinctus from peninsular India & the first record of Vollenhovia from the Western Ghats mountain range proper.  Proceratium gibbosum sp.nov. is described from Periyar Tiger Reserve in Kerala, being the first record of the P. stictum species group from the Indian subcontinent; it differs from other members of the P. stictum group by the mesonotum bearing a prominent rounded dorsal hump (tumulus) & petiole devoid of ventral tooth.  The first record of the genus Zasphinctus Wheeler, 1918 from the Indian region is presented here, with a description of a new species.  Zasphinctus sahyadriensis sp.nov. differs from all known Afrotropical & Asian Zasphinctus by a combination of characters including clypeal area with single median tooth, occipital margin being regular in outline, & head sculpture sparsely punctate.  The occurrence of the genus Vollenhovia Mayr, 1865 is confirmed from peninsular India, with the description of the female castes of Vollenhovia keralensis sp.nov.  We provide ecological notes on these new taxa.  In addition, separate identification keys based on the worker caste are also presented to Indo-Malayan species of Proceratium, Afrotropical-Indomalayan species of Zasphinctus, & Vollenhovia of the Indian subcontinent.  The biogeographical implications of the presence of these 3 genera are also discussed in relation to plate tectonics of the Indian subcontinent.]          *[Other species that were found in the same microhabitat of P. gibbosum were Tyrannomyrmex alii Sadasivan & Kripakaran,  2017, Protanilla sp., Discothyrea sp., & Recurvidris sp.]          *[ In captivity, Zasphinctus sahyadriensis workers accepted brood of a Pheidole species as food.]          *[Vollenhovia keralensis is described from workers, gynes, & males.]

title: Seasonal pattern and species composition of ants (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) in and around Serampore, Hoogly, West Bengal

There were 5 species of 4 genera in Formicinae & Myrmicinae, 4 species in 2 genera in Ponerinae & 1 species in Dolichoderinae & Pseudomyrmicinae. author: Saha, S. and Das, T. and Raychaudhuri, D.
title: Myrmecophilous association between ants and aphids - an overview
abstract: *[The present paper document the aphids & aphidocolous ants collected on different host plants.  Our investigation from August, 2017-July, 2018 results a total of 40 aphid infested host plants along with 7 species of aphidocolous ants.  Out of 10 aphid species recorded, Aphis gossypii (Glover) is tended by more ant species (5) followed by Rhopalosiphum maidis (Fitch) by four (4) species of ants.]

author: Saha, S. and Roy, T. and Raychaudhuri, D.
title: Ant faunal diversity of Bibhutibhushan Wildlife Sanctuary, North 24 Parganas, West Bengal, India
abstract: *[The present study details the diversity of ants of Bibhutibhushan Wildlife Sanctuary, North 24 Parganas, West Bengal, India.  A total of 22 species in 13 genera distributed in 5 subfamilies were collected.  These include 3 newly recorded species: Lepisiota frauenfeldi (Mayr) (Formicinae), Crematogaster (Acrocoelia) hodgsoni Forel (Myrmicinae), & Brachyponera nigrita Emery (Ponerinae) for the state & nearly 90.5% of the reported species are new for the district.  Analysis of their zoogeographical distribution reveals that the fauna apart from being Oriental also includes some Palaearctic (72.73%), Australian (13.63%), & Ethiopian (4.54%) elements.  The dominant functional group is constituted by the Subordinate Camponotini (36.37%) followed by Generalized Myrmicinae (22.73%), Tropical Climate Specialist (13.63%), Specialist Predator (9.09%), Opportunist (9.09%), & Dominant Dolichorinae (9.09%).  Ants are mostly prevalent during Monsoon (81.82%), followed by Postmonsoon (68.18%) & Premonsoon (50.00%).  Camponotus (Tanaemyrmex) compressus (Fabricius) & Oecophylla smaragdina (Fabricius) are recorded throughout the year.  Ranking sequence of the most abundant species (in descending order) is: Camponotus (T.) compressus (15.01%) = Oecophylla smaragdina (15.01%) then Crematogaster (A.) hodgsoni (12.91%).   Camponotus (T.) compressus & Oecophylla smaragdina are the most dominant species.  Data also reveals that both core & buffer zones conjointly offer a better combination of habitat requirement, as 12 species are common in both the zones.  The highest number of species are recorded from leaf litter & ground combined together (22 species) & 6 species are arboreal in nature.  Shannon's Diversity Index (alpha diversity) & Simpson's Diversity Index both are higher in buffer zone.  This reflects the habitat exploitation efficiency of the encountered species.  As per Jaccard Index (beta diversity) the similarity value of both the zones is only 0.55.]          *[Dolichoderus (Hypoclinea) affinis misspelled Dolichodesus (Hypoclinea) affinis; Lepisiota frauenfeldi misspelled Leisiota frauenfeldi; Polyrhachis inconsistently misspelled Polyrachis; Polyrhachis (Cyrtomyrma) laveissima misspelled Polyrachis (Cyrtomyrma) laveissima; Pseudomyrmecinae misspelled Pseudomyrmicinae.]

author: Saha, S. and Roy, T. and Raychaudhuri, D.
title: Anecdote of spiders and their model ants of Bibhutibhusan Wildlife Sanctuary, N-24 Parganas, West Bengal
abstract: *[Our study on ant diversity of Bibhutibhusan Wildlife Sanctuary, N-24 Parganas, West Bengal during the period, August 2017-July 2018, unfolded wonderful Batesian & Wasmannian mimicry (chemical mimicry) between the ant models Tetraponera rufonigra (Jerdon) and its sibling T. allaborans (Walker), Oceophylla smaragdina (Fabricius), & spiders of the genus Myrmarachne Macleay (Salticidae).  Species of Myrmarachne encountered are M. plataleoides O. P. Cambridge, M. maratha Tikader and M. orientales Tikader.  It is supposed that chemical or Wasmannian mimicry enables species with ant-like pheromones to live in close contact with ants.  The members of spider Myrmarachne that resemble the aggresive weaver ant Oceophylla smaragdina, with which they live in close contact, also show chemical resemblance.  Further, by mimicking the ants they gain protection from predators.  Since weaver ants have a painful bite & also taste bad, this strategy appears to be successful.  Though these spiders mimic the weaver ants very well, they are known to stay away from them.  They weave a thin web on the leaves, hide under their webbing & ambush their prey.  This communication discusses the morphological & structural similarities between the mimics & their models.  This is the first report of mimicry from this part of the country.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Oceophylla smaragdina; Tetraponera allaborans; Tetraponera rufonigra; Formicinae; Pseudomyrmecinae; Asia; India; Asia; India; scientific; workers; morphology; behavior; mimicry; Batesian mimicry; Wasmannian mimicry; chemical mimicry; ant models; myrmecomorphy; Salticidae; spiders; Myrmarachne maratha; Myrmarachne orientales; Myrmarachne plataleoides;

author: Saha, S.P. and Saroja, C. and Srijana, R. and Hrishikesh, C.
title: Evaluation of ant nest microenvironment from Darjeeling Himalaya
abstract: *[This study on ant-nest soil samples collected from the Southwest Darjeeling Himalaya area revealed that microbial load of nest soil were remarkably higher in number compare to that of the surrounding area, irrespective of ant genus.  Twenty nests samples from Solenopsis, Monomorium, & Camponotus were studied.  The nest soils were mostly in the neutral range pH, with high moisture content, & appeared chemically rich in organic carbon, nitrogenous compounds, & available phosphorus.  As Darjeeling Himalayan soils faces a constant demand for nutrients specially for nitrogen & phosphorus, ant-left nest soil can meet that following proper agro-ecological management practices.]          *[Camponotus misspelled Componotus.]
keywords: ant; Formicidae; Camponotus; Monomorium; Solenopsis; Formicinae; Myrmicinae; Asia; India; scientific; nests; ant-nest microbes; soil; soil nutrients; pH; moisture content; organic carbon; nitrogenous compounds; phosphorus;

author: Sahai, K.
title: Reproductive biology of two species of Canavalia DC. (Fabaceae): A non-conventional wild legume
note: Part of FORMIS 10; from NAL's AGRICOLA; from-DPW,
abstract: The reproductive biology of two important species of Canavalia, i.e. Canavalia gladiata and Canavalia virosa, was investigated in detail by studying floral phenology, floral biology including fruit and seed set, breeding system and pollinator's activity. Both the species flower and set their seed primarily from August to December. The study of pollen--pistil interaction indicated the existence of morphological protandry in both species, and pollen germination occurred only after rupture of the stigmatic surface. This suggests that some form of self-incompatibility operates in these species. Ants were the common vectors tripping the stigma and transporting some foreign pollen. Campylomma verbasci (large black ants) were only seen on the flowers of C. virosa, while Monomorium minimum (small black ants) were restricted to the flowers of C. gladiata. Inadequacy of reliable pollinators and high rate of bud/flower drop may be the main factors for low fruit and seed set in both the species.    NOTE: Peng & Christian 2008 indicated that Campylomma is a genus of bugs, Hemiptera: Miridae.          *[Small black ants (Monomorium  minimum) & big black ants (Campylomma verbasci) were the frequent visitors for C. gladiata & C. virosa, respectively, & mainly behaved as primary nectar robbers.  Their number & visiting frequency were maximum in the morning & minimum in the afternoon.]
